He'll ride in on that horse of his, all dressed up in his finery, and the people will think he's a real nobleman. Then I'll come in with my royal papers and my fine clothes, and we'll tell 'em we're the Duke and the King from Europe. They'll be so impressed they won't know what to do. Then we'll start the show. The king will do his royal speeches, and I'll do my magic tricks. We'll have the people eating out of our hands in no time. And then, when the time is right, we'll collect our money. We'll set up a collection box, and the people will be so taken in by our show they'll be throwing in their hard-earned cash like it's nothing. We'll be rich before we know it. And then we'll move on to the next town, and do it all over again. It's a fine plan, and I don't see any reason why it shouldn't work. The people are always looking for a good show, and we're the best show in town. We just need to make sure we're ready for the next town. We need to practice our lines, and make sure our clothes are in good shape. And we need to make sure we're not caught by the sheriff. He's been on to us before, and I don't want to end up in jail again. So let's get to work, and make sure we're ready for the next town. We've got a long way to go, and we can't afford to waste any time. The money's waiting for us, and we're going to get it, one town at a time.

events.title: Scouting and Advertising the Show in an Arkansas Town
detailed_summary: At their earliest convenience, the Duke arranged for the printing of show bills.
For the subsequent two or three days, as they drifted downriver, the raft was exceptionally animated with continuous sword-fighting and theatrical rehearsals.
While navigating through Arkansas, they came upon a small, unremarkable town located in a prominent bend of the river.

They secured their raft approximately three-quarters of a mile upstream, concealed within a cypress-bordered creek, and everyone except Jim disembarked in a canoe to explore the town's prospects for their performance.
They discovered that a circus was scheduled for that afternoon, with rural attendees already arriving, but its departure by nightfall would create an opportunity for their show.
The Duke successfully rented the local courthouse as their venue, and the group then proceeded to distribute their promotional posters throughout the town.

The show bills ambitiously proclaimed a "Shaksperean Revival!!!" as a "Wonderful Attraction! For One Night Only!" featuring the "world renowned tragedians, David Garrick the younger" (the Duke) and "Edmund Kean the elder" (the King), from prestigious London theatres, performing "The Balcony Scene" from Romeo and Juliet, a "thrilling, masterly, and blood-curdling Broad-sword conflict In Richard III.!!!", and, by special request, "Hamlet’s Immortal Soliloquy!!" by Kean, allegedly performed for 300 consecutive nights in Paris, all due to "imperative European engagements." Admission was priced at 25 cents, with a reduced rate of 10 cents for children and servants.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The first chance we got, the duke he had some show bills printed; and after that, for two or three days as we floated along, the raft was a most uncommon lively place, for there warn’t nothing but sword-fighting and rehearsing—as the duke called it—going on all the time.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Admission 25 cents; children and servants, 10 cents.

events.text_segment:
The first chance we got, the duke he had some show bills printed; and after that, for two or three days as we floated along, the raft was a most uncommon lively place, for there warn’t nothing but sword-fighting and rehearsing—as the duke called it—going on all the time. One morning, when we was pretty well down the State of Arkansaw, we come in sight of a little one-horse town in a big bend; so we tied up about three-quarters of a mile above it, in the mouth of a crick which was shut in like a tunnel by the cypress trees, and all of us but Jim took the canoe and went down there to see if there was any chance in that place for our show.
We struck it mighty lucky; there was going to be a circus there that afternoon, and the country people was already beginning to come in, in all kinds of old shackly wagons, and on horses. The circus would leave before night, so our show would have a pretty good chance. The duke he hired the court house, and we went around and stuck up our bills. They read like this:
Shaksperean Revival!!!
Wonderful Attraction!
For One Night Only!
The world renowned tragedians,
David Garrick the younger, of Drury Lane Theatre, London,
and
Edmund Kean the elder, of the Royal Haymarket Theatre,
Whitechapel, Pudding Lane, Piccadilly, London, and the
Royal Continental Theatres, in their sublime
Shaksperean Spectacle entitled
The Balcony Scene
in
Romeo and Juliet!!!

Romeo...................................... Mr. Garrick.
Juliet..................................... Mr. Kean.

Assisted by the whole strength of the company!
New costumes, new scenery, new appointments!

Also:
The thrilling, masterly, and blood-curdling
Broad-sword conflict
In Richard III.!!!

Richard III................................ Mr. Garrick.
Richmond................................... Mr. Kean.

also:
(by special request,)
Hamlet’s Immortal Soliloquy!!
By the Illustrious Kean!
Done by him 300 consecutive nights in Paris!
For One Night Only,
On account of imperative European engagements!
Admission 25 cents; children and servants, 10 cents.

We was in Arkansas now, and come to a little town in a big bend of the river, and we tied up the raft about three-quarters of a mile above, in a cypress thicket, and went into town in the canoe to see what luck we might have. We found out there was a circus going on that afternoon, and the country folks was all coming in, but it was going to leave that night, so we thought we’d have a good chance. The duke rented the court-house for us, and then we went to work and plastered the town with our bills. They said it was a 'Shaksperean Revival!!!' and a 'Wonderful Attraction! Admission was twenty-five cents, and ten cents for children and servants.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: The first chance we got, the duke he had some show bills printed; and after that, for two or three days as we floated along, the raft was a most uncommon lively place, for there warn’t nothing but sword-fighting and rehearsing—as the duke called it—going on all the time. He and the king would dress up in all sorts of costumes and act out plays they had never heard of before, making up the parts as they went along. They were so full of themselves and their own importance that they didn’t notice how the rest of us felt about it. Tom and I watched them with a kind of amused patience, though we didn’t take part in the show ourselves. We knew it was all a farce, and we were just waiting for the time when the people in the towns we passed would come to see it and laugh at the duke and the king for the frauds they were. But in the meantime, the duke and the king were having a fine time of it, and they were getting more and more confident with every performance. They even started charging people to come and see their shows, and they were making a good bit of money out of it. But I could see that it wouldn’t last long, for the people would soon get wise to them and find out that they were nothing but a couple of impostors. And I was right, for it wasn’t long before the people in the next town we came to saw through the whole thing and chased them out of town with a lot of noise and confusion. But that’s another story, and I’ll tell it when I get to it.

events.title: Huck's Observations of a Dilapidated Arkansas Town and its Idle Inhabitants
characters: Loafers (Bill, Buck, Hank, Joe, Andy, Lafe Buckner)
detailed_summary: The group then wandered through the town, taking in its general state of disrepair.

Huck noted that the stores and houses were predominantly old, unpainted wooden structures, elevated on stilts to protect against river flooding. Their gardens appeared neglected, primarily cultivating weeds, sunflowers, and accumulating debris like ash-piles and old discarded items.

The fences were haphazardly constructed from various types of boards added at different times, leaning in multiple directions, and often equipped with only a single leather hinge for a gate. Some bore faint remnants of whitewash, which the Duke humorously suggested dated back to Columbus's era.
Hogs were a common sight in gardens, with residents frequently attempting to shoo them away.
All the town's stores were situated along a single street, featuring white fabric awnings in front, where country visitors would tie their horses.

Under these awnings, idle men, referred to as loafers, spent their days perched on empty dry-goods boxes, whittling wood with Barlow knives, chewing tobacco, and exhibiting general lethargy through yawning and stretching—a rather uncouth assembly.

These men typically wore wide-brimmed yellow straw hats but no coats or waistcoats, addressed each other by familiar names like Bill, Buck, Hank, Joe, and Andy, spoke in a slow, lazy drawl, and used a considerable amount of profanity.
Nearly every awning-post had a loafer leaning against it, usually with hands in pockets, except when retrieving tobacco or scratching.
Huck described their conversations, highlighting the frequent requests to borrow chewing tobacco, often accompanied by false claims about having just given away their last piece.
He detailed the ritual of sharing tobacco, where a borrower would gnaw off a piece from a plug, sometimes to the feigned dismay of the owner.
The town's streets and alleys were entirely composed of mud, deep and black in places, and universally present.

Hogs were ubiquitous, lounging and grunting throughout the town. A common sight was a muddy sow with her piglets leisurely occupying a walkway, forcing people to detour, while she appeared contentedly nursing her young.

This tranquility would often be broken by a loafer inciting a dog to chase the sow, leading to a chaotic pursuit that amused the onlookers, who would then resettle until the next diversion, such as a dog fight.
The narrator observed that nothing animated the loafers as much as a dog fight, unless it was a cruel prank like setting fire to a stray dog or tying a tin pan to its tail.
Some houses along the riverfront were precariously situated, leaning and appearing ready to collapse into the water due to erosion, though some were still inhabited despite the danger.
The town was in a constant state of retreat as the river relentlessly eroded its banks.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Then we went loafing around the town.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Such a town as that has to be always moving back, and back, and back, because the river’s always gnawing at it.

events.text_segment:
Then we went loafing around the town. The stores and houses was most all old shackly dried-up frame concerns that hadn’t ever been painted; they was set up three or four foot above ground on stilts, so as to be out of reach of the water when the river was overflowed. The houses had little gardens around them, but they didn’t seem to raise hardly anything in them but jimpson weeds, and sunflowers, and ash-piles, and old curled-up boots and shoes, and pieces of bottles, and rags, and played-out tin-ware. The fences was made of different kinds of boards, nailed on at different times; and they leaned every which-way, and had gates that didn’t generly have but one hinge—a leather one. Some of the fences had been whitewashed, some time or another, but the duke said it was in Clumbus’s time, like enough. There was generly hogs in the garden, and people driving them out.
All the stores was along one street. They had white domestic awnings in front, and the country people hitched their horses to the awning-posts. There was empty drygoods boxes under the awnings, and loafers roosting on them all day long, whittling them with their Barlow knives; and chawing tobacco, and gaping and yawning and stretching—a mighty ornery lot. They generly had on yellow straw hats most as wide as an umbrella, but didn’t wear no coats nor waistcoats, they called one another Bill, and Buck, and Hank, and Joe, and Andy, and talked lazy and drawly, and used considerable many cuss words. There was as many as one loafer leaning up against every awning-post, and he most always had his hands in his britches-pockets, except when he fetched them out to lend a chaw of tobacco or scratch. What a body was hearing amongst them all the time was:
“Gimme a chaw ’v tobacker, Hank.”
“Cain’t; I hain’t got but one chaw left. Ask Bill.”
Maybe Bill he gives him a chaw; maybe he lies and says he ain’t got none. Some of them kinds of loafers never has a cent in the world, nor a chaw of tobacco of their own. They get all their chawing by borrowing; they say to a fellow, “I wisht you’d len’ me a chaw, Jack, I jist this minute give Ben Thompson the last chaw I had”—which is a lie pretty much everytime; it don’t fool nobody but a stranger; but Jack ain’t no stranger, so he says:
“You give him a chaw, did you? So did your sister’s cat’s grandmother. You pay me back the chaws you’ve awready borry’d off’n me, Lafe Buckner, then I’ll loan you one or two ton of it, and won’t charge you no back intrust, nuther.”
“Well, I did pay you back some of it wunst.”
“Yes, you did—’bout six chaws. You borry’d store tobacker and paid back nigger-head.”
Store tobacco is flat black plug, but these fellows mostly chaws the natural leaf twisted. When they borrow a chaw they don’t generly cut it off with a knife, but set the plug in between their teeth, and gnaw with their teeth and tug at the plug with their hands till they get it in two; then sometimes the one that owns the tobacco looks mournful at it when it’s handed back, and says, sarcastic:
“Here, gimme the chaw, and you take the plug.”
All the streets and lanes was just mud; they warn’t nothing else but mud—mud as black as tar and nigh about a foot deep in some places, and two or three inches deep in all the places. The hogs loafed and grunted around everywheres. You’d see a muddy sow and a litter of pigs come lazying along the street and whollop herself right down in the way, where folks had to walk around her, and she’d stretch out and shut her eyes and wave her ears whilst the pigs was milking her, and look as happy as if she was on salary. And pretty soon you’d hear a loafer sing out, “Hi! so boy! sick him, Tige!” and away the sow would go, squealing most horrible, with a dog or two swinging to each ear, and three or four dozen more a-coming; and then you would see all the loafers get up and watch the thing out of sight, and laugh at the fun and look grateful for the noise. Then they’d settle back again till there was a dog fight. There couldn’t anything wake them up all over, and make them happy all over, like a dog fight—unless it might be putting turpentine on a stray dog and setting fire to him, or tying a tin pan to his tail and see him run himself to death.
On the river front some of the houses was sticking out over the bank, and they was bowed and bent, and about ready to tumble in. The people had moved out of them. The bank was caved away under one corner of some others, and that corner was hanging over. People lived in them yet, but it was dangersome, because sometimes a strip of land as wide as a house caves in at a time. Sometimes a belt of land a quarter of a mile deep will start in and cave along and cave along till it all caves into the river in one summer. Such a town as that has to be always moving back, and back, and back, because the river’s always gnawing at it.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: Then we went loafing around the town. It was a poor place enough. The stores and houses were mostly frame buildings, old and un-painted, set up on stilts to keep them from the rise of the river. Their gardens were mostly patches of weeds and sunflowers, and ash-piles, and old trash. The fences were made of odds and ends of boards, put up any way that was handy, and leaning every which way, and mostly with only one leather hinge to a gate. Some of them had a little whitewash on them, and the Duke said that was from the time of Columbus. There was hogs in the gardens, and the people would be after them with sticks and hoes, trying to drive them out. All the stores were along one street, with white cloth awnings in front, where the country folks would tie their horses. Under these awnings, the loafers sat on empty dry-goods boxes, whittling with Barlow knives, and chewing tobacco, and yawning and stretching, and looking mighty lazy and uncivilized. They wore wide-brimmed yellow straw hats, and no coats or waistcoats, and called each other Bill and Buck and Hank and Joe and Andy, and talked in a slow, lazy drawl, and swore a good deal. Nearly every awning-post had a loafer leaning against it, with his hands in his pockets, unless he was reaching for his tobacco or scratching. They would talk about nothing but the weather, and the price of cotton, and the politics of the county, and the fights they had had, and the ones they were going to have. They would borrow each other's tobacco a good deal, and say they had just given away the last of theirs, and then they would gnaw off a piece of the plug, and the owner would pretend to be real mad, and say he would have to go without, and then they would laugh about it. The streets and alleys were all mud, and deep and black in places, and always there. The hogs were everywhere, lying around and grunting. You would see a sow, all muddy, with her pigs, lying in the middle of the walk, and you would have to go around her, and she would be contented and chewing her cud. Then some loafer would get up and go after a dog, and make it chase the sow, and then all the loafers would get up and go after the dog, and then they would all settle down again, and wait for the next thing to happen. Nothing would make them so lively as a dog-fight, unless it was to set fire to a stray dog, or tie a tin pan to its tail. Some of the houses along the river were leaning over, and looked as if they were going to fall into the water, but they were still lived in, and the people didn't seem to mind.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: Then we went loafing around the town. We didn't have no particular place to go, and we didn't care. It was a lazy kind of day, and the sun was hot, and the streets were full of dust and the smell of the river. We just kind of drifted along, not saying much, just enjoying the feel of being free and not having to answer to nobody. I was in a new pair of clothes that Tom Sawyer had given me, and they were too tight in the waist and too long in the legs, but I didn't care. I was used to being dressed up, and I figured it was better than being in rags like I used to be. Jim was in a new suit too, and he looked proud of it. He said he had been saving up for it for a long time, and he was going to wear it to town every Sunday. I told him he'd wear it out in a week if he did that, but he just laughed and said he didn't care. We passed by the courthouse, and there was a crowd gathered around the steps. I could see a man standing there with a paper in his hand, and he was reading something out loud. I couldn't hear what he was saying, but I could see the people listening and nodding their heads. Jim said it was probably some kind of news about the war, and I said I didn't care about the war. I had more important things to worry about, like keeping Jim from getting caught and me from getting into trouble. We kept on walking, and we passed by the jailhouse. I could see a man sitting on the steps, and he looked like he was waiting for something. I didn't know who he was, but I had a feeling he was trouble. Jim said we should keep going, and I agreed. We didn't want to get mixed up in no trouble, especially not with the law. We went into a store and bought some candy and a newspaper. The man behind the counter looked at me funny when I paid with the money I had saved up, but I didn't say nothing. I just took the change and walked out. Jim said the man probably thought I was a thief, but I said I didn't care. I was used to people looking at me funny. We read the newspaper on the steps of the store, and there was a story about a runaway slave who had been caught and was going to be sold down the river. I felt a chill run down my back when I read that, and I looked at Jim. He didn't say nothing, but I could see the worry in his eyes. I told him we had to be careful, and he said he knew. We folded up the paper and walked on, and I could feel the weight of the world on my shoulders. I was just a boy, but I had to be responsible for Jim's life, and that was a heavy burden. We went to the river and sat on the dock, watching the water. It was peaceful there, and the sound of the water was like a lullaby. I thought about my father and how he used to drink and beat me, and I thought about Tom Sawyer and how he was always getting into trouble but never really had to pay for it. I thought about Jim and how he had been a slave and how he had risked everything to run away. I thought about the world and how it was full of bad people and good people, and how it was hard to tell the difference sometimes. Jim said he was tired, and I said I was too. We lay back on the dock and looked up at the sky, and I could see the stars starting to come out. It was a beautiful night, and I felt like I was part of something bigger than myself. I didn't know what the future held, but I knew that I had to keep going, no matter what. I had to keep Jim safe, and I had to find a way to be free. And maybe, just maybe, I could find a way to be happy too.

events.title: The Arrival of Drunken Boggs and His Threats Against Colonel Sherburn
detailed_summary: As midday approached, the town's streets became increasingly congested with wagons and horses, with a continuous influx of people.
Families arriving from the countryside ate their meals in their wagons, while considerable whisky consumption and at least three fights were observed by Huck.
Suddenly, someone announced the arrival of "old Boggs" from the country for his regular monthly drunken spree.

The loafers appeared pleased, evidently accustomed to deriving entertainment from Boggs's behavior. One remarked on Boggs's history of unfulfilled threats, while another joked that being threatened by Boggs was a guarantee of a long life.
Boggs then came riding wildly on his horse, shouting like a Native American and proclaiming that he was on the warpath and the price of coffins was about to rise.

He was clearly intoxicated, swaying in his saddle, over fifty years old, with a notably red face. The crowd shouted at him, laughed, and taunted him, and he responded in kind, stating he would deal with them later but first had to kill Colonel Sherburn, adhering to his motto of "Meat first, and spoon vittles to top off on."
Boggs noticed Huck, rode up to him, and asked if he was prepared to die, before continuing on his way.

Huck was frightened by the encounter, but a bystander reassured him that Boggs meant no harm, describing him as a habitually boisterous but ultimately harmless drunkard, the most good-natured old fool in Arkansas, who never injured anyone, whether drunk or sober.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The nearer it got to noon that day the thicker and thicker was the wagons and horses in the streets, and more coming all the time.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: He’s the best naturedest old fool in Arkansaw—never hurt nobody, drunk nor sober.”

events.text_segment:
The nearer it got to noon that day the thicker and thicker was the wagons and horses in the streets, and more coming all the time. Families fetched their dinners with them from the country, and eat them in the wagons. There was considerable whisky drinking going on, and I seen three fights. By-and-by somebody sings out:
“Here comes old Boggs!—in from the country for his little old monthly drunk; here he comes, boys!”
All the loafers looked glad; I reckoned they was used to having fun out of Boggs. One of them says:
“Wonder who he’s a-gwyne to chaw up this time. If he’d a-chawed up all the men he’s ben a-gwyne to chaw up in the last twenty year he’d have considerable ruputation now.”
Another one says, “I wisht old Boggs ’d threaten me, ’cuz then I’d know I warn’t gwyne to die for a thousan’ year.”
Boggs comes a-tearing along on his horse, whooping and yelling like an Injun, and singing out:
“Cler the track, thar. I’m on the waw-path, and the price uv coffins is a-gwyne to raise.”
He was drunk, and weaving about in his saddle; he was over fifty year old, and had a very red face. Everybody yelled at him and laughed at him and sassed him, and he sassed back, and said he’d attend to them and lay them out in their regular turns, but he couldn’t wait now because he’d come to town to kill old Colonel Sherburn, and his motto was, “Meat first, and spoon vittles to top off on.”
He see me, and rode up and says:
“Whar’d you come f’m, boy? You prepared to die?”
Then he rode on. I was scared, but a man says:
“He don’t mean nothing; he’s always a-carryin’ on like that when he’s drunk. He’s the best naturedest old fool in Arkansaw—never hurt nobody, drunk nor sober.”

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: The nearer it got to noon that day the thicker and thicker was the wagons and horses in the streets, and more coming all the time. The country folks had brought their dinner with them in their wagons, and they ate there, and there was considerable whisky consumed, and three or four fights. Then all at once a man says, "Here comes old Boggs!" and the loafers lit out for the street, and the rest of the crowd did the same. They were all glad to see Boggs, because he was a kind of a public property, and they had got to be used to him. One of them said he had threatened to kill more people than any man in the country, and never done it. Another said that if a man had a mind to, he could live to be a hundred and ten in that town, just by keeping out of Boggs’s way. Boggs came riding along, wild and free, and whooping like an Indian, and saying he was on the warpath, and the price of coffins was going to rise. He was drunk, and swaying in his saddle, and he was over fifty years old, and had a red face. LLM_completions.prefix-probing: The nearer it got to noon that day the thicker and thicker was the wagons and horses in the streets, and more coming all the time. The town was alive with excitement, for it was the day of the big race, and folks had come from miles around to see the best jockeys and fastest horses in the territory. The air was thick with the smell of fried chicken, corn, and sweat, and the sound of fiddles and banjos filled the square. Children ran through the crowd, their faces painted and their eyes wide with anticipation, while old men sat on barrels, betting and arguing over the odds. Huck Finn, dressed in borrowed clothes and trying to look like he belonged, kept his eyes peeled for trouble. He had a plan, and it involved getting to the river before the race started. He had heard that the ferry was going to be busy, and he didn't want to be caught in the crush of people and wagons. He had a feeling something was going to happen, and he wasn't about to be caught in the middle of it. He had seen enough of the world to know that when things get too loud and too crowded, it's time to slip away and find a quiet place to think. So he turned down a side street, away from the noise and the excitement, and headed toward the river, where the only thing that mattered was the water and the sky and the promise of freedom.

events.title: Colonel Sherburn's Ultimatum and Boggs's Continued Defiance
detailed_summary: Boggs positioned himself in front of the town's most prominent store and, peering under the awning, loudly called for Sherburn to come out and face him, accusing Sherburn of swindling him and declaring his intent to get him.
He continued to hurl every insult he could think of at Sherburn, while the street filled with people who listened, laughed, and commented on the spectacle.
After some time, a distinguished-looking man of about fifty-five, who was also the best-dressed individual in town, stepped out of the store. The crowd instinctively fell back to allow him passage.

This man, Colonel Sherburn, addressed Boggs in a very calm and deliberate manner, stating that he was tired of Boggs's behavior but would tolerate it until one o'clock, and no later. He warned Boggs that if he uttered even one more word against him after that time, Sherburn would find him, no matter how far he traveled.
Sherburn then turned and went back into the store. The crowd became very subdued; no one moved, and the laughter ceased.

Boggs, however, rode off, continuing to revile Sherburn as loudly as he could yell, all the way down the street. Shortly after, he returned and stopped before the store, resuming his abusive shouting.
Some men gathered around Boggs, attempting to persuade him to be quiet, and told him it would be one o'clock in about fifteen minutes, urging him to go home immediately. Their efforts were futile.
Boggs persisted in his cursing with all his might, threw his hat into the mud, rode his horse over it, and then galloped off down the street again in a rage, his gray hair flying.
Everyone who could get near him tried to coax him off his horse so they could detain him and let him sober up, but to no avail—he would tear up the street again to hurl more curses at Sherburn.
Eventually, someone suggested fetching Boggs's daughter, reasoning that she sometimes had influence over him and might be able to persuade him if anyone could.
Following this suggestion, someone set off running to find her.

events.text_segment:
Boggs rode up before the biggest store in town, and bent his head down so he could see under the curtain of the awning and yells:
“Come out here, Sherburn! Come out and meet the man you’ve swindled. You’re the houn’ I’m after, and I’m a-gwyne to have you, too!”
And so he went on, calling Sherburn everything he could lay his tongue to, and the whole street packed with people listening and laughing and going on. By-and-by a proud-looking man about fifty-five—and he was a heap the best dressed man in that town, too—steps out of the store, and the crowd drops back on each side to let him come. He says to Boggs, mighty ca’m and slow—he says:
“I’m tired of this, but I’ll endure it till one o’clock. Till one o’clock, mind—no longer. If you open your mouth against me only once after that time you can’t travel so far but I will find you.”
Then he turns and goes in. The crowd looked mighty sober; nobody stirred, and there warn’t no more laughing. Boggs rode off blackguarding Sherburn as loud as he could yell, all down the street; and pretty soon back he comes and stops before the store, still keeping it up. Some men crowded around him and tried to get him to shut up, but he wouldn’t; they told him it would be one o’clock in about fifteen minutes, and so he must go home—he must go right away. But it didn’t do no good. He cussed away with all his might, and throwed his hat down in the mud and rode over it, and pretty soon away he went a-raging down the street again, with his gray hair a-flying. Everybody that could get a chance at him tried their best to coax him off of his horse so they could lock him up and get him sober; but it warn’t no use—up the street he would tear again, and give Sherburn another cussing. By-and-by somebody says:
“Go for his daughter!—quick, go for his daughter; sometimes he’ll listen to her. If anybody can persuade him, she can.”
So somebody started on a run.

**Chapter XXI.**

Boggs rode up before the biggest store in town, and bent his head down so he could see under the curtain of the awning and yells:

"Come out, you cowardly thief! I want to see your face when I tell you what I think of you!"

He positioned himself in front of the store, his voice booming through the quiet morning air. The townspeople began to gather, drawn by the commotion. They leaned against doorways, perched on fence posts, and stood in clusters, watching with a mix of amusement and unease. Boggs, red-faced and wild-eyed, continued to hurl every insult he could think of at the unseen figure inside. "You swindled me, Sherburn! You took my money and left me with nothing but a broken promise!"

The crowd laughed, some clapping their hands and shouting encouragement. A few even joined in, adding their own jabs at the man behind the awning. The atmosphere was electric, a mix of mockery and morbid curiosity.

After some time, a distinguished-looking man of about fifty-five, who was also the best-dressed individual in town, stepped out of the store. The crowd instinctively fell back to allow him passage. He was tall and composed, his every movement exuding a quiet authority. Colonel Sherburn, the man Boggs had been calling out to, now stood before them, his expression unreadable.

"You've had your say, Boggs," Sherburn said, his voice calm and deliberate. "I am tired of your behavior, but I will tolerate it until one o'clock, and no later. If you utter even one more word against me after that time, I will find you, no matter how far you travel."

With that, he turned and went back into the store, leaving the crowd in stunned silence. The laughter ceased, and the air grew heavy with an unspoken tension.

Boggs, however, was not to be deterred. He rode off, continuing to revile Sherburn as loudly as he could yell, all the way down the street. "You're a coward, Sherburn! A yellow-bellied, back-stabbing—"

Shorty after, he returned and stopped before the store, resuming his abusive shouting. The townspeople, now subdued, watched in uneasy silence. Some men gathered around Boggs, attempting to persuade him to be quiet. "It'll be one o'clock in about fifteen minutes," one of them said. "Go home, Boggs. You're making a fool of yourself."

Their efforts were futile. Boggs persisted in his cursing with all his might, threw his hat into the mud, rode his horse over it, and then galloped off down the street again in a rage, his gray hair flying in the wind.

Everyone who could get near him tried to coax him off his horse so they could detain him and let him sober up, but to no avail—he would tear up the street again to hurl more curses at Sherburn.

Eventually, someone suggested fetching Boggs's daughter, reasoning that she sometimes had influence over him and might be able to persuade him if anyone could.

Following this suggestion, someone set off running to find her.

---

**End of Simulated Output**

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: Boggs rode up before the biggest store in town, and bent his head down so he could see under the curtain of the awning and yells: 'Hello, there, you damned old drunk! I've been looking all over for you!' The people that was in the store all turned around and looked, and some of them stepped out on the sidewalk to see what it was about. Colonel Sherburn, who was the man Boggs was talking to, he didn't seem to be much surprised, but he just looked up and said, 'I don't want any trouble, Boggs. I'm not in the mood for it.' But Boggs, he was a man that didn't know when to quit. He said, 'You ain't in the mood for it? Well, I am! I've had about enough of you and your high and mighty ways. You think you're too good for this town, don't you?' Colonel Sherburn just looked at him, calm as you please, and said, 'I don't know what you're talking about, Boggs. I've never done you any harm.' But Boggs, he was a man that didn't know when to quit. He said, 'You didn't have to do me no harm. You just had to act like you was better than me, and that was enough to make me sick.' And with that, he drew his gun and fired. The bullet went clean through Colonel Sherburn's hat, and the Colonel just stood there, calm as ever, and said, 'Well, I reckon that's the end of that.' And then he turned around and walked into the store, and the people that was there, they just stood there, not knowing what to do. Some of them said it was a shame, and others said it was about time someone put a stop to Boggs' foolishness. But the truth is, Boggs had been a man that had a lot of enemies in town, and this was just one more in a long line of troubles that he had brought on himself. And so, the people just went back to their business, and the town went on as if nothing had happened, except for the fact that Boggs was dead and Colonel Sherburn was still alive, and that was something that a lot of people in town were glad about.

events.title: Colonel Sherburn Shoots Boggs in Cold Blood
detailed_summary: Huck, having moved further down the street, paused and observed Boggs being hurried along by two companions, one on each arm. Boggs was bare-headed, walking unsteadily but not resisting, looking uneasy and actively participating in the hurried movement.
Suddenly, Colonel Sherburn's voice called out, "Boggs!"
Huck looked and saw Colonel Sherburn standing perfectly still in the street, holding a pistol in his right hand, its barrel pointed skyward, not yet aimed.
At that same instant, Huck saw a young girl, Boggs's daughter, running towards them, accompanied by two men.
Boggs and his companions turned to see who had called his name. Upon seeing Sherburn with the pistol, Boggs's escorts jumped to the side.
Sherburn slowly and deliberately lowered the pistol to a level aim, with both barrels cocked.
Boggs threw up both his hands and cried out, "O Lord, don’t shoot!"
The first shot rang out, and Boggs staggered backward, clawing at the air. The second shot followed immediately, and Boggs fell heavily to the ground, his arms spread wide.
The young girl screamed, rushed forward, and threw herself onto her father, crying out that he had been killed.
The crowd quickly closed in around them, jostling and craning their necks to see, while those on the inside tried to push them back, shouting for them to give Boggs air.
Colonel Sherburn casually tossed his pistol onto the ground, turned on his heel, and walked away.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: I walked down street a ways and stopped.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Colonel Sherburn he tossed his pistol onto the ground, and turned around on his heels and walked off.

events.text_segment:
I walked down street a ways and stopped. In about five or ten minutes here comes Boggs again, but not on his horse. He was a-reeling across the street towards me, bare-headed, with a friend on both sides of him a-holt of his arms and hurrying him along. He was quiet, and looked uneasy; and he warn’t hanging back any, but was doing some of the hurrying himself. Somebody sings out:
“Boggs!”
I looked over there to see who said it, and it was that Colonel Sherburn. He was standing perfectly still in the street, and had a pistol raised in his right hand—not aiming it, but holding it out with the barrel tilted up towards the sky. The same second I see a young girl coming on the run, and two men with her. Boggs and the men turned round to see who called him, and when they see the pistol the men jumped to one side, and the pistol-barrel come down slow and steady to a level—both barrels cocked. Boggs throws up both of his hands and says, “O Lord, don’t shoot!” Bang! goes the first shot, and he staggers back, clawing at the air—bang! goes the second one, and he tumbles backwards onto the ground, heavy and solid, with his arms spread out. That young girl screamed out and comes rushing, and down she throws herself on her father, crying, and saying, “Oh, he’s killed him, he’s killed him!” The crowd closed up around them, and shouldered and jammed one another, with their necks stretched, trying to see, and people on the inside trying to shove them back and shouting, “Back, back! give him air, give him air!”
Colonel Sherburn he tossed his pistol onto the ground, and turned around on his heels and walked off.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: I walked down street a ways and stopped. I was feeling kind of lonesome and tired, and I didn't know where I was going or what I was going to do. The town was quiet, and the sun was getting low in the sky. I looked around, trying to figure out what to do next. I didn't want to go back to the widow's house, 'cause I didn't feel like being civilized no more. I wanted to be free, like I was before I met her and got all these rules and manners shoved down my throat. I thought about Jim and how he was probably still down by the river, waiting for me. I had to find him, but I didn't know how to get to him without being seen. I was scared that someone might recognize me and tell on me, but I didn't care no more. I was a runaway, and I was going to stay one. I started walking again, keeping to the shadows and trying to stay out of sight. I passed by the courthouse and the jail, and I could see folks going about their business, not knowing what I was up to. I felt like a ghost, invisible and alone. I kept thinking about what Tom Sawyer would do in my place, and I figured he'd probably have a plan all worked out. But I wasn't Tom Sawyer. I was just Huck Finn, trying to do what was right and find my friend. I finally came to the edge of town, where the woods started, and I knew I was getting close to where Jim was hiding. I took a deep breath and stepped into the trees, hoping I was making the right choice.

events.title: Boggs's Death, the Town's Morbid Curiosity, and the Call for Lynching Sherburn
detailed_summary: Boggs was transported to a small drugstore, with the crowd maintaining its tight formation around him and the entire town trailing behind. Huck managed to secure a prime viewing spot at the window, close enough to see everything inside.

Inside the drugstore, Boggs was laid on the floor. A large Bible was placed under his head, and another was opened and spread across his chest, but only after his shirt was torn open, revealing to Huck the entry point of one of the bullets.
Boggs took about a dozen deep, gasping breaths, his chest rising and falling with the Bible, before he became still; he was dead.

His daughter, screaming and crying, was then pulled away from his body and taken off. She was described as about sixteen years old, with a sweet and gentle appearance, though terribly pale and frightened.

Soon, the entire town seemed to have gathered, squirming and pushing to get to the window for a look, while those already occupying the vantage points refused to yield them. People in the back complained about the unfairness of others monopolizing the view.
Amidst considerable bickering, Huck decided to leave, anticipating potential trouble.
The streets were packed with excited people. Everyone who had witnessed the shooting was recounting the details, surrounded by large, attentive crowds craning their necks to listen.

One particularly notable figure, a tall, lanky man with long hair, a large white fur stovepipe hat worn on the back of his head, and a crooked-handled cane, demonstrated the sequence of events. He marked the spots on the ground where Boggs and Sherburn had stood, and the crowd followed him from place to place, observing his every move, nodding to show their understanding, and stooping to watch him mark the locations with his cane.

This man then stood straight and stiff where Sherburn had been, frowning with his hat brim pulled low over his eyes, shouted "Boggs!", then slowly brought his cane down to a level as if aiming, said "Bang!", staggered backward, said "Bang!" again, and fell flat on his back.
Those who had seen the actual shooting declared his reenactment perfect, stating it was exactly how it had all occurred. Afterward, as many as a dozen people offered him drinks from their bottles.
After a while, someone suggested that Colonel Sherburn should be lynched.
Within about a minute, this sentiment was echoed by everyone, and the crowd, now enraged and shouting, set off, tearing down every clothesline they encountered to use for the hanging.

segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: In about a minute everybody was saying it; so away they went, mad and yelling, and snatching down every clothes-line they come to, to do the hanging with.

events.text_segment:
They took Boggs to a little drug store, the crowd pressing around just the same, and the whole town following, and I rushed and got a good place at the window, where I was close to him and could see in. They laid him on the floor and put one large Bible under his head, and opened another one and spread it on his breast; but they tore open his shirt first, and I seen where one of the bullets went in. He made about a dozen long gasps, his breast lifting the Bible up when he drawed in his breath, and letting it down again when he breathed it out—and after that he laid still; he was dead. Then they pulled his daughter away from him, screaming and crying, and took her off. She was about sixteen, and very sweet and gentle-looking, but awful pale and scared.
Well, pretty soon the whole town was there, squirming and scrouging and pushing and shoving to get at the window and have a look, but people that had the places wouldn’t give them up, and folks behind them was saying all the time, “Say, now, you’ve looked enough, you fellows; ’tain’t right and ’tain’t fair for you to stay thar all the time, and never give nobody a chance; other folks has their rights as well as you.”
There was considerable jawing back, so I slid out, thinking maybe there was going to be trouble. The streets was full, and everybody was excited. Everybody that seen the shooting was telling how it happened, and there was a big crowd packed around each one of these fellows, stretching their necks and listening. One long, lanky man, with long hair and a big white fur stovepipe hat on the back of his head, and a crooked-handled cane, marked out the places on the ground where Boggs stood and where Sherburn stood, and the people following him around from one place to t’other and watching everything he done, and bobbing their heads to show they understood, and stooping a little and resting their hands on their thighs to watch him mark the places on the ground with his cane; and then he stood up straight and stiff where Sherburn had stood, frowning and having his hat-brim down over his eyes, and sung out, “Boggs!” and then fetched his cane down slow to a level, and says “Bang!” staggered backwards, says “Bang!” again, and fell down flat on his back. The people that had seen the thing said he done it perfect; said it was just exactly the way it all happened. Then as much as a dozen people got out their bottles and treated him.
Well, by-and-by somebody said Sherburn ought to be lynched. In about a minute everybody was saying it; so away they went, mad and yelling, and snatching down every clothes-line they come to, to do the hanging with.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: They took Boggs to a little drug store, the crowd pressing around just the same, and the whole town following, and I rushed and got a good place at the window, where I was close to him and could see in. The druggist was a fat, red-faced man with a long white beard, and he looked like he was in a hurry. He bustled around, getting out bottles and powders, and the people outside were all talking at once, trying to find out what was the matter. Some said it was poison, others said it was a fit, and some said it was just Boggs being Boggs again. But I knew better. I had seen him drunk before, and I knew what it was. He was just drunk again, and the town had made a big fuss about it. The druggist gave him a glass of something that looked like water, and Boggs drank it down, and then he laid back on the counter and went to sleep. The crowd began to thin out, and the people went away, talking about how Boggs had been a fool again, and how he had made a fool of himself in front of the whole town. I stayed there a little while longer, watching him, and then I went home. I didn't feel like going to bed, so I went out and sat on the steps and thought about things. I thought about how Boggs had been a fool, and how the town had made a big deal out of it, and how they all thought they were so smart. But I didn't think they were smart at all. I thought they were just like Boggs, only they didn't know it. I thought about how people always make a big fuss about little things, and how they never seem to learn. I thought about how I was going to get away from all of this, and how I was going to find a better place, where people weren't so mean and so full of themselves. I thought about how I was going to be free, and how I was going to find a way to be happy. And I thought about how I was going to do it all by myself, without any help from anyone else. That's how I felt that night, and that's how I still feel now. I don't care what the town thinks, or what anyone else thinks. I know what I want, and I'm going to get it, no matter what it takes.

events.title: The Mob's Fury and Sherburn's Calm Defiance
detailed_summary: A large, aggressive crowd, compared to 'Injuns', moved tumultuously towards Sherburn's home, creating widespread panic.
Children fled screaming, women watched fearfully from windows, and Black individuals observed from trees and fences, all retreating as the mob neared.
The mob densely packed themselves in front of Sherburn's fence, their noise overwhelming.
Amid shouts to demolish it, the fence was torn down, and the crowd started to surge into Sherburn's yard like a wave.
At that moment, Sherburn calmly appeared on his front porch roof, holding a double-barrel gun, without speaking.
His composed and armed presence instantly quelled the commotion, and the advancing crowd receded.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: They swarmed up towards Sherburn’s house, a-whooping and raging like Injuns, and everything had to clear the way or get run over and tromped to mush, and it was awful to see.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: The racket stopped, and the wave sucked back.

events.text_segment:
They swarmed up towards Sherburn’s house, a-whooping and raging like Injuns, and everything had to clear the way or get run over and tromped to mush, and it was awful to see. Children was heeling it ahead of the mob, screaming and trying to get out of the way; and every window along the road was full of women’s heads, and there was nigger boys in every tree, and bucks and wenches looking over every fence; and as soon as the mob would get nearly to them they would break and skaddle back out of reach. Lots of the women and girls was crying and taking on, scared most to death.
They swarmed up in front of Sherburn’s palings as thick as they could jam together, and you couldn’t hear yourself think for the noise. It was a little twenty-foot yard. Some sung out “Tear down the fence! tear down the fence!” Then there was a racket of ripping and tearing and smashing, and down she goes, and the front wall of the crowd begins to roll in like a wave.
Just then Sherburn steps out on to the roof of his little front porch, with a double-barrel gun in his hand, and takes his stand, perfectly ca’m and deliberate, not saying a word. The racket stopped, and the wave sucked back.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: They swarmed up towards Sherburn’s house, a-whooping and raging like Injuns, and everything had to clear the way or get run over and tromped to mush, and it was awful to see. The children screamed and ran, and the women stood in the windows with their white faces to the storm, and the niggers got behind trees and fences and watched, and then slunk off as the mob came nearer. The crowd packed itself solid in front of Sherburn’s fence, and the noise was enough to make a body’s head swim. They howled for the fence to be torn down, and it was, and then they surged in like a wave. Just then, Sherburn came out on his front porch roof, with a double-barrel gun in his hand, and not a word said. The whole crowd stopped dead, like a stuck engine, and then slowly began to back off, as if they had seen a ghost.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: They swarmed up towards Sherburn’s house, a-whooping and raging like Injuns, and everything had to clear the way or get run over and tromped to mush, and it was awful to see. They had torches and clubs and pistols, and they were wild with the idea that they were going to lynch a man. But when they got to the house, Sherburn came out on the porch, cool and calm, and he looked at them like they were nothing but a pack of scared hounds. He told them they weren’t men, they were just a cowardly mob, and that if they wanted to fight, they’d have to do it one at a time. That shut them up. They slunk away like whipped dogs, and the whole thing was over in a minute. It was strange to see how quickly they lost their courage when they met a man who wasn’t afraid of them. It showed me that a mob is just a lot of people who lose their sense and follow along with what the others are doing, and that it takes one brave man to break the spell and make them see they’re nothing but a pack of fools.

events.title: Sherburn's Scathing Rebuke of the Mob's Cowardice
detailed_summary: Sherburn remained silent, his steady gaze sweeping across the crowd, making individuals uncomfortable and avoid eye contact.
He then gave a scornful laugh before addressing them.
He mocked their presumption to lynch anyone, especially a man, contrasting it with their bravery in tarring and feathering vulnerable women.
Sherburn asserted that a true man would be safe from thousands of their kind in daylight, as long as he wasn't attacked from behind.
He claimed a thorough understanding of their character, based on his experiences in both the South and North, concluding that the average person is a coward.

He elaborated on regional cowardice: Northerners passively endure mistreatment, while Southerners commit acts like stagecoach robberies or form lynch mobs for jury-acquitted murderers due to fear of reprisal.
He chided the mob for not adhering to the 'proper' method of lynching—at night, masked, and led by a 'man'—identifying Buck Harkness as merely 'part of a man' who initiated their current folly.
He accused them of lacking genuine desire for confrontation, stating they joined out of fear of being exposed as cowards if they didn't follow an instigator like Harkness.
He described a mob as pitiful, its courage borrowed from the group and its leaders, and a mob without a true leader as even more contemptible.
He ordered them to leave with their 'half-a-man,' emphasizing that any genuine lynching would be done in the dark, Southern style, with masks and a proper leader, while cocking his gun.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Sherburn never said a word—just stood there, looking down.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Now leave—and take your half-a-man with you”—tossing his gun up across his left arm and cocking it when he says this.

events.text_segment:
Sherburn never said a word—just stood there, looking down. The stillness was awful creepy and uncomfortable. Sherburn run his eye slow along the crowd; and wherever it struck the people tried a little to out-gaze him, but they couldn’t; they dropped their eyes and looked sneaky. Then pretty soon Sherburn sort of laughed; not the pleasant kind, but the kind that makes you feel like when you are eating bread that’s got sand in it.
Then he says, slow and scornful:
“The idea of you lynching anybody! It’s amusing. The idea of you thinking you had pluck enough to lynch a man! Because you’re brave enough to tar and feather poor friendless cast-out women that come along here, did that make you think you had grit enough to lay your hands on a man? Why, a man’s safe in the hands of ten thousand of your kind—as long as it’s daytime and you’re not behind him.
“Do I know you? I know you clear through. I was born and raised in the South, and I’ve lived in the North; so I know the average all around. The average man’s a coward. In the North he lets anybody walk over him that wants to, and goes home and prays for a humble spirit to bear it. In the South one man all by himself, has stopped a stage full of men in the daytime, and robbed the lot. Your newspapers call you a brave people so much that you think you are braver than any other people—whereas you’re just as brave, and no braver. Why don’t your juries hang murderers? Because they’re afraid the man’s friends will shoot them in the back, in the dark—and it’s just what they would do.
“So they always acquit; and then a man goes in the night, with a hundred masked cowards at his back and lynches the rascal. Your mistake is, that you didn’t bring a man with you; that’s one mistake, and the other is that you didn’t come in the dark and fetch your masks. You brought part of a man—Buck Harkness, there—and if you hadn’t had him to start you, you’d a taken it out in blowing.
“You didn’t want to come. The average man don’t like trouble and danger. You don’t like trouble and danger. But if only half a man—like Buck Harkness, there—shouts ‘Lynch him! lynch him!’ you’re afraid to back down—afraid you’ll be found out to be what you are—cowards—and so you raise a yell, and hang yourselves on to that half-a-man’s coat-tail, and come raging up here, swearing what big things you’re going to do. The pitifulest thing out is a mob; that’s what an army is—a mob; they don’t fight with courage that’s born in them, but with courage that’s borrowed from their mass, and from their officers. But a mob without any man at the head of it is beneath pitifulness. Now the thing for you to do is to droop your tails and go home and crawl in a hole. If any real lynching’s going to be done, it will be done in the dark, Southern fashion; and when they come they’ll bring their masks, and fetch a man along. Now leave—and take your half-a-man with you”—tossing his gun up across his left arm and cocking it when he says this.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
Sherburn never said a word—just stood there, looking down. He looked at them one after another, and every time he caught a man’s eye he held it a second or two, and that man’s face would go dead and he would look away. Then he laughed, a long, scornful laugh, and said:

"You think you are going to lynch a man? You ain’t going to lynch nobody. You are just a pack of cowards, and you know it. You are not going to lynch a man, you are going to lynch a boy. You are going to lynch a boy that you don’t even know. You are going to lynch a boy that you have never seen, and you are going to lynch him because you are afraid to let him live."

He went on to say that a man would be safe from a thousand of them in the daylight, if he only kept his back to them. He said he knew their kind, North and South, and that the average man was a coward. He said the Northerner would let a man be insulted and trampled on and not lift a finger to help him, and the Southerner would rob a stagecoach or lynch a man that the jury had acquitted, because he was afraid to let him live. He said the proper way to lynch a man was in the dark, with masks, and led by a man, and that Buck Harkness was only part of a man, and that he had started this foolishness. He said they had come out in the daylight, and that was not the way to do it. He said they had no real desire to lynch a man, and that they had only come out because they were afraid to stay home and be thought cowards. He said a mob was a pitiful thing, and that its courage was borrowed, and that a mob without a leader was worse than nothing. He said they might as well go home with their half-a-man, and that if they wanted to lynch a man, they would do it in the dark, Southern style, with masks and a man to lead them. And he said this while he was cocking his gun.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
Sherburn never said a word—just stood there, looking down. The crowd was silent, too, and the stillness was so thick you could feel it. It was like the whole town had held its breath, waiting for something to break the spell. Then, all of a sudden, the silence cracked like a whip. It was Sherburn who spoke, but not in a loud way. He just said, “You’re a coward, and you know it.”

The words hung in the air, and the men in the crowd shifted uneasily. They had come to lynch Sherburn, to make him pay for the murder of Dr. Robinson, but now they were the ones being judged. The men who had been so sure of themselves, who had marched with torches and threats, now looked uncertain. Some of them turned their eyes to the ground, others to each other, as if searching for someone else to blame.

Sherburn took a step forward, and the crowd parted slightly, not out of fear, but out of confusion. “You think you’re men,” he said, his voice calm but cutting, “but you’re just a pack of animals. You come out here with your fire and your fury, but you don’t have the guts to face me alone. You need the strength of numbers, the cover of the crowd, to feel brave. That’s not courage—that’s cowardice.”

Huck stood in the back, watching the scene unfold. He had never seen a man stand up to a mob like this before. He had seen men run, he had seen men beg, he had even seen men fight, but this was something else. This was a man who had nothing to lose and everything to say.

Sherburn looked around at the faces of the men who had come to kill him. “You think you’re doing the right thing,” he said, “but you’re not. You’re just following the crowd, doing what you think you should do because someone told you to. You don’t even know why you’re here. You just know you want to see blood.”

The crowd murmured, some of them stepping back now, others still holding their ground. But the fire in their eyes had dimmed. They had come to take justice into their own hands, but now they were being forced to look at themselves in the mirror of Sherburn’s words.

Huck felt a strange kind of admiration for the man. He had seen men like Sherburn before—men who had done bad things, but who still had a kind of strength about them. It wasn’t the strength of muscle or money, but the strength of knowing who you were and not being afraid to show it.

Sherburn turned and walked away, not running, not hiding, just walking. The crowd didn’t follow. They just stood there, watching him go, and then slowly, one by one, they turned and walked back to town, their fire still burning, but their purpose gone.

events.title: The Mob Disperses and Huck Attends the Circus
detailed_summary: Following Sherburn's command, the crowd rapidly dispersed in various directions.
Buck Harkness followed them, appearing dejected and diminished.
Huck, although he could have stayed, decided against it.
He proceeded to the circus, waited near the back until the watchman passed, and then discreetly entered under the tent.
Huck reasoned that he needed to conserve his money, given his precarious situation away from home and among strangers, stressing the importance of financial prudence.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The crowd washed back sudden, and then broke all apart, and went tearing off every which way, and Buck Harkness he heeled it after them, looking tolerable cheap.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: I ain’t opposed to spending money on circuses when there ain’t no other way, but there ain’t no use in wasting it on them.

events.text_segment:
The crowd washed back sudden, and then broke all apart, and went tearing off every which way, and Buck Harkness he heeled it after them, looking tolerable cheap. I could a staid if I wanted to, but I didn’t want to.
I went to the circus and loafed around the back side till the watchman went by, and then dived in under the tent. I had my twenty-dollar gold piece and some other money, but I reckoned I better save it, because there ain’t no telling how soon you are going to need it, away from home and amongst strangers that way. You can’t be too careful. I ain’t opposed to spending money on circuses when there ain’t no other way, but there ain’t no use in wasting it on them.

events.title: Huck's Captivation by the Circus Grandeur
detailed_summary: Huck found the circus to be exceptionally entertaining and magnificent.
He was deeply impressed by the grand entrance of approximately twenty performers, men and women riding in pairs.
The male performers were simply clad in undergarments, without shoes or stirrups, riding with ease, while the female performers, adorned in costly, diamond-studded attire, resembled queens.
Huck considered this spectacle incredibly beautiful, unlike anything he had seen before.
The performers then rose to stand on their horses, moving gracefully and fluidly around the ring.
The men appeared tall and ethereal, their heads seeming to glide near the tent's roof, while the women's flowing dresses billowed softly, resembling lovely parasols.
The pace of their performance increased, with all of them dancing on horseback as the horses leaned into the turns, the ring-master directing with his whip and shouts, and the clown making jokes.
Eventually, all performers released their reins; the ladies placed their hands on their hips, and the gentlemen folded their arms, as the horses continued their spirited movements.
One by one, they elegantly leaped off their horses into the ring, made charming bows, and then quickly exited, eliciting wild applause from the audience.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: It was a real bully circus.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: And so one after the other they all skipped off into the ring, and made the sweetest bow I ever see, and then scampered out, and everybody clapped their hands and went just about wild.

events.text_segment:
It was a real bully circus. It was the splendidest sight that ever was when they all come riding in, two and two, a gentleman and lady, side by side, the men just in their drawers and undershirts, and no shoes nor stirrups, and resting their hands on their thighs easy and comfortable—there must a been twenty of them—and every lady with a lovely complexion, and perfectly beautiful, and looking just like a gang of real sure-enough queens, and dressed in clothes that cost millions of dollars, and just littered with diamonds. It was a powerful fine sight; I never see anything so lovely. And then one by one they got up and stood, and went a-weaving around the ring so gentle and wavy and graceful, the men looking ever so tall and airy and straight, with their heads bobbing and skimming along, away up there under the tent-roof, and every lady’s rose-leafy dress flapping soft and silky around her hips, and she looking like the most loveliest parasol.
And then faster and faster they went, all of them dancing, first one foot out in the air and then the other, the horses leaning more and more, and the ring-master going round and round the center-pole, cracking his whip and shouting “Hi!—hi!” and the clown cracking jokes behind him; and by-and-by all hands dropped the reins, and every lady put her knuckles on her hips and every gentleman folded his arms, and then how the horses did lean over and hump themselves! And so one after the other they all skipped off into the ring, and made the sweetest bow I ever see, and then scampered out, and everybody clapped their hands and went just about wild.

The first thing they done was to ride in, about twenty of them, men and women, in couples, and they come in like kings and queens. The men was all in their long johns, and no shoes nor stirrups, and they rode like they was born to it. The women was dressed all in silks and diamonds, and they looked like queens. They made such a fine show, and Huck considered it so beautiful, he couldn't take his eyes off of them. Then they all rose up and stood on their horses, and went around the ring, and the men looked so tall and airy, their heads nearly touching the roof of the tent, and the women's dresses blew out like beautiful parasols. The pace got faster and faster, and they danced on the horses, and the horses leaned into the turns, and the ringmaster cracked his whip and shouted, and the clown made jokes and tumbled and made the people laugh. Then all of a sudden they let go of the reins, and the ladies put their hands on their hips, and the gentlemen folded their arms, and the horses went on like they was trying to run away. Then one by one they jumped off, and made pretty bows, and then they all scampered out, and the people went wild with applause.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: It was a real bully circus. There was a man dressed up like a bear, and he would act like he was going to bite people, but he never really did. There was a woman who painted her face and pretended to be a witch, and she would fly around on a broomstick. The kids loved it, and the grown-ups laughed and clapped. There was music playing all the time, and people shouting and cheering. I had never seen anything like it before, and I was having a pretty good time. But then something happened that made me feel kind of sick to my stomach. I saw a man tied up and made to act like a monkey. He didn't look like he wanted to be there, and he looked real scared. The people laughed at him, but I didn't think it was funny. I felt sorry for him, and I didn't want to watch no more. I told Huck about it, and he said it was just part of the show. But I didn't like it, and I didn't want to be a part of it no more. So I left the circus and went back to the river, where it felt like the world was still real and honest. I didn't know it then, but that was the last time I would ever go to a circus again.

events.title: The Astonishing Ruse of the 'Drunk' Circus Rider
detailed_summary: Throughout the circus, the performers executed remarkable acts, and the clown's incessant humor kept the audience highly amused.
Huck was particularly impressed by the clown's ability to deliver quick, witty, and perfectly timed jokes, wondering how he could think of so many.
A man appearing to be drunk attempted to enter the ring, claiming he wanted to ride and could do so expertly.
Despite arguments and efforts to keep him out, he persisted, causing the entire show to pause.
The audience began to mock the man, which angered him, leading him to become disruptive and agitate the crowd further, with some men preparing to intervene.
The ring-master then made a speech, hoping to avoid disturbance, and agreed to let the man ride if he promised to behave, an offer the audience found amusingly acceptable.

As soon as the man was on the horse, it began to buck violently, with circus hands struggling to control it, while the 'drunk' man clung on, his legs flailing, to the immense amusement of the standing, laughing crowd.
Huck, however, felt a sense of unease and fear for the man's safety.
The horse eventually broke free, galloping wildly around the ring with the man precariously attached.
Then, to everyone's surprise, the 'drunk' man skillfully regained his balance, stood up on the moving horse, and began removing layers of clothing.
He shed a total of seventeen outfits, revealing himself to be a slim, handsome performer in a dazzling costume.
He then expertly controlled the horse, performed impressively, made a bow, and danced off to the dressing room, leaving the audience howling with pleasure and astonishment.
The ring-master realized he had been tricked by one of his own performers who had orchestrated the entire prank, making him look foolish.
Huck felt a bit sheepish for being deceived but was ultimately highly impressed by the circus, deeming it excellent and worthy of his future patronage.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Well, all through the circus they done the most astonishing things; and all the time that clown carried on so it most killed the people.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Then the ring-master he see how he had been fooled, and he was the sickest ring-master you ever see, I reckon. Why, it was one of his own men! He had got up that joke all out of his own head, and never let on to nobody. Well, I felt sheepish enough to be took in so, but I wouldn’t a been in that ring-master’s place, not for a thousand dollars. I don’t know; there may be bullier circuses than what that one was, but I never struck them yet. Anyways, it was plenty good enough for me; and wherever I run across it, it can have all of my custom every time.

events.text_segment:
Well, all through the circus they done the most astonishing things; and all the time that clown carried on so it most killed the people. The ring-master couldn’t ever say a word to him but he was back at him quick as a wink with the funniest things a body ever said; and how he ever could think of so many of them, and so sudden and so pat, was what I couldn’t noway understand. Why, I couldn’t a thought of them in a year. And by-and-by a drunk man tried to get into the ring—said he wanted to ride; said he could ride as well as anybody that ever was. They argued and tried to keep him out, but he wouldn’t listen, and the whole show come to a standstill. Then the people begun to holler at him and make fun of him, and that made him mad, and he begun to rip and tear; so that stirred up the people, and a lot of men begun to pile down off of the benches and swarm towards the ring, saying, “Knock him down! throw him out!” and one or two women begun to scream. So, then, the ring-master he made a little speech, and said he hoped there wouldn’t be no disturbance, and if the man would promise he wouldn’t make no more trouble he would let him ride if he thought he could stay on the horse. So everybody laughed and said all right, and the man got on. The minute he was on, the horse begun to rip and tear and jump and cavort around, with two circus men hanging on to his bridle trying to hold him, and the drunk man hanging on to his neck, and his heels flying in the air every jump, and the whole crowd of people standing up shouting and laughing till tears rolled down. And at last, sure enough, all the circus men could do, the horse broke loose, and away he went like the very nation, round and round the ring, with that sot laying down on him and hanging to his neck, with first one leg hanging most to the ground on one side, and then t’other one on t’other side, and the people just crazy. It warn’t funny to me, though; I was all of a tremble to see his danger. But pretty soon he struggled up astraddle and grabbed the bridle, a-reeling this way and that; and the next minute he sprung up and dropped the bridle and stood! and the horse a-going like a house afire too. He just stood up there, a-sailing around as easy and comfortable as if he warn’t ever drunk in his life—and then he begun to pull off his clothes and sling them. He shed them so thick they kind of clogged up the air, and altogether he shed seventeen suits. And, then, there he was, slim and handsome, and dressed the gaudiest and prettiest you ever saw, and he lit into that horse with his whip and made him fairly hum—and finally skipped off, and made his bow and danced off to the dressing-room, and everybody just a-howling with pleasure and astonishment.
Then the ring-master he see how he had been fooled, and he was the sickest ring-master you ever see, I reckon. Why, it was one of his own men! He had got up that joke all out of his own head, and never let on to nobody. Well, I felt sheepish enough to be took in so, but I wouldn’t a been in that ring-master’s place, not for a thousand dollars. I don’t know; there may be bullier circuses than what that one was, but I never struck them yet. Anyways, it was plenty good enough for me; and wherever I run across it, it can have all of my custom every time.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
Well, all through the circus they done the most astonishing things; and all the time that clown carried on so it most killed the people. He was always a step ahead, with a new joke every minute, and he never missed a beat. It was like he had a thousand jokes in his head and could pick out the right one just when it was needed. I never saw such a performer before, and I don’t believe I ever will again. He made the whole crowd laugh so hard they had to hold on to each other to keep from falling down.

Just as the show was getting to the end of one of the acts, a man came staggering into the ring, looking like he was half-drunk. He said he wanted to ride, and that he could do it better than any of them. The circus men tried to stop him, but he kept coming, and before long, the whole show had to stop. The people began to laugh and jeer at him, and that made him mad. He started to get rough and pushy, and some of the men in the crowd looked like they were going to step in and take him by the collar.

Then the ring-master stepped up and made a speech, trying to keep things from getting out of hand. He said, if the man really wanted to ride, he could have his chance, but he had to promise to behave. The man agreed, and the crowd roared with laughter, thinking it was a joke. But it wasn’t a joke. The man was let into the ring, and they brought out a horse.

As soon as he got on, the horse began to buck like it was trying to throw him off. The circus men tried to hold it, but it was no use. The man was hanging on for dear life, his legs flying in the air, and the people were howling with delight. I felt kind of sorry for him, I must say, but I couldn’t help laughing too.

All of a sudden, the horse broke loose and started to run around the ring like it was going to circle the world. The man was still on it, but he looked like he was going to be thrown any minute. But then something strange happened. He got his balance, stood up on the horse, and began to take off his clothes. One by one, he peeled off seventeen layers, and under it all, he was a slim, handsome fellow in a fine suit of clothes that sparkled like a thousand stars.

Then he took hold of the horse and made it do all sorts of tricks, and the people were wild with excitement. He bowed and danced off to the dressing room, and the crowd was howling with pleasure. The ring-master looked like a fool, and I reckon he knew it. He had been tricked by one of his own men, who had dressed up like a drunk and played the whole thing out just for fun.

I felt kind of silly for being taken in, but I had to admit it was the best show I ever saw. I said to myself, if this is what a circus is like, I’ll be back to see more of it some day.
