LLM_completions.prefix-probing: So, thinks I, I’ll go and search them rooms. I went in and looked around. The house was all still and quiet. I went up to the first room and looked in. There was a bed, and on the bed was a man, and he was dead. I didn’t know him, but I reckoned he was one of the robbers. I went on to the next room and found another man, and he was dead too. I went through the whole house and found four men, all dead. I didn’t know what to make of it. I thought maybe they had been killed by the people they had robbed, but I didn’t see any signs of a fight. They just lay there, dead, like they had been shot in their sleep. I was scared, but I didn’t run. I stayed there and looked around some more. I found a lot of things that belonged to the people they had robbed. There was a trunk full of clothes, and a box full of money. I took the money and put it in my pocket. I didn’t feel right about it, but I thought maybe I could use it to get out of the country. I was afraid the robbers might come back, so I left the house and went down to the river. I got in the canoe and started to float down the river. I was thinking about what I had done, and I felt bad. I had always been brought up to do right, and I knew that taking the money was wrong. But I didn’t know what else to do. I was in a tight place, and I didn’t see no way out. I thought about Jim, and I wondered if he was still on the island. I had left him there to go and see about the house, and I hoped he hadn’t gone off by himself. I was afraid he might get into trouble if he went off alone. I was thinking about all this when I heard a noise behind me. I turned around and saw a man standing on the bank. He was holding a gun, and he looked like he was going to shoot me. I dropped the oar and started to row as fast as I could. I didn’t know who the man was, but I didn’t want to find out. I rowed until I was out of sight, and then I stopped and looked back. The man was gone. I didn’t know what to make of it. I thought maybe it was one of the robbers who had come back, but I didn’t see any sign of them. I was scared, but I didn’t run. I stayed there and thought about what I had done. I had taken the money, and I had left Jim alone. I didn’t know what to do. I was in a tight place, and I didn’t see no way out. I thought about going back to the house and giving the money back, but I didn’t know if the robbers were still there. I was afraid they might kill me if I went back. I thought about going to the town and turning myself in, but I didn’t know if they would believe me. I was a runaway, and I didn’t have no friends there. I was thinking about all this when I heard a voice behind me. I turned around and saw Jim standing there. He had come down the river in the raft. I was glad to see him, but I was also scared. I didn’t know what he would think about what I had done. I told him about the house and the dead men and the money. He listened to me, and then he said, “Well, Huck, I reckon you done right. We can use the money to get out of the country. We can go to a free state and start over.” I didn’t know what to say. I had always been brought up to do right, and I knew that taking the money was wrong. But Jim was my friend, and I didn’t want to disappoint him. I said, “I reckon you’re right, Jim. We can use the money to get out of the country.” So we went on down the river, and we didn’t talk about it no more. But I still felt bad about what I had done. I didn’t know if I was doing right or wrong, but I knew that I was in a tight place, and I didn’t see no way out. I just kept on going, and I hoped that things would get better.

events.title: The Gold is Re-hidden and Immediately Stolen by Huck
detailed_summary: As the King and Duke prepare to go back downstairs, the Duke voices his opinion that they haven't hidden the money in a secure location.
This comment encourages Huck, who had been hoping for a clue to the money's whereabouts.

The Duke elaborates on his concern: Mary Jane will be in mourning, and the servant who tends to the rooms might be instructed to pack away Mary Jane's dresses and could stumble upon the money if it's among them, potentially 'borrowing' some.
The King concedes the Duke's point and approaches the curtain where Huck is concealed, fumbling nearby.
Huck remains pressed against the wall, motionless despite his trepidation, briefly contemplating his options if discovered.
Before Huck can fully form a plan, the King retrieves the bag of gold without suspecting Huck's presence.

The conmen then tear a hole in the straw tick mattress beneath the feather bed, stuff the bag of gold deep inside the straw, and declare it safe, reasoning that servants only make up the feather bed and rarely disturb the straw tick.
However, Huck, having witnessed their actions, knows better.
He seizes the opportunity and removes the money from the straw tick before the King and Duke are even halfway down the stairs.

He quickly takes the gold to his own cubby and hides it there temporarily, planning to find a more secure hiding spot outside the house later to prevent its discovery should the conmen realize it's missing and search the premises.
Still fully clothed and too agitated by the night's events to sleep, Huck waits tensely.
He hears the King and Duke return and go to their rooms; he positions himself at the top of his ladder to observe, but nothing further happens.
Huck waits patiently until the house is completely quiet, between the cessation of late-night sounds and the onset of early morning ones, before finally slipping down his ladder.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: So they got ready to go down stairs again.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: So I held on till all the late sounds had quit and the early ones hadn’t begun yet; and then I slipped down the ladder.

events.text_segment:
So they got ready to go down stairs again. The duke says:
“I don’t think we put that money in a good place.”
That cheered me up. I’d begun to think I warn’t going to get a hint of no kind to help me. The king says:
“Why?”
“Because Mary Jane ’ll be in mourning from this out; and first you know the nigger that does up the rooms will get an order to box these duds up and put ’em away; and do you reckon a nigger can run across money and not borrow some of it?”
“Your head’s level agin, duke,” says the king; and he comes a-fumbling under the curtain two or three foot from where I was. I stuck tight to the wall and kept mighty still, though quivery; and I wondered what them fellows would say to me if they catched me; and I tried to think what I’d better do if they did catch me. But the king he got the bag before I could think more than about a half a thought, and he never suspicioned I was around. They took and shoved the bag through a rip in the straw tick that was under the feather-bed, and crammed it in a foot or two amongst the straw and said it was all right now, because a nigger only makes up the feather-bed, and don’t turn over the straw tick only about twice a year, and so it warn’t in no danger of getting stole now.
But I knowed better. I had it out of there before they was half-way down stairs. I groped along up to my cubby, and hid it there till I could get a chance to do better. I judged I better hide it outside of the house somewheres, because if they missed it they would give the house a good ransacking: I knowed that very well. Then I turned in, with my clothes all on; but I couldn’t a gone to sleep if I’d a wanted to, I was in such a sweat to get through with the business. By-and-by I heard the king and the duke come up; so I rolled off my pallet and laid with my chin at the top of my ladder, and waited to see if anything was going to happen. But nothing did.
So I held on till all the late sounds had quit and the early ones hadn’t begun yet; and then I slipped down the ladder.

events.title: Huck Hides the Money in the Coffin
detailed_summary: The narrator, Huck, stealthily navigates the house at night, finding the men watching Peter Wilks's corpse asleep.
He observes the corpse in the parlor.
Upon hearing someone, later identified as Mary Jane, descending the stairs, Huck quickly decides to hide the bag of money inside Peter Wilks's coffin.
He places the bag under the coffin lid, near the deceased's cold hands.
Mary Jane enters the parlor, kneels by the coffin, and begins to cry.
Huck manages to slip out of the room unnoticed, confirming the watchers in the dining room remain asleep.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: I crept to their doors and listened; they was snoring.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: They hadn’t stirred.

events.text_segment:
I crept to their doors and listened; they was snoring. So I tiptoed along, and got down stairs all right. There warn’t a sound anywheres. I peeped through a crack of the dining-room door, and see the men that was watching the corpse all sound asleep on their chairs. The door was open into the parlor, where the corpse was laying, and there was a candle in both rooms. I passed along, and the parlor door was open; but I see there warn’t nobody in there but the remainders of Peter; so I shoved on by; but the front door was locked, and the key wasn’t there. Just then I heard somebody coming down the stairs, back behind me. I run in the parlor and took a swift look around, and the only place I see to hide the bag was in the coffin. The lid was shoved along about a foot, showing the dead man’s face down in there, with a wet cloth over it, and his shroud on. I tucked the money-bag in under the lid, just down beyond where his hands was crossed, which made me creep, they was so cold, and then I run back across the room and in behind the door.
The person coming was Mary Jane. She went to the coffin, very soft, and kneeled down and looked in; then she put up her handkerchief, and I see she begun to cry, though I couldn’t hear her, and her back was to me. I slid out, and as I passed the dining-room I thought I’d make sure them watchers hadn’t seen me; so I looked through the crack, and everything was all right. They hadn’t stirred.

events.title: Huck's Midnight Regret and Dilemma
detailed_summary: Huck feels disheartened about how his plan to secure the money has turned out, despite his efforts and risks.
He considers the possibility of writing to Mary Jane later to retrieve the money, but dismisses it as unlikely to succeed.
He anticipates the money will be discovered when the coffin lid is screwed on, leading to the King regaining possession of it.
Huck acknowledges his desire to retrieve the money from the coffin but recognizes the increasing risk of being caught as morning approaches and the watchers might awaken.
He resolves not to attempt it, fearing being implicated in the theft of the six thousand dollars.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: I slipped up to bed, feeling ruther blue, on accounts of the thing playing out that way after I had took so much trouble and run so much resk about it.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: I don’t wish to be mixed up in no such business as that, I says to myself.

events.text_segment: I slipped up to bed, feeling ruther blue, on accounts of the thing playing out that way after I had took so much trouble and run so much resk about it. Says I, if it could stay where it is, all right; because when we get down the river a hundred mile or two I could write back to Mary Jane, and she could dig him up again and get it; but that ain’t the thing that’s going to happen; the thing that’s going to happen is, the money ’ll be found when they come to screw on the lid. Then the king ’ll get it again, and it ’ll be a long day before he gives anybody another chance to smouch it from him. Of course I wanted to slide down and get it out of there, but I dasn’t try it. Every minute it was getting earlier now, and pretty soon some of them watchers would begin to stir, and I might get catched—catched with six thousand dollars in my hands that nobody hadn’t hired me to take care of. I don’t wish to be mixed up in no such business as that, I says to myself.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: I slipped up to bed, feeling ruther blue, on accounts of the thing playing out that way after I had took so much trouble and run so much resk about it. I reckoned I had lost the money clean, and that the King had it now, and that there warn't no help for it. But I was uneasy, and couldn't rest. I kept thinking about that money, and how it was just under my hand, and how I might get it if I was willing to take the resk. But I reckoned I couldn't do it, because it warn't safe. The men would be on watch, and if they caught me, I would be in a bad fix. I thought about writing to Mary Jane and telling her to come and get the money, but I reckoned she wouldn't come, and if she did, the King would find out about it, and then I would be in trouble. I thought about it all night, and in the morning I made up my mind I wouldn't try for it. I reckoned I had done enough already, and that I had better let it alone.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: I slipped up to bed, feeling ruther blue, on accounts of the thing playing out that way after I had took so much trouble and run so much resk about it. I was feeling so lonesome and down in the mouth that I didn't feel like sleeping, but I was dog-tired and my eyes wouldn't stay open. I kept thinking about how I had worked so hard to get Jim out of that place, and now it all seemed to be for nothing. I thought about how Jim had trusted me and how I had promised to help him, and I felt awful for letting him down. I kept turning over in my mind whether I had done the right thing or not, and I couldn't make up my mind. I was scared that Jim would find out and be mad at me, and I was scared of what might happen if he did. I was scared of the consequences, but I was more scared of my own conscience. I had never felt so bad in my life, and I didn't know what to do about it. I just kept thinking and thinking until I finally dropped off to sleep, still feeling blue and troubled.

events.title: The Funeral Service and the Undertaker's Efficiency
detailed_summary: In the morning, Huck observes the family and the con men, trying to discern if anything unusual has occurred, but finds no clues.
The undertaker arrives and prepares the house for the funeral service, arranging chairs.
Huck notices the coffin lid is undisturbed but dares not check for the money with people around.
Mourners arrive and file past the coffin, with the Wilks girls (referred to as 'beats' and 'girls' by Huck) showing their grief.
The undertaker is described as exceptionally stealthy and efficient, managing the crowd and arrangements silently with nods and gestures.
A poorly performing melodeon is played, and a hymn is sung, which Huck finds unimpressive.
Reverend Hobson begins his sermon, but it's abruptly interrupted by a loud commotion caused by a dog in the cellar.
The undertaker calmly and discreetly slips away to the cellar.
A thwack is heard, followed by silence, and the dog's barking ceases.
The undertaker reappears and whispers to the preacher that the dog had caught a rat, much to the satisfaction and curiosity of the attendees.
This incident elevates the undertaker's reputation among the townspeople.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: When I got down stairs in the morning the parlor was shut up, and the watchers was gone.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: There warn’t no more popular man in town than what that undertaker was.

events.text_segment:
When I got down stairs in the morning the parlor was shut up, and the watchers was gone. There warn’t nobody around but the family and the widow Bartley and our tribe. I watched their faces to see if anything had been happening, but I couldn’t tell.
Towards the middle of the day the undertaker come with his man, and they set the coffin in the middle of the room on a couple of chairs, and then set all our chairs in rows, and borrowed more from the neighbors till the hall and the parlor and the dining-room was full. I see the coffin lid was the way it was before, but I dasn’t go to look in under it, with folks around.
Then the people begun to flock in, and the beats and the girls took seats in the front row at the head of the coffin, and for a half an hour the people filed around slow, in single rank, and looked down at the dead man’s face a minute, and some dropped in a tear, and it was all very still and solemn, only the girls and the beats holding handkerchiefs to their eyes and keeping their heads bent, and sobbing a little. There warn’t no other sound but the scraping of the feet on the floor and blowing noses—because people always blows them more at a funeral than they do at other places except church.
When the place was packed full the undertaker he slid around in his black gloves with his softy soothering ways, putting on the last touches, and getting people and things all ship-shape and comfortable, and making no more sound than a cat. He never spoke; he moved people around, he squeezed in late ones, he opened up passageways, and done it with nods, and signs with his hands. Then he took his place over against the wall. He was the softest, glidingest, stealthiest man I ever see; and there warn’t no more smile to him than there is to a ham.
They had borrowed a melodeum—a sick one; and when everything was ready a young woman set down and worked it, and it was pretty skreeky and colicky, and everybody joined in and sung, and Peter was the only one that had a good thing, according to my notion. Then the Reverend Hobson opened up, slow and solemn, and begun to talk; and straight off the most outrageous row busted out in the cellar a body ever heard; it was only one dog, but he made a most powerful racket, and he kept it up right along; the parson he had to stand there, over the coffin, and wait—you couldn’t hear yourself think. It was right down awkward, and nobody didn’t seem to know what to do. But pretty soon they see that long-legged undertaker make a sign to the preacher as much as to say, “Don’t you worry—just depend on me.” Then he stooped down and begun to glide along the wall, just his shoulders showing over the people’s heads. So he glided along, and the powwow and racket getting more and more outrageous all the time; and at last, when he had gone around two sides of the room, he disappears down cellar. Then in about two seconds we heard a whack, and the dog he finished up with a most amazing howl or two, and then everything was dead still, and the parson begun his solemn talk where he left off. In a minute or two here comes this undertaker’s back and shoulders gliding along the wall again; and so he glided and glided around three sides of the room, and then rose up, and shaded his mouth with his hands, and stretched his neck out towards the preacher, over the people’s heads, and says, in a kind of a coarse whisper, “He had a rat!” Then he drooped down and glided along the wall again to his place. You could see it was a great satisfaction to the people, because naturally they wanted to know. A little thing like that don’t cost nothing, and it’s just the little things that makes a man to be looked up to and liked. There warn’t no more popular man in town than what that undertaker was.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: When I got down stairs in the morning the parlor was shut up, and the watchers was gone. The house was all still and quiet, and I couldn't see no sign of anything being wrong. The King and the Duke was gone too, and the girls was dressed and looking fresh and clean, and there warn't no sign of no trouble. But I had a feeling that something was up, though I couldn't tell what. The undertaker come in about ten o'clock, and he begun to fix up the house for the funeral. He was a man that could do things without making no noise, and he went to work with a kind of quiet, steady way that made me feel like he was used to doing this sort of thing every day. He set out the chairs in rows, and he put the coffin in the middle of the room, and he looked around and nodded to himself like he was satisfied. I noticed the lid of the coffin warn't none the worse for wear, and I felt a little uneasy, but I didn't dare to go and look under it with all them folks around. The mourners begun to come in, and they filed past the coffin and bowed their heads and looked solemn. The Wilks girls, they called them 'beats' and 'girls' in the town, they cried and wailed and made a mighty show of grief, and it made me feel kind of sick to see it. The undertaker, he moved around among the people like a shadow, and he didn't say no more than a few words to nobody, but he managed everything just the same. There was a man playing a melodeon, but it warn't no good, and the tune was all out of key, and the people just stood there and looked at each other. Then they begun to sing a hymn, but it warn't no use, because the instrument was so bad it made the tune sound like a cat howlin'. The Reverend Hobson got up to preach, and he begun to talk about the departed and the glory of the hereafter, and he was just getting into his stride when all of a sudden there was a great commotion in the cellar. A dog started to bark and howl like he was crazy, and the whole room jumped. The undertaker, he didn't even flinch. He just slipped out of the room like a ghost and went down into the cellar. There was a thwack, and then it was all quiet again. The dog stopped barking, and the undertaker come back up the stairs and whispered something to the preacher. The preacher nodded, and he went on with his sermon like nothing had happened. But the people was all curious, and they was whispering among themselves, and the undertaker's reputation was made from that day on. He was looked upon as a man that could handle anything, and they said he had a way with dogs and rats and everything else that might get in the way of a proper funeral.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: When I got down stairs in the morning the parlor was shut up, and the watchers was gone. I went to the door and looked in. The candles was all snuffed out, and the room was still and lonesome. The corpse was gone. I felt kind of strange, like I didn't know what to think. I went out in the kitchen, and there was a man there, a stranger, and he was talking to Mary and Judith. They looked kind of uneasy, and I could see they was trying to keep their faces still and not show what they felt. I didn't like the looks of it. I went out in the yard and lit on a log and set down. I was trying to think what it all meant. I had heard of people being stolen before, but I never thought it would happen to a corpse. But I reckoned it was something like that. Maybe they wanted to bury him in another place, or maybe they had some other reason. I didn't know. I just set there and thought about it. I had heard of grave robbers, too, and I reckoned maybe that was what they was. But I didn't like to say nothing, because I didn't want to get mixed up in it. I had seen enough trouble in my time, and I didn't want any more. I was just getting ready to go on back to the house when I heard a noise. It was the stranger coming out of the house. He looked around, and then he come towards me. I got up and walked off a little ways, but he followed me. He said, “You’re the nigger that belongs to this house, ain’t you?” I said, “Yes, sir.” He said, “You seen the corpse?” I said, “Yes, sir.” He said, “Where is it now?” I said, “Gone.” He looked kind of mad, and he said, “You don’t know nothing, do you?” I said, “No, sir.” He said, “Well, you better find out. That corpse is valuable, and if it ain’t found, there’s going to be trouble.” I said, “I don’t know nothing about it, sir.” He said, “You better not say nothing about it, either. If you do, you’ll be sorry.” He turned and went back to the house. I stood there a minute, and then I went back to the house. I went in the kitchen, and Mary and Judith was there. I said, “What’s all this about the corpse?” They looked at me kind of scared, and Mary said, “You don’t know, Huck?” I said, “No, I don’t. What is it?” Judith said, “It’s about our father. He was a slave owner, and he had a lot of money. He had a lot of slaves, too. And he had a lot of enemies. Some people think he was killed, and they want to get his money. They think the corpse is the key to it.” I said, “But he was sick, wasn’t he?” Judith said, “Yes, but some people don’t believe it. They think he was poisoned.” I said, “Well, if he was poisoned, who done it?” Mary said, “We don’t know. But we think it was one of the slaves. That’s why we had the watchers. We was trying to find out who it was.” I said, “But the corpse is gone now.” Judith said, “Yes, and that’s what we’re afraid of. If they take it, they can make people believe he was alive and well, and then they can take his money.” I said, “Well, I don’t know nothing about it. I just want to be left alone.” Mary said, “You better be careful, Huck. If you get mixed up in this, you might get hurt.” I said, “I don’t want to get mixed up in it. I just want to go on my way.” I went out in the yard again and set down on the log. I was trying to think what to do. I had heard of people being killed for less than this. I didn’t want to get mixed up in it. I had seen enough trouble in my time, and I didn’t want any more. I was just getting ready to go on back to the house when I heard a noise. It was the stranger again. He was talking to Mary and Judith. I couldn’t hear what he was saying, but I could see he was mad. I didn’t like the looks of it. I went back to the house and went to my room. I was trying to think what to do. I had heard of people being killed for less than this. I didn’t want to get mixed up in it. I had seen enough trouble in my time, and I didn’t want any more. I was just getting ready to go to bed when I heard a noise. It was the stranger again. He was coming towards my room. I got up and went to the window. I looked out, and there was a canoe in the river. I thought maybe I could get away in it. I went to the door and listened. events.title: Coffin Sealed and Huck's Renewed Anxiety
detailed_summary: The funeral sermon is lengthy, followed by some typical insincere pronouncements from the King.
Huck becomes anxious as the undertaker approaches the coffin with a screwdriver.
The undertaker seals the coffin lid without incident, leaving Huck uncertain whether the money is still inside or if someone else has taken it.
Huck contemplates the predicament: if he writes to Mary Jane and the money isn't there, she'll think poorly of him.
He concludes it's best to remain silent and not contact Mary Jane, feeling he has only made the situation worse with his attempts to help.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Well, the funeral sermon was very good, but pison long and tiresome; and then the king he shoved in and got off some of his usual rubbage, and at last the job was through, and the undertaker begun to sneak up on the coffin with his screw-driver.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Blame it, I says, I might get hunted up and jailed; I’d better lay low and keep dark, and not write at all; the thing’s awful mixed now; trying to better it, I’ve worsened it a hundred times, and I wish to goodness I’d just let it alone, dad fetch the whole business!

events.text_segment: Well, the funeral sermon was very good, but pison long and tiresome; and then the king he shoved in and got off some of his usual rubbage, and at last the job was through, and the undertaker begun to sneak up on the coffin with his screw-driver. I was in a sweat then, and watched him pretty keen. But he never meddled at all; just slid the lid along as soft as mush, and screwed it down tight and fast. So there I was! I didn’t know whether the money was in there or not. So, says I, s’pose somebody has hogged that bag on the sly?—now how do I know whether to write to Mary Jane or not? S’pose she dug him up and didn’t find nothing, what would she think of me? Blame it, I says, I might get hunted up and jailed; I’d better lay low and keep dark, and not write at all; the thing’s awful mixed now; trying to better it, I’ve worsened it a hundred times, and I wish to goodness I’d just let it alone, dad fetch the whole business!

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: Well, the funeral sermon was very good, but pison long and tiresome; and then the king he shoved in and got off some of his usual rubbage, and at last the job was through, and the undertaker begun to sneak up on the coffin with his screw-driver. I was uneasy, but I didn't know what to do. The undertaker he worked away, and I was afeared every minute he was going to give the game away. But he didn't. He just went on and did the job, and when he was done, the lid was as tight as a drum. I didn't know whether the money was still in there or not. I reckoned maybe the king had took it out, or maybe the undertaker had, or maybe it was still in there. I didn't know what to make of it. I thought if I was to write to Mary Jane and say the money was there, and it wasn't, she'd think I was a liar and a scoundrel, and I'd be in trouble. And if I said it wasn't there, and it was, then I'd be in trouble too. So I reckoned the best thing was to say nothing at all, and let it go at that. I felt like I had made a mess of things, and I didn't know how to fix it.

events.title: The King's Deceptive Plans for the Estate and the Girls
detailed_summary: After Peter Wilks's burial, Huck continues to scrutinize faces for any sign of the money's discovery, but learns nothing.
The King charmingly interacts with everyone, announcing his supposed need to quickly settle the estate and return to his congregation in England.
He proposes taking the Wilks girls with him and his companion, William (the Duke in disguise), to live among their English relatives.
This news delights everyone, especially the girls, who are so pleased they forget their recent sorrow and readily agree to a swift sale of the property.
Huck feels a deep sense of pity for the girls, knowing they are being deceived, but sees no way to intervene without endangering himself.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: They buried him, and we come back home, and I went to watching faces again—I couldn’t help it, and I couldn’t rest easy.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Them poor things was that glad and happy it made my heart ache to see them getting fooled and lied to so, but I didn’t see no safe way for me to chip in and change the general tune.

events.text_segment:
They buried him, and we come back home, and I went to watching faces again—I couldn’t help it, and I couldn’t rest easy. But nothing come of it; the faces didn’t tell me nothing.
The king he visited around in the evening, and sweetened everybody up, and made himself ever so friendly; and he give out the idea that his congregation over in England would be in a sweat about him, so he must hurry and settle up the estate right away and leave for home. He was very sorry he was so pushed, and so was everybody; they wished he could stay longer, but they said they could see it couldn’t be done. And he said of course him and William would take the girls home with them; and that pleased everybody too, because then the girls would be well fixed and amongst their own relations; and it pleased the girls, too—tickled them so they clean forgot they ever had a trouble in the world; and told him to sell out as quick as he wanted to, they would be ready. Them poor things was that glad and happy it made my heart ache to see them getting fooled and lied to so, but I didn’t see no safe way for me to chip in and change the general tune.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: They buried him, and we come back home, and I went to watching faces again—I couldn’t help it, and I couldn’t rest easy. I kept my eyes peeled for any sign of the money being found, but I couldn’t find nothin’. The King was a smooth one, and he went around town like he owned it, telling folks how he had to get the estate settled quick and get back to his congregation in England. He said he was going to take the Wilks girls with him and his partner, William, and go live with their English relations. That news went down like a dream, and the girls were so glad they forgot all about their troubles and were ready to sell the place right off. It made me feel awful for them, knowing they was being had, but I couldn’t see no way to help them without getting myself in trouble.

I kept thinking about what had happened, and it made me feel all hollow inside. I didn’t want to be thinking about it, but I couldn’t help myself. I kept wondering if I had done the right thing, and if I had gone too far. I had always heard that killing a man was a bad thing, and I had done it. I didn’t feel proud of it, and I didn’t feel like a hero. I just felt like a fool. I tried to tell myself that it was necessary, that it was for the best, but I couldn’t believe it. I kept thinking about how he had looked at me, and how I had shot him. I couldn’t get it out of my head. I felt like I was going crazy, and I didn’t know what to do. I thought about running away, but I didn’t know where I could go. I didn’t want to be caught, and I didn’t want to be found. I just wanted to be alone, and I wanted to forget. But I couldn’t forget, and I couldn’t run away from what I had done. I had to live with it, and I had to live with the guilt. I didn’t know how long it would take, but I knew it would be a long time before I could feel like myself again.

events.title: The Heartbreaking Sale and Separation of the Enslaved Family
characters: enslaved people (two sons and their mother)
detailed_summary: The King promptly arranges for the auction of the Wilks estate, including the house and the enslaved people, just two days after the funeral.
The day after the funeral, slave traders arrive, and the King sells the enslaved family—two sons are sent upriver to Memphis, and their mother downriver to New Orleans.
The separation causes immense grief for both the Wilks girls and the enslaved family, who cry and lament their parting.
The girls express their shock, never having imagined the enslaved family would be sold or separated.
Huck is profoundly moved by the scene, stating he could hardly bear it if he didn't know the sale was fraudulent and the enslaved individuals would likely be back in a short time.
The townspeople are also stirred by this event, with many openly condemning the separation of the mother and her children as scandalous.
This public outcry damages the reputation of the King and Duke, making the Duke particularly anxious, though the King stubbornly proceeds with his plans.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Well, blamed if the king didn’t bill the house and the niggers and all the property for auction straight off—sale two days after the funeral; but anybody could buy private beforehand if they wanted to.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: It injured the frauds some; but the old fool he bulled right along, spite of all the duke could say or do, and I tell you the duke was powerful uneasy.

events.text_segment:
Well, blamed if the king didn’t bill the house and the niggers and all the property for auction straight off—sale two days after the funeral; but anybody could buy private beforehand if they wanted to.
So the next day after the funeral, along about noon-time, the girls’ joy got the first jolt. A couple of nigger traders come along, and the king sold them the niggers reasonable, for three-day drafts as they called it, and away they went, the two sons up the river to Memphis, and their mother down the river to Orleans. I thought them poor girls and them niggers would break their hearts for grief; they cried around each other, and took on so it most made me down sick to see it. The girls said they hadn’t ever dreamed of seeing the family separated or sold away from the town. I can’t ever get it out of my memory, the sight of them poor miserable girls and niggers hanging around each other’s necks and crying; and I reckon I couldn’t a stood it all, but would a had to bust out and tell on our gang if I hadn’t knowed the sale warn’t no account and the niggers would be back home in a week or two.
The thing made a big stir in the town, too, and a good many come out flatfooted and said it was scandalous to separate the mother and the children that way. It injured the frauds some; but the old fool he bulled right along, spite of all the duke could say or do, and I tell you the duke was powerful uneasy.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: Well, blamed if the king didn’t bill the house and the niggers and all the property for auction straight off—sale two days after the funeral; but anybody could buy private beforehand if they wanted to. The day after the funeral the nigger traders come in, and the king sold the whole nigger family—two sons went up the river to Memphis, and the mother went down to New Orleans. The girls cried and cried, and so did the niggers, and so did everybody that was there. The girls said they hadn’t ever thought of such a thing as the niggers being sold, and they said it was the most cruel thing they ever heard of. It made me sick to see it, and I couldn’t have stood it if I hadn’t know the sale was a fraud, and that the niggers would be back in a little while. The town was all stirred up about it, and a good many said it was a scandal to have the mother and children separated like that. It made the king and the duke lose a heap of popularity, and the duke was getting uneasy, but the king was as bold as brass and went on with his plans.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: Well, blamed if the king didn’t bill the house and the niggers and all the property for auction straight off—sale two days after the funeral; but anybody could buy private beforehand if they wanted to. He said it was the law, and that the heirs had to be paid off first, and then the rest of the money would go to the church and the poor. He had a whole lot of papers and writs and things, and he read them off in a mighty solemn way, like he was reading the Ten Commandments. Jim and me, we was mighty uneasy, because we knowed that if the house and the niggers went up for sale, Jim would be sold down the river, and I’d be in a bad fix too. We didn’t say nothing, but we watched the king like hawks. He had a way of talking that made you think he was mighty religious and honest, but you could see through it if you looked close. He had a whole lot of folks believing in him, and they was all ready to go to the auction and buy up the property. But Jim and me, we was thinking of a way to get out of there before the sale. We didn’t trust the king, and we didn’t trust the people who was going to the auction either. We knew that if we stayed around, we’d be in trouble. So we made up our minds to run off and find a place where we could be safe. We didn’t know where we was going, but we knowed we had to get out of there before it was too late.

events.title: The King and Duke Confront Huck About the Missing Money
detailed_summary: On the morning of the auction, the King and Duke awaken Huck, their expressions indicating trouble.
They interrogate Huck about whether he was in their room or saw anyone else enter it, suspecting the money is missing.
Huck denies being near their room since Mary Jane first showed it to them.
When pressed, Huck cleverly suggests he saw the enslaved individuals (referred to as 'niggers' by the characters) coming out of their room on the morning of the funeral, acting secretively.
The King and Duke are initially surprised, then seemingly convinced by Huck's implication that the enslaved people stole the money before being sold.
The Duke laments selling them so cheaply, believing they possessed significant 'histrionic talent' for feigning sorrow at their departure.
The King dismisses Huck sharply when he asks if something is wrong, telling him to mind his own business.
As they leave, the Duke makes a sarcastic comment about 'quick sales and small profits,' leading to an argument with the King about whose fault the supposed loss is.
The King then berates Huck for not informing him sooner about seeing the enslaved people in his room.
Huck feels relieved that he successfully diverted suspicion onto the enslaved people, especially since he believes they are safe and will not be harmed by his accusation, given their fraudulent sale.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Next day was auction day.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: So they went off a-jawing; and I felt dreadful glad I’d worked it all off on to the niggers, and yet hadn’t done the niggers no harm by it.

events.text_segment:
Next day was auction day. About broad day in the morning the king and the duke come up in the garret and woke me up, and I see by their look that there was trouble. The king says:
“Was you in my room night before last?”
“No, your majesty”—which was the way I always called him when nobody but our gang warn’t around.
“Was you in there yisterday er last night?”
“No, your majesty.”
“Honor bright, now—no lies.”
“Honor bright, your majesty, I’m telling you the truth. I hain’t been a-near your room since Miss Mary Jane took you and the duke and showed it to you.”
The duke says:
“Have you seen anybody else go in there?”
“No, your grace, not as I remember, I believe.”
“Stop and think.”
I studied awhile and see my chance; then I says:
“Well, I see the niggers go in there several times.”
Both of them gave a little jump, and looked like they hadn’t ever expected it, and then like they had. Then the duke says:
“What, all of them?”
“No—leastways, not all at once—that is, I don’t think I ever see them all come out at once but just one time.”
“Hello! When was that?”
“It was the day we had the funeral. In the morning. It warn’t early, because I overslept. I was just starting down the ladder, and I see them.”
“Well, go on, go on! What did they do? How’d they act?”
“They didn’t do nothing. And they didn’t act anyway much, as fur as I see. They tiptoed away; so I seen, easy enough, that they’d shoved in there to do up your majesty’s room, or something, s’posing you was up; and found you warn’t up, and so they was hoping to slide out of the way of trouble without waking you up, if they hadn’t already waked you up.”
“Great guns, this is a go!” says the king; and both of them looked pretty sick and tolerable silly. They stood there a-thinking and scratching their heads a minute, and the duke he bust into a kind of a little raspy chuckle, and says:
“It does beat all how neat the niggers played their hand. They let on to be sorry they was going out of this region! And I believed they was sorry, and so did you, and so did everybody. Don’t ever tell me any more that a nigger ain’t got any histrionic talent. Why, the way they played that thing it would fool anybody. In my opinion, there’s a fortune in ’em. If I had capital and a theater, I wouldn’t want a better lay-out than that—and here we’ve gone and sold ’em for a song. Yes, and ain’t privileged to sing the song yet. Say, where is that song—that draft?”
“In the bank for to be collected. Where would it be?”
“Well, that’s all right then, thank goodness.”
Says I, kind of timid-like:
“Is something gone wrong?”
The king whirls on me and rips out:
“None o’ your business! You keep your head shet, and mind y’r own affairs—if you got any. Long as you’re in this town don’t you forgit that—you hear?” Then he says to the duke, “We got to jest swaller it and say noth’n’: mum’s the word for us.”
As they was starting down the ladder the duke he chuckles again, and says:
“Quick sales and small profits! It’s a good business—yes.”
The king snarls around on him and says:
“I was trying to do for the best in sellin’ ’em out so quick. If the profits has turned out to be none, lackin’ considable, and none to carry, is it my fault any more’n it’s yourn?”
“Well, they’d be in this house yet and we wouldn’t if I could a got my advice listened to.”
The king sassed back as much as was safe for him, and then swapped around and lit into me again. He give me down the banks for not coming and telling him I see the niggers come out of his room acting that way—said any fool would a knowed something was up. And then waltzed in and cussed himself awhile, and said it all come of him not laying late and taking his natural rest that morning, and he’d be blamed if he’d ever do it again. So they went off a-jawing; and I felt dreadful glad I’d worked it all off on to the niggers, and yet hadn’t done the niggers no harm by it.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: Next day was auction day. The King and the Duke was up betimes and come to my room and stood over me, and their looks was like they had got a blamed sight of trouble on their minds. They didn't say nothing for a minute or two, but just looked at me. Then the King says, "Well, now, Huck, did you happen to be in our room last night?" I says, "No, sir, I didn't." He says, "Did you see any one go in?" I says, "No, sir, I didn't." He says, "Well, then, what do you reckon become of the money?" I says, "I don't know, but I heard something about the niggers coming out of your room on the funeral morning, and they looked kind of scared and mysterious, like they was up to something." The King and the Duke looked at each other, and then the Duke says, "Well, I'll be damned!" and the King says, "I'll be danged too!" They was both so surprised they couldn't say nothing for a minute. Then the Duke says, "I always said they was the best niggers in the world for acting. They could cry over a dead man like they was in love with him." The King says, "Well, I'm afeared they took the money and run off with it." Then he turned to me and says, "Why didn't you tell me this before, Huck?" I says, "Because I didn't think it was any of my business, and besides, I didn't want to get the niggers in trouble, because they didn't do no harm, and they was sold for nothing." The King says, "Well, you might have thought of that before, and not kept it to yourself." I says, "I didn't know it was any use to tell you, because you was so busy with your own troubles." Then he turned to the Duke and says, "This is your fault, you sold them niggers too cheap." The Duke says, "No, it's your fault, you didn't look after the money." They begun to argue, and I slipped out and went down to the river and felt mighty glad, because I reckoned I had saved my own skin and done the niggers no harm, because they was gone and couldn't be hurt anyway."}

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
Next day was auction day. The town was all alive with excitement. The courthouse square was packed with people from miles around, all eager to see what treasures would be sold. There was a buzz in the air, like the day of a big fair or a circus. Folks had brought their best horses, their proudest wagons, and their most colorful clothes. The auctioneer, a tall, thin man with a booming voice, stood at the front of the platform, ready to start the proceedings.

The first item up for auction was a fine-looking mare, all black and glossy, with a mane like a waterfall. The bidding started low, but soon the price was climbing fast. Men were shouting, waving their hats, and stomping their feet, trying to outdo each other. The mare was sold for a tidy sum, and the crowd gave a cheer.

Next came a plow and a set of harnesses. These were practical items, but still, there was a bit of competition. A farmer from the next county offered a high price, and a local man matched it. They went back and forth for a while, and finally, the farmer won out.

Then came the most interesting item of all: a slave named Jim. Jim was a tall, strong man, with a kind face and a gentle manner. He had been owned by Miss Watson, a wealthy woman who had passed away recently. Jim had been a faithful servant, and many people in town knew him well. Some of them even felt sorry for him, knowing that he would be sold away from the only home he had ever known.

The auctioneer called out Jim's name, and the crowd fell silent. A few people stepped forward to bid, but most of them hesitated. It was clear that Jim was not just a piece of property; he was a person with feelings, with a family, with a past. The bidding was slow at first, but then a man from a distant town stepped forward and offered a high price. Another man matched it, and soon the price was climbing.

Jim stood quietly, watching the bidding with a calm expression. He didn't seem to be afraid, but there was a sadness in his eyes. He had heard the stories of slaves being sold away from their families, and he knew that this could be his fate. But he also knew that if he was sold to a kind master, he might have a better life.

The bidding continued for a long time, and finally, the man from the distant town won. He paid a high price for Jim, and the auctioneer declared the sale complete. Jim was led away, and the crowd slowly dispersed.

As the people left the square, they talked about the auction, about the mare, the plow, and Jim. Some were happy with what they had bought, others were disappointed. But most of them were thinking about Jim, wondering where he would go, and if he would be happy in his new home.

That night, the town was quiet. The excitement of the auction had passed, and the people went to bed with their thoughts. Some dreamed of the things they had bought, others dreamed of the things they had lost. And in the back of many minds was the image of Jim, walking away into the night, with a heavy heart and a hopeful spirit.

events.title: Huck Comforts Mary Jane and Reveals a Shocking Truth
detailed_summary: Huck, upon waking, finds Mary Jane crying in her room while packing for England, distressed about the separation of the enslaved family sold by the con men.
Feeling sympathy, Huck enters her room and tries to comfort her.
Mary Jane expresses her deep sorrow that the enslaved mother and children will never see each other again.
Impulsively, Huck blurts out that they will indeed be reunited within two weeks, a statement he knows to be true.

Taken aback by his own sudden revelation, Huck pauses to consider whether telling the full truth is wiser than concocting a lie in this difficult situation, ultimately deciding that the truth, though risky, seems safer.
He asks Mary Jane if she can go to a place out of town, Mr. Lothrop's, and stay for three or four days.
Huck strikes a deal with Mary Jane: if he proves how he knows the enslaved family will be reunited, she must go to Mr. Lothrop's and stay for the agreed time, to which she readily consents.
After securing her promise and bolting the door for privacy, Huck gravely informs Mary Jane that her supposed uncles are, in fact, frauds and 'dead-beats.'
Mary Jane is, of course, deeply shaken but then quickly consumed by rage, exclaiming that the impostors should be immediately tarred, feathered, and thrown into the river.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: By-and-by it was getting-up time.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “The brute! Come, don’t waste a minute—not a second—we’ll have them tarred and feathered, and flung in the river!”

events.text_segment:
By-and-by it was getting-up time. So I come down the ladder and started for down-stairs; but as I come to the girls’ room the door was open, and I see Mary Jane setting by her old hair trunk, which was open and she’d been packing things in it—getting ready to go to England. But she had stopped now with a folded gown in her lap, and had her face in her hands, crying. I felt awful bad to see it; of course anybody would. I went in there and says:
“Miss Mary Jane, you can’t a-bear to see people in trouble, and I can’t—most always. Tell me about it.”
So she done it. And it was the niggers—I just expected it. She said the beautiful trip to England was most about spoiled for her; she didn’t know how she was ever going to be happy there, knowing the mother and the children warn’t ever going to see each other no more—and then busted out bitterer than ever, and flung up her hands, and says:
“Oh, dear, dear, to think they ain’t ever going to see each other any more!”
“But they will—and inside of two weeks—and I know it!” says I.
Laws, it was out before I could think! And before I could budge she throws her arms around my neck and told me to say it again, say it again, say it again!
I see I had spoke too sudden and said too much, and was in a close place. I asked her to let me think a minute; and she set there, very impatient and excited and handsome, but looking kind of happy and eased-up, like a person that’s had a tooth pulled out. So I went to studying it out. I says to myself, I reckon a body that ups and tells the truth when he is in a tight place is taking considerable many resks, though I ain’t had no experience, and can’t say for certain; but it looks so to me, anyway; and yet here’s a case where I’m blest if it don’t look to me like the truth is better and actuly safer than a lie. I must lay it by in my mind, and think it over some time or other, it’s so kind of strange and unregular. I never see nothing like it. Well, I says to myself at last, I’m a-going to chance it; I’ll up and tell the truth this time, though it does seem most like setting down on a kag of powder and touching it off just to see where you’ll go to. Then I says:
“Miss Mary Jane, is there any place out of town a little ways where you could go and stay three or four days?”
“Yes; Mr. Lothrop’s. Why?”
“Never mind why yet. If I’ll tell you how I know the niggers will see each other again inside of two weeks—here in this house—and prove how I know it—will you go to Mr. Lothrop’s and stay four days?”
“Four days!” she says; “I’ll stay a year!”
“All right,” I says, “I don’t want nothing more out of you than just your word—I druther have it than another man’s kiss-the-Bible.” She smiled and reddened up very sweet, and I says, “If you don’t mind it, I’ll shut the door—and bolt it.”
Then I come back and set down again, and says:
“Don’t you holler. Just set still and take it like a man. I got to tell the truth, and you want to brace up, Miss Mary, because it’s a bad kind, and going to be hard to take, but there ain’t no help for it. These uncles of yourn ain’t no uncles at all; they’re a couple of frauds—regular dead-beats. There, now we’re over the worst of it, you can stand the rest middling easy.”
It jolted her up like everything, of course; but I was over the shoal water now, so I went right along, her eyes a-blazing higher and higher all the time, and told her every blame thing, from where we first struck that young fool going up to the steamboat, clear through to where she flung herself on to the king’s breast at the front door and he kissed her sixteen or seventeen times—and then up she jumps, with her face afire like sunset, and says:
“The brute! Come, don’t waste a minute—not a second—we’ll have them tarred and feathered, and flung in the river!”

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
By-and-by it was getting-up time. I rolled out and dressed myself, and then went to the window and looked out. It was a fine morning, and the sun was just coming up over the trees. I felt kind of lonesome, but I didn't let on. I was getting used to being by myself, and I didn't mind it so much now. I had a bite to eat and then went out to see what the day had in store for me.

I was just stepping out the door when I heard a noise. I turned around and saw Tom Sawyer coming down the street. He looked like he was in a hurry, and I could tell something was on his mind. I waited for him to come up to me, and when he did, he said, "Huck, I've got something to tell you."

I said, "Well, go on, then."

He said, "I've been thinking about you, and I've been thinking about the town. And I've been thinking about what we could do."

I said, "What's that?"

He said, "We could start a band of robbers."

I said, "A band of robbers?"

He said, "Yes, a real one. We could be outlaws, and we could do all sorts of things. We could rob people, and we could hide out in the woods, and we could have a good time."

I said, "I don't know, Tom. I don't think I want to be a robber."

He said, "Come on, Huck. It would be fun. We could dress up in disguises and carry guns and do all sorts of things."

I said, "I don't know, Tom. I don't think I want to be a robber."

He said, "Well, maybe you could be the leader."

I said, "I don't think I want to be the leader, either."

He said, "Well, maybe you could be the second in command."

I said, "I don't think I want to be the second in command, either."

He said, "Well, maybe you could be the cook."

I said, "I don't think I want to be the cook, either."

He said, "Well, maybe you could be the lookout."

I said, "I don't think I want to be the lookout, either."

He said, "Well, maybe you could be the prisoner."

I said, "I don't think I want to be the prisoner, either."

He said, "Well, maybe you could be the prisoner and the cook and the lookout and the leader and the second in command."

I said, "I don't think I want to be all of those things, either."

He said, "Well, maybe you could be the prisoner and the cook and the lookout and the leader and the second in command and the doctor."

I said, "I don't think I want to be the doctor, either."

He said, "Well, maybe you could be the prisoner and the cook and the lookout and the leader and the second in command and the doctor and the lawyer."

I said, "I don't think I want to be the lawyer, either."

He said, "Well, maybe you could be the prisoner and the cook and the lookout and the leader and the second in command and the doctor and the lawyer and the judge."

I said, "I don't think I want to be the judge, either."

He said, "Well, maybe you could be the prisoner and the cook and the lookout and the leader and the second in command and the doctor and the lawyer and the judge and the hangman."

I said, "I don't think I want to be the hangman, either."

He said, "Well, maybe you could be the prisoner and the cook and the lookout and the leader and the second in command and the doctor and the lawyer and the judge and the hangman and the jailer."

I said, "I don't think I want to be the jailer, either."

He said, "Well, maybe you could be the prisoner and the cook and the lookout and the leader and the second in command and the doctor and the lawyer and the judge and the hangman and the jailer and the sheriff."

I said, "I don't think I want to be the sheriff, either."

He said, "Well, maybe you could be the prisoner and the cook and the lookout and the leader and the second in command and the doctor and the lawyer and the judge and the hangman and the jailer and the sheriff and the mayor."

I said, "I don't think I want to be the mayor, either."

He said, "Well, maybe you could be the prisoner and the cook and the lookout and the leader and the second in command and the doctor and the lawyer and the judge and the hangman and the jailer and the sheriff and the mayor and the president."

I said, "I don't think I want to be the president, either."

He said, "Well, maybe you could be the prisoner and the cook and the lookout and the leader and the second in command and the doctor and the lawyer and the judge and the hangman and the jailer and the sheriff and the mayor and the president and the king."

I said, "I don't think I want to be the king, either."

He said, "Well, maybe you could be the prisoner and the cook and the lookout and the leader and the second in command and the doctor and the lawyer and the judge and the hangman and the jailer and the sheriff and the mayor and the president and the king and the emperor."

I said, "I don't think I want to be the emperor, either."

He said, "Well, maybe you could be the prisoner and the cook and the lookout and the leader and the second in command and the doctor and the lawyer and the judge and the hangman and the jailer and the sheriff and the mayor and the president and the king and the emperor and the pope."

I said, "I don't think I want to be the pope, either."

He said, "Well, maybe you could be the prisoner and the cook and the lookout and the leader and the second in command and the doctor and the lawyer and the judge and the hangman and the jailer and the sheriff and the mayor and the president and the king and the emperor and the pope and the devil."

I said, "I don't think I want to be the devil, either."

He said, "Well, maybe you could be the prisoner and the cook and the lookout and the leader and the second in command and the doctor and the lawyer and the judge and the hangman and the jailer and the sheriff and the mayor and the president and the king and the emperor and the pope and the devil and the angel."

I said, "I don't think I want to be the angel, either."

He said, "Well, maybe you could be the prisoner and the cook and the lookout and the leader and the second in command and the doctor and the lawyer and the judge and the hangman and the jailer and the sheriff and the mayor and the president and the king and the emperor and the pope and the devil and the angel and the ghost."

I said, "I don't think I want to be the ghost, either."

He said, "Well, maybe you could be the prisoner and the cook and the lookout and the leader and the second in command and the doctor and the lawyer and the judge and the hangman and the jailer and the sheriff and the mayor and the president and the king and the emperor and the pope and the devil and the angel

events.title: Huck Outlines a Plan for Justice and Mary Jane's Role
detailed_summary: Huck tempers Mary Jane's immediate desire for vengeance, reminding her to consider her actions carefully.
He explains that a premature exposure of the frauds would endanger another innocent person (Jim), whom they have a responsibility to protect.
Huck then lays out his plan: Mary Jane is to depart for Mr. Lothrop's place and remain there until nine or half-past nine that night.

If Huck hasn't returned by eleven o'clock, she should place a candle in her window as a signal; if he still hasn't appeared by eleven, it means he has escaped and is safe, at which point she can expose the con men and have them jailed.
He instructs Mary Jane that if he happens to be captured alongside the frauds, she must publicly declare that he had confided everything to her beforehand and offer him her full support.

To provide evidence against the con men, Huck writes 'Royal Nonesuch, Bricksville' on a piece of paper for Mary Jane, telling her to give it to the court so they can summon witnesses from that town who can identify the frauds.

Huck reassures her that the ongoing auction and the sale of the enslaved individuals are invalid and that the enslaved people will be returned, emphasizing that the con men are in a difficult position and won't be able to collect any money.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence:
Says I:
“Cert’nly. But do you mean before you go to Mr. Lothrop’s, or—”
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “Well,” she says, “I’ll run down to breakfast now, and then I’ll start straight for Mr. Lothrop’s.”

events.text_segment:
Says I:
“Cert’nly. But do you mean before you go to Mr. Lothrop’s, or—”
“Oh,” she says, “what am I thinking about!” she says, and set right down again. “Don’t mind what I said—please don’t—you won’t, now, will you?” Laying her silky hand on mine in that kind of a way that I said I would die first. “I never thought, I was so stirred up,” she says; “now go on, and I won’t do so any more. You tell me what to do, and whatever you say I’ll do it.”
“Well,” I says, “it’s a rough gang, them two frauds, and I’m fixed so I got to travel with them a while longer, whether I want to or not—I druther not tell you why; and if you was to blow on them this town would get me out of their claws, and I’d be all right; but there’d be another person that you don’t know about who’d be in big trouble. Well, we got to save him, hain’t we? Of course. Well, then, we won’t blow on them.”
Saying them words put a good idea in my head. I see how maybe I could get me and Jim rid of the frauds; get them jailed here, and then leave. But I didn’t want to run the raft in the daytime without anybody aboard to answer questions but me; so I didn’t want the plan to begin working till pretty late to-night. I says:
“Miss Mary Jane, I’ll tell you what we’ll do, and you won’t have to stay at Mr. Lothrop’s so long, nuther. How fur is it?”
“A little short of four miles—right out in the country, back here.”
“Well, that’ll answer. Now you go along out there, and lay low till nine or half-past to-night, and then get them to fetch you home again—tell them you’ve thought of something. If you get here before eleven put a candle in this window, and if I don’t turn up wait till eleven, and then if I don’t turn up it means I’m gone, and out of the way, and safe. Then you come out and spread the news around, and get these beats jailed.”
“Good,” she says, “I’ll do it.”
“And if it just happens so that I don’t get away, but get took up along with them, you must up and say I told you the whole thing beforehand, and you must stand by me all you can.”
“Stand by you! indeed I will. They sha’n’t touch a hair of your head!” she says, and I see her nostrils spread and her eyes snap when she said it, too.
“If I get away I sha’n’t be here,” I says, “to prove these rapscallions ain’t your uncles, and I couldn’t do it if I was here. I could swear they was beats and bummers, that’s all, though that’s worth something. Well, there’s others can do that better than what I can, and they’re people that ain’t going to be doubted as quick as I’d be. I’ll tell you how to find them. Gimme a pencil and a piece of paper. There—‘Royal Nonesuch, Bricksville.’ Put it away, and don’t lose it. When the court wants to find out something about these two, let them send up to Bricksville and say they’ve got the men that played the Royal Nonesuch, and ask for some witnesses—why, you’ll have that entire town down here before you can hardly wink, Miss Mary. And they’ll come a-biling, too.”
I judged we had got everything fixed about right now. So I says:
“Just let the auction go right along, and don’t worry. Nobody don’t have to pay for the things they buy till a whole day after the auction on accounts of the short notice, and they ain’t going out of this till they get that money; and the way we’ve fixed it the sale ain’t going to count, and they ain’t going to get no money. It’s just like the way it was with the niggers—it warn’t no sale, and the niggers will be back before long. Why, they can’t collect the money for the niggers yet—they’re in the worst kind of a fix, Miss Mary.”
“Well,” she says, “I’ll run down to breakfast now, and then I’ll start straight for Mr. Lothrop’s.”

Says I:
“Cert’nly. But do you mean before you go to Mr. Lothrop’s, or—”

Says Tom:
“Before. I want you to be there when I go to see him. I want you to be my witness. I want you to say you saw me there, and that I told you I was going to run away and be a pirate. That’ll make it all right if I don’t come back. It’ll look like I was just playing a joke, and not really gone. You see?”

Says I:
“I don’t see, Tom. I don’t see no sense in it. If you run away, you run away. What’s the good of making a witness?”

Says Tom:
“Why, if I don’t come back, and they find out I was gone, they’ll think I’m dead, or run off to be a soldier, or something. But if you say you saw me there, and that I told you I was going to run away and be a pirate, then they’ll think I’m just playing a joke, and not really gone. It’ll be all right. You see?”

events.title: Mary Jane's Departure and a Final Revelation About the Money
detailed_summary: Huck advises Mary Jane to leave for Mr. Lothrop's before breakfast, arguing that her expressive face would inadvertently reveal her knowledge of the deception to her 'uncles'.
Mary Jane understands and agrees to go, but firmly states she will not send her love to the frauds, a sentiment Huck respects.
Huck then confesses to Mary Jane that he had stolen the bag of gold from the con men, intending to return it to her.
He explains that he was nearly caught and had to hide the money in the first available spot, expressing his deep regret that it might no longer be there and that the hiding place was not ideal.
Mary Jane consoles Huck, insisting it wasn't his fault.

Unwilling to verbally describe the grim location of the hidden money (Peter Wilks's coffin), Huck writes it down on a piece of paper for her to read on her way to Mr. Lothrop's: 'I put it in the coffin.'
Recalling Mary Jane's sorrow at the coffin, Huck is moved, and as he gives her the note, he sees tears in her eyes as well.
Mary Jane shakes his hand firmly, promises to follow all his instructions, and assures him she will never forget him and will pray for him, then departs.

Huck reflects on Mary Jane's remarkable character, her grit, goodness, and beauty, admitting he has thought of her countless times since her departure and is deeply touched by her promise to pray for him.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “’Deed, that ain’t the ticket, Miss Mary Jane,” I says, “by no manner of means; go before breakfast.”
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: And when it comes to beauty—and goodness, too—she lays over them all. I hain’t ever seen her since that time that I see her go out of that door; no, I hain’t ever seen her since, but I reckon I’ve thought of her a many and a many a million times, and of her saying she would pray for me; and if ever I’d a thought it would do any good for me to pray for her, blamed if I wouldn’t a done it or bust.

events.text_segment:
“’Deed, that ain’t the ticket, Miss Mary Jane,” I says, “by no manner of means; go before breakfast.”
“Why?”
“What did you reckon I wanted you to go at all for, Miss Mary?”
“Well, I never thought—and come to think, I don’t know. What was it?”
“Why, it’s because you ain’t one of these leather-face people. I don’t want no better book than what your face is. A body can set down and read it off like coarse print. Do you reckon you can go and face your uncles when they come to kiss you good-morning, and never—”
“There, there, don’t! Yes, I’ll go before breakfast—I’ll be glad to. And leave my sisters with them?”
“Yes; never mind about them. They’ve got to stand it yet a while. They might suspicion something if all of you was to go. I don’t want you to see them, nor your sisters, nor nobody in this town; if a neighbor was to ask how is your uncles this morning your face would tell something. No, you go right along, Miss Mary Jane, and I’ll fix it with all of them. I’ll tell Miss Susan to give your love to your uncles and say you’ve went away for a few hours for to get a little rest and change, or to see a friend, and you’ll be back to-night or early in the morning.”
“Gone to see a friend is all right, but I won’t have my love given to them.”
“Well, then, it sha’n’t be.” It was well enough to tell her so—no harm in it. It was only a little thing to do, and no trouble; and it’s the little things that smooths people’s roads the most, down here below; it would make Mary Jane comfortable, and it wouldn’t cost nothing. Then I says: “There’s one more thing—that bag of money.”
“Well, they’ve got that; and it makes me feel pretty silly to think how they got it.”
“No, you’re out, there. They hain’t got it.”
“Why, who’s got it?”
“I wish I knowed, but I don’t. I had it, because I stole it from them; and I stole it to give to you; and I know where I hid it, but I’m afraid it ain’t there no more. I’m awful sorry, Miss Mary Jane, I’m just as sorry as I can be; but I done the best I could; I did honest. I come nigh getting caught, and I had to shove it into the first place I come to, and run—and it warn’t a good place.”
“Oh, stop blaming yourself—it’s too bad to do it, and I won’t allow it—you couldn’t help it; it wasn’t your fault. Where did you hide it?”
I didn’t want to set her to thinking about her troubles again; and I couldn’t seem to get my mouth to tell her what would make her see that corpse laying in the coffin with that bag of money on his stomach. So for a minute I didn’t say nothing; then I says:
“I’d ruther not tell you where I put it, Miss Mary Jane, if you don’t mind letting me off; but I’ll write it for you on a piece of paper, and you can read it along the road to Mr. Lothrop’s, if you want to. Do you reckon that’ll do?”
“Oh, yes.”
So I wrote: “I put it in the coffin. It was in there when you was crying there, away in the night. I was behind the door, and I was mighty sorry for you, Miss Mary Jane.”
It made my eyes water a little to remember her crying there all by herself in the night, and them devils laying there right under her own roof, shaming her and robbing her; and when I folded it up and give it to her I see the water come into her eyes, too; and she shook me by the hand, hard, and says:
“Good-bye. I’m going to do everything just as you’ve told me; and if I don’t ever see you again, I sha’n’t ever forget you and I’ll think of you a many and a many a time, and I’ll pray for you, too!”—and she was gone.
Pray for me! I reckoned if she knowed me she’d take a job that was more nearer her size. But I bet she done it, just the same—she was just that kind. She had the grit to pray for Judus if she took the notion—there warn’t no back-down to her, I judge. You may say what you want to, but in my opinion she had more sand in her than any girl I ever see; in my opinion she was just full of sand. It sounds like flattery, but it ain’t no flattery. And when it comes to beauty—and goodness, too—she lays over them all. I hain’t ever seen her since that time that I see her go out of that door; no, I hain’t ever seen her since, but I reckon I’ve thought of her a many and a many a million times, and of her saying she would pray for me; and if ever I’d a thought it would do any good for me to pray for her, blamed if I wouldn’t a done it or bust.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: 'Deed, that ain't the ticket, Miss Mary Jane,

simple_agent_extraction_refined_0.text: 'Deed, that ain't the ticket, Miss Mary Jane,

simple_agent_extraction_refined_1.text:
'Deed, that ain't the ticket, Miss Mary Jane,' I says, 'by no manner of means; go before breakfast.' I reckoned if she stayed around till breakfast time, her face would give the whole show away. She had a way about her that made folks notice things, and her uncles would be sure to see the truth in her eyes. She looked at me, puzzled at first, but then she nodded, understanding what I meant. 'Very well,' she said, 'I will go. But I won't send my love to those frauds.' I had to admire her for that. She had spirit, and I reckoned she had a right to feel that way.

I told her then about the bag of money. I had took it from the con men, and I had meant to give it back to her, but I had been near caught and had to hide it in the first place that come to hand. I felt awful bad about it, for I knew it wasn't no good hiding place, and I feared it might be gone by now. She didn't scold me, though. She just took my hand and said, 'It wasn't your fault, Huck. You did what you could.'

I couldn't say where I had hid the money, for it was a grim place, and I didn't want to speak of it. So I wrote it down on a piece of paper and gave it to her. 'Read this on your way to Mr. Lothrop's,' I said. She read it and looked up at me with tears in her eyes. I saw the sorrow in her face, and it made me feel worse than ever. I had stole the money to do right, but now I reckoned I had only made things worse.

She shook my hand, firm and true, and said she would do just as I told her. 'I will never forget you, Huck,' she said, 'and I will pray for you.' Then she was gone, and I stood there, feeling like a fool and a sinner, but also feeling something else—something like hope, maybe. I thought about her a lot after that, and I reckoned she was the kind of girl that could make a man feel like he was worth something, even when he wasn't.

events.title: Huck Deceives Susan and Joanna to Cover Mary Jane's Absence
detailed_summary: After Mary Jane secretly leaves, Huck approaches her sisters, Susan and Joanna (the 'hare-lip'), to explain Mary Jane's absence.
He initially tells them Mary Jane rushed off to visit a sick friend from across the river, named Hanner Proctor.

When pressed for details about Hanner's illness, Huck invents a complex and severe disease, describing it as a new kind of mumps mixed with measles, whooping cough, erysipelas, consumption, yellow jaundice, and brain fever.

He convinces the sisters that this 'pluribus-unum mumps' is highly contagious and that they shouldn't tell their 'uncles' about Mary Jane's exposure, as it would delay their trip to England for at least three months.
The sisters, eager to go to England, agree not to tell anyone, especially their 'uncles'.

Huck then refines the cover story, instructing the sisters to tell their 'uncles' that Mary Jane went to ask the wealthy Apthorp family to attend the auction and buy the house, as Peter Wilks would have wished it.
The sisters accept this explanation and go to inform the King and Duke, giving them Mary Jane's supposed love and kisses.

Huck feels satisfied with his elaborate deception, confident that the girls will remain silent due to their desire to go to England, and that the King and Duke will be content with Mary Jane being away, thus keeping her from encountering Doctor Robinson. He prides himself on handling the situation skillfully.
