Of course he would a throwed more style into it, but I can’t do that very handy, not being brung up to it.

events.text_segment:
Well, Mary Jane she lit out the back way, I reckon; because nobody see her go. When I struck Susan and the hare-lip, I says:
“What’s the name of them people over on t’other side of the river that you all goes to see sometimes?”
They says:
“There’s several; but it’s the Proctors, mainly.”
“That’s the name,” I says; “I most forgot it. Well, Miss Mary Jane she told me to tell you she’s gone over there in a dreadful hurry—one of them’s sick.”
“Which one?”
“I don’t know; leastways, I kinder forget; but I thinks it’s—”
“Sakes alive, I hope it ain’t Hanner?”
“I’m sorry to say it,” I says, “but Hanner’s the very one.”
“My goodness, and she so well only last week! Is she took bad?”
“It ain’t no name for it. They set up with her all night, Miss Mary Jane said, and they don’t think she’ll last many hours.”
“Only think of that, now! What’s the matter with her?”
I couldn’t think of anything reasonable, right off that way, so I says:
“Mumps.”
“Mumps your granny! They don’t set up with people that’s got the mumps.”
“They don’t, don’t they? You better bet they do with these mumps. These mumps is different. It’s a new kind, Miss Mary Jane said.”
“How’s it a new kind?”
“Because it’s mixed up with other things.”
“What other things?”
“Well, measles, and whooping-cough, and erysiplas, and consumption, and yaller janders, and brain-fever, and I don’t know what all.”
“My land! And they call it the mumps?”
“That’s what Miss Mary Jane said.”
“Well, what in the nation do they call it the mumps for?”
“Why, because it is the mumps. That’s what it starts with.”
“Well, ther’ ain’t no sense in it. A body might stump his toe, and take pison, and fall down the well, and break his neck, and bust his brains out, and somebody come along and ask what killed him, and some numskull up and say, ‘Why, he stumped his toe.’ Would ther’ be any sense in that? No. And ther’ ain’t no sense in this, nuther. Is it ketching?”
“Is it ketching? Why, how you talk. Is a harrow catching—in the dark? If you don’t hitch on to one tooth, you’re bound to on another, ain’t you? And you can’t get away with that tooth without fetching the whole harrow along, can you? Well, these kind of mumps is a kind of a harrow, as you may say—and it ain’t no slouch of a harrow, nuther, you come to get it hitched on good.”
“Well, it’s awful, I think,” says the hare-lip. “I’ll go to Uncle Harvey and—”
“Oh, yes,” I says, “I would. Of course I would. I wouldn’t lose no time.”
“Well, why wouldn’t you?”
“Just look at it a minute, and maybe you can see. Hain’t your uncles obleegd to get along home to England as fast as they can? And do you reckon they’d be mean enough to go off and leave you to go all that journey by yourselves? You know they’ll wait for you. So fur, so good. Your uncle Harvey’s a preacher, ain’t he? Very well, then; is a preacher going to deceive a steamboat clerk? is he going to deceive a ship clerk?—so as to get them to let Miss Mary Jane go aboard? Now you know he ain’t. What will he do, then? Why, he’ll say, ‘It’s a great pity, but my church matters has got to get along the best way they can; for my niece has been exposed to the dreadful pluribus-unum mumps, and so it’s my bounden duty to set down here and wait the three months it takes to show on her if she’s got it.’ But never mind, if you think it’s best to tell your uncle Harvey—”
“Shucks, and stay fooling around here when we could all be having good times in England whilst we was waiting to find out whether Mary Jane’s got it or not? Why, you talk like a muggins.”
“Well, anyway, maybe you’d better tell some of the neighbors.”
“Listen at that, now. You do beat all for natural stupidness. Can’t you see that they’d go and tell? Ther’ ain’t no way but just to not tell anybody at all.”
“Well, maybe you’re right—yes, I judge you are right.”
“But I reckon we ought to tell Uncle Harvey she’s gone out a while, anyway, so he won’t be uneasy about her?”
“Yes, Miss Mary Jane she wanted you to do that. She says, ‘Tell them to give Uncle Harvey and William my love and a kiss, and say I’ve run over the river to see Mr.’—Mr.—what is the name of that rich family your uncle Peter used to think so much of?—I mean the one that—”
“Why, you must mean the Apthorps, ain’t it?”
“Of course; bother them kind of names, a body can’t ever seem to remember them, half the time, somehow. Yes, she said, say she has run over for to ask the Apthorps to be sure and come to the auction and buy this house, because she allowed her uncle Peter would ruther they had it than anybody else; and she’s going to stick to them till they say they’ll come, and then, if she ain’t too tired, she’s coming home; and if she is, she’ll be home in the morning anyway. She said, don’t say nothing about the Proctors, but only about the Apthorps—which’ll be perfectly true, because she is going there to speak about their buying the house; I know it, because she told me so herself.”
“All right,” they said, and cleared out to lay for their uncles, and give them the love and the kisses, and tell them the message.
Everything was all right now. The girls wouldn’t say nothing because they wanted to go to England; and the king and the duke would ruther Mary Jane was off working for the auction than around in reach of Doctor Robinson. I felt very good; I judged I had done it pretty neat—I reckoned Tom Sawyer couldn’t a done it no neater himself. Of course he would a throwed more style into it, but I can’t do that very handy, not being brung up to it.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: Well, Mary Jane she lit out the back way, I reckon; because nobody see her go. So I went to Susan and Joanna Wilks, and told them she had gone over the river to see a sick friend of hers, a boy named Hanner Proctor. I said he was awful sick, and that Mary Jane had got to go right away, and that she hadn't time to say good-by. Susan and Joanna, they looked kind of uneasy, and Susan says: "But what is the matter with him?" I says: "Why, it's a new kind of mumps, I reckon, mixed with the measles and the whooping-cough and erysipelas and consumption and the yellow jaundice and brain-fever all rolled into one. It's a pluribus-unum mumps, I call it. It's the worst kind of a disease that ever was invented, and it's mighty contagious." They looked scared, and I see I was getting along. I says: "You don't want to tell the uncles about it, do you? Because if you do, they'll have to stay here three months to let the house out and get ready, and then they can't go to England this trip." They said they wouldn't tell a soul, and I said: "That's right. But you got to be careful, because if the uncles find out Mary Jane has been exposed, they'll be awful mad, and they'll think she's been fooling with the niggers and the tramps, and they'll never go to England at all." So they said they wouldn't say a word, and I said: "Now, I want you to tell the uncles that Mary Jane went over to ask the Apthorps to come to the auction and buy the house, because Peter Wilks would have wanted it so." They said they would, and they went off to do it, and they gave the uncles Mary Jane's love and kisses, and the uncles was satisfied, and didn't ask no more questions. So I felt good, because I knowed the girls wouldn't say no more, because they wanted to go to England, and the uncles wouldn't be looking for Mary Jane, and so she'd be safe from Doctor Robinson. I reckoned I had handled that business considerable slick.

Well, Mary Jane she lit out the back way, I reckon; because nobody see her go. I was sittin' on the porch, chewin' on a piece of licorice, and I heard her footsteps go scufflin' down the alley. I didn't say nothin', 'cause I reckoned she had her reasons. Mary Jane was a good girl, but she had a mind of her own, and she wasn't afraid to use it. I remember once she told me, 'Huck, you can't make a person do what they don't want to do, and you can't stop 'em neither.' I didn't know what she meant at the time, but I reckon I do now.

I waited a while, but she didn't come back. The sun was gettin' low, and the shadows was stretchin' out long on the ground. I thought maybe she had gone to see her mammy, who lived a few blocks down the road. But when I went to check, I found the house empty and the door wide open. That made me uneasy. I didn't like the feel of it. It was like somethin' bad was about to happen.

I went back to the house and told Tom Sawyer, who was sittin' on the steps with a book in his lap. He looked up and said, 'Well, that's strange. I wonder where she went.' Tom was always full of ideas, but he didn't seem too worried. He said, 'Maybe she just wanted to take a walk. Girls do that sometimes.' But I didn't think so. Mary Jane wasn't the kind to just go for a walk without tellin' nobody.

I started to get a feelin' that somethin' was wrong. I went to the river and looked around. The water was still and quiet, and the air was thick with the smell of damp earth. I thought maybe she had gone down there to think. I called her name a few times, but there was no answer. I was gettin' worried now. I didn't like the way things was goin'.

I went back to town and asked around. I asked the storekeeper, and he said he hadn't seen her. I asked the baker, and he said the same. I even asked old Mrs. Douglas, who was always knowin' everythin' that went on in town. She said, 'I haven't seen her, Huck. But I heard somethin' about a man in town who was lookin' for a girl. He said he had a job for her.' That made me even more uneasy. I didn't like the sound of that.

I went back to the house and told Tom what I had heard. He looked up from his book and said, 'Well, that's bad. We need to find her.' He was always the one to take action, while I was more the one to think things through. But this time, I reckoned we both needed to do a little of both.

We started to make plans. Tom said we should go to the river and see if we could find any clues. I said we should go to the store and see if we could find out more about the man who was lookin' for a girl. We both agreed that we needed to be careful. We didn't want to get in trouble if we was caught snoopin' around.

We went to the river first. The water was still, and the air was thick with the smell of damp earth. I looked around, but I didn't see nothin'. Tom said, 'Maybe she went the other way.' So we went back to town and went to the store. The storekeeper was still there, and he looked up from his paper and said, 'Well, if it ain't Tom Sawyer and Huck Finn. What can I do for you boys today?' Tom said, 'We're lookin' for a girl. Her name is Mary Jane. Have you seen her?' The storekeeper said, 'No, I haven't. But I heard somethin' about a man in town who was lookin' for a girl. He said he had a job for her.' That made me even more uneasy. I didn't like the sound of that.

We left the store and went back to the house. Tom said, 'We need to find her before it's too late.' I said, 'I reckon you're right.' We both knew that we had to do somethin' before it was too late. We didn't know what, but we knew we had to do it quick.

We went to the river again, and this time we found somethin'. There was a piece of cloth on the bank, and it looked like it had been torn off a dress. I picked it up and looked at it. Tom said, 'That's Mary Jane's dress.' I said, 'I reckon it is.' We both felt a chill run down our spines. We knew that somethin' bad had happened.

We went back to town and told Mrs. Douglas what we had found. She looked at the cloth and said, 'That's Mary Jane's dress. I know that pattern.' She looked up at us and said, 'We need to find her before it's too late.' I said, 'I reckon you're right.' We both knew that we had to do somethin' before it was too late. We didn't know what, but we knew we had to do it quick.

We went to the river again, and this time we found somethin' else. There was a boat tied up on the bank, and it looked like it had been used recently. I looked at it and said, 'That's the man's boat.' Tom said, 'We need to follow it.' I said, 'I reckon we do.' We both knew that we had to do somethin' before it was too late. We didn't know what, but we knew we had to do it quick.

We went to the river and followed the boat. It was gettin' dark, and the stars was startin' to come out. The water was still, and the air was thick with the smell of damp earth. events.title: The Auction's Climax and the Arrival of True Claimants
detailed_summary: The auction of Peter Wilks's property takes place in the public square towards the end of the afternoon, proceeding slowly.
The King (the 'old man') is present next to the auctioneer, maintaining his fraudulent persona by interjecting with pious remarks and bits of Scripture.
The Duke is also active, mingling with the crowd and attempting to evoke sympathy with feigned sorrow.
After a lengthy process, nearly everything is sold, except for a small, insignificant lot in the graveyard which the King is eager to offload.
While they are still trying to sell this last piece of property, a steamboat arrives at the landing.
Within minutes, a noisy crowd disembarks from the steamboat, shouting, laughing, and creating a commotion as they make their way up from the river.
The newcomers dramatically announce their arrival, proclaiming themselves as the 'opposition line' and presenting 'two sets of heirs to old Peter Wilks,' offering the townspeople a choice.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Well, they held the auction in the public square, along towards the end of the afternoon, and it strung along, and strung along, and the old man he was on hand and looking his level pisonest, up there longside of the auctioneer, and chipping in a little Scripture now and then, or a little goody-goody saying of some kind, and the duke he was around goo-gooing for sympathy all he knowed how, and just spreading himself generly.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “Here’s your opposition line! here’s your two sets o’ heirs to old Peter Wilks—and you pays your money and you takes your choice!”

events.text_segment:
Well, they held the auction in the public square, along towards the end of the afternoon, and it strung along, and strung along, and the old man he was on hand and looking his level pisonest, up there longside of the auctioneer, and chipping in a little Scripture now and then, or a little goody-goody saying of some kind, and the duke he was around goo-gooing for sympathy all he knowed how, and just spreading himself generly.
But by-and-by the thing dragged through, and everything was sold—everything but a little old trifling lot in the graveyard. So they’d got to work that off—I never see such a girafft as the king was for wanting to swallow everything. Well, whilst they was at it a steamboat landed, and in about two minutes up comes a crowd a-whooping and yelling and laughing and carrying on, and singing out:
“Here’s your opposition line! here’s your two sets o’ heirs to old Peter Wilks—and you pays your money and you takes your choice!”

events.title: Arrival of the True Heirs
detailed_summary: Two new individuals, an older gentleman and a younger man with his arm in a sling, are brought into town, causing amusement among the crowd.
Huck, the narrator, does not find the situation humorous and anticipates that the duke and king will be disconcerted.
Contrary to Huck's expectation, the duke acts innocently pleased, while the king feigns sorrow over the appearance of what he implies are more impostors.
Several prominent townspeople show their allegiance by gathering around the king.
The newly arrived older gentleman appears utterly perplexed by the situation.
He addresses the crowd, revealing an authentic English accent, different from the king's imitation.
He introduces himself as Harvey Wilks and his companion as his brother William, who is deaf, mute, and further hampered by a broken arm.
Harvey explains their recent misfortunes: William's injury and their baggage being mistakenly left at a different town upriver.
He asserts their true identities and declares their intention to prove them upon the arrival of their baggage in a day or two, stating they will wait at the local hotel.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: They was fetching a very nice-looking old gentleman along, and a nice-looking younger one, with his right arm in a sling.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: But up till then I won’t say nothing more, but go to the hotel and wait.”

events.text_segment:
They was fetching a very nice-looking old gentleman along, and a nice-looking younger one, with his right arm in a sling. And, my souls, how the people yelled and laughed, and kept it up. But I didn’t see no joke about it, and I judged it would strain the duke and the king some to see any. I reckoned they’d turn pale. But no, nary a pale did they turn. The duke he never let on he suspicioned what was up, but just went a goo-gooing around, happy and satisfied, like a jug that’s googling out buttermilk; and as for the king, he just gazed and gazed down sorrowful on them new-comers like it give him the stomach-ache in his very heart to think there could be such frauds and rascals in the world. Oh, he done it admirable. Lots of the principal people gethered around the king, to let him see they was on his side. That old gentleman that had just come looked all puzzled to death. Pretty soon he begun to speak, and I see straight off he pronounced like an Englishman—not the king’s way, though the king’s was pretty good for an imitation. I can’t give the old gent’s words, nor I can’t imitate him; but he turned around to the crowd, and says, about like this:
“This is a surprise to me which I wasn’t looking for; and I’ll acknowledge, candid and frank, I ain’t very well fixed to meet it and answer it; for my brother and me has had misfortunes; he’s broke his arm, and our baggage got put off at a town above here last night in the night by a mistake. I am Peter Wilks’ brother Harvey, and this is his brother William, which can’t hear nor speak—and can’t even make signs to amount to much, now’t he’s only got one hand to work them with. We are who we say we are; and in a day or two, when I get the baggage, I can prove it. But up till then I won’t say nothing more, but go to the hotel and wait.”

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: They was fetching a very nice-looking old gentleman along, and a nice-looking younger one, with his right arm in a sling. The crowd was all in a laugh, and holler, and shout, and make a general row, and I see right away that the king and the duke was in a sweat, and didn't know what to do. But the duke he put on the innocent pleased look, and the king he put on the sorrowful look, and said it was a shame, and he reckoned he'd have to give up the town, now that there was more of the Wilks family come. But the old gentleman, he looked kind of bewildered, and didn't seem to know what it was all about. He stood there with his hands behind him, and his eyes wide open, and then he says, in a real English voice, that didn't sound like the king's, 'I beg your pardon, but who are you, and what is this all about?' And the king, he says, 'Why, we are your relations, and we are here to claim the property, and to take care of you, and to see that you don't get imposed upon.' And the old gentleman, he says, 'I don't understand a word you are saying. I am Harvey Wilks, and this is my brother William, and we have just come down the river from St. Louis, and we have had a great misfortune. William here has broken his arm, and we lost all our baggage at a town up the river, and we are going to stay at the hotel until our things come along, and then we will prove who we are.' And the king, he says, 'Well, I reckon we can wait a day or two, and see what comes of it.' And the crowd, they all went away, and the king and the duke, they looked kind of uneasy, and I see right away that there was going to be trouble.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
They was fetching a very nice-looking old gentleman along, and a nice-looking younger one, with his right arm in a sling. They was both dressed up in the style of the old-fashioned Southern gentry, and they had a fine air about them that made me feel like I was in the presence of real people. The old gentleman had a silver beard and wore a dark blue coat with brass buttons, and the younger one had a mustache and a look of determination on his face. I could see that they was both proud men, and I reckoned they had been through some hard times to be brought along like this.

The men that was fetching them was rough-looking and had a cruel look in their eyes. They was dressed in rough clothes and had guns strapped to their sides. I could see that they was not to be trusted, and I felt a little uneasy watching them. I had heard of men like this before, and I knew that they was not the kind of people you wanted to get mixed up with.

The old gentleman and the younger one was being taken to a place where they would be tried for some crime or other. I didn't know what it was, but I could see that they was being treated like criminals, and I felt sorry for them. I had heard of men being treated this way before, and I knew that it was not right. I had always been taught that all men was equal, and I didn't see why these two gentlemen should be treated so badly just because they had been accused of something.

As I watched them being taken away, I felt a sense of injustice and I wished that I could do something to help them. I had always been a free spirit, and I didn't like to see people being treated unfairly. I knew that I couldn't do anything about it right now, but I made a mental note to keep an eye on them and see if there was anything I could do to help them in the future.

events.title: The King's Deflection and Hines's Accusation
detailed_summary: As the genuine Wilks brothers depart for the hotel, the king vociferously derides their explanation, suggesting their misfortunes are fabrications typical of frauds.
The majority of the onlookers laugh in agreement with the king.
However, a small group, including Doctor Robinson and a lawyer named Levi Bell, who has just arrived by steamboat, remain unconvinced and are seen conferring quietly.
A local man, identified later as Hines, steps forward and directly confronts the king about his account of arriving in town.
The king reiterates his claim of arriving by steamboat from Cincinnati the evening before the funeral.
Hines sharply contradicts the king, stating he personally saw the king, along with Tim Collins and a boy, at 'the Pint' that very morning, having arrived in a canoe.
Doctor Robinson inquires if Hines would recognize the boy again.
Hines immediately points to Huck, confirming him as the boy he saw with the king.

Doctor Robinson then addresses the crowd, expressing his conviction that the king and duke are impostors and proposing they all go to the tavern to confront the two pairs of claimants to ascertain the truth.

segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: I reckon we’ll find out		something		before we get through.”

events.text_segment:
So him and the new dummy started off; and the king he laughs, and blethers out:
“Broke his arm—very likely, ain’t it?—and very convenient, too, for a fraud that’s got to make signs, and ain’t learnt how. Lost their baggage! That’s mighty good!—and mighty ingenious—under the circumstances!”
So he laughed again; and so did everybody else, except three or four, or maybe half a dozen. One of these was that doctor; another one was a sharp-looking gentleman, with a carpet-bag of the old-fashioned kind made out of carpet-stuff, that had just come off of the steamboat and was talking to him in a low voice, and glancing towards the king now and then and nodding their heads—it was Levi Bell, the lawyer that was gone up to Louisville; and another one was a big rough husky that come along and listened to all the old gentleman said, and was listening to the king now. And when the king got done this husky up and says:
“Say, looky here; if you are Harvey Wilks, when’d you come to this town?”
“The day before the funeral, friend,” says the king.
“But what time o’ day?”
“In the evenin’—’bout an hour er two before sundown.”
“How’d you come?”
“I come down on the Susan Powell from Cincinnati.”
“Well, then, how’d you come to be up at the Pint in the mornin’—in a canoe?”
“I warn’t up at the Pint in the mornin’.”
“It’s a lie.”
Several of them jumped for him and begged him not to talk that way to an old man and a preacher.
“Preacher be hanged, he’s a fraud and a liar. He was up at the Pint that mornin’. I live up there, don’t I? Well, I was up there, and he was up there. I see him there. He come in a canoe, along with Tim Collins and a boy.”
The doctor he up and says:
“Would you know the boy again if you was to see him, Hines?”
“I reckon I would, but I don’t know. Why, yonder he is, now. I know him perfectly easy.”
It was me he pointed at. The doctor says:
“Neighbors, I don’t know whether the new couple is frauds or not; but if these two ain’t frauds, I am an idiot, that’s all. I think it’s our duty to see that they don’t get away from here till we’ve looked into this thing. Come along, Hines; come along, the rest of you. We’ll take these fellows to the tavern and affront them with t’other couple, and I reckon we’ll find out something before we get through.”

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: So him and the new dummy started off; and the king he laughs, and blethers out: 'Well, I reckon they'll be gone a while, anyway. I'll take this chance to get out and have a look around.' So he slipped out of the house and started down the road, keeping a sharp eye out for folks. He was mighty curious to see what kind of place this was, and if there was any chance of getting a fresh horse or some supplies. He hadn't had a decent meal in two days, and he was getting mighty tired of salt pork and hardtack. He walked along, keeping to the shadows, and every time he heard a sound, he'd duck behind a tree or a bush. He was just about to cross a little creek when he heard a voice behind him say, 'Hello there, stranger. You lost?' He turned around and saw a man standing there, holding a shotgun. The man had a long beard and wore a ragged coat. The king looked at him and said, 'No, I ain't lost. I'm just passing through.' The man squinted at him and said, 'Well, you look like you're in a hurry. You got a name?' The king thought fast and said, 'Name's Solomon. Solomon Grangerford.' The man looked at him for a minute, then said, 'Well, Solomon Grangerford, you might want to be careful around here. This is a rough part of the country.' The king said, 'I don't mind rough. I've seen rougher.' The man chuckled and said, 'Well, if you're looking for trouble, you've come to the right place. But if you're looking for a place to rest, I reckon you can stay the night. My name's Tom, by the way.' The king said, 'Pleasure to meet you, Tom. I'd appreciate the rest.' So Tom led him to a little cabin in the woods, and they sat down by the fire. Tom gave him some coffee and a piece of cornbread, and they talked for a while. The king found out that Tom was a widower with two kids, and that he'd been living in the woods for years, avoiding the law. The king listened and nodded, pretending to be interested, but he was really thinking about how he could get Tom's horse and supplies and be on his way. He was getting tired of this place, and he wanted to get back to the others before they missed him. He figured he could take the horse and leave Tom with a few dollars and a note, and that would be the end of it. But he didn't count on Tom being a man of his word, and when the time came to leave, Tom was right there, watching him go.

events.title: The Investigation Begins: The Missing Gold
detailed_summary: The crowd, eager for the confrontation, proceeds with all parties to a spacious room in the hotel, where candles are lit.
Doctor Robinson voices his suspicion that the king and duke are frauds and expresses concern that any accomplices they might have could escape with Peter Wilks's gold.
He suggests that if the king and duke are genuine, they should not oppose sending for the money and allowing the townsfolk to keep it safe until their identities are proven.
The king, affecting a sorrowful demeanor, agrees with the sentiment but declares that the money is unfortunately no longer where it was.
He fabricates a story, claiming he hid the gold inside his straw mattress for safekeeping, as he was unaccustomed to 'niggers' and assumed their honesty like English servants.
He alleges that the slaves, whom he subsequently sold, stole the gold the very next morning after he had hidden it, and he hadn't missed it before their departure.
He further states that his 'servant,' Huck, can attest to these events.
The doctor and several others react with audible disbelief to the king's tale.

When questioned, Huck claims he did not witness the slaves stealing the money but did see them surreptitiously leaving the room and hurrying away, which he had assumed was due to fear of having awakened his master.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: It was nuts for the crowd, though maybe not for the king’s friends; so we all started.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: That was all they asked me.

events.text_segment:
It was nuts for the crowd, though maybe not for the king’s friends; so we all started. It was about sundown. The doctor he led me along by the hand, and was plenty kind enough, but he never let go my hand.
We all got in a big room in the hotel, and lit up some candles, and fetched in the new couple. First, the doctor says:
“I don’t wish to be too hard on these two men, but I think they’re frauds, and they may have complices that we don’t know nothing about. If they have, won’t the complices get away with that bag of gold Peter Wilks left? It ain’t unlikely. If these men ain’t frauds, they won’t object to sending for that money and letting us keep it till they prove they’re all right—ain’t that so?”
Everybody agreed to that. So I judged they had our gang in a pretty tight place right at the outstart. But the king he only looked sorrowful, and says:
“Gentlemen, I wish the money was there, for I ain’t got no disposition to throw anything in the way of a fair, open, out-and-out investigation o’ this misable business; but, alas, the money ain’t there; you k’n send and see, if you want to.”
“Where is it, then?”
“Well, when my niece give it to me to keep for her I took and hid it inside o’ the straw tick o’ my bed, not wishin’ to bank it for the few days we’d be here, and considerin’ the bed a safe place, we not bein’ used to niggers, and suppos’n’ ’em honest, like servants in England. The niggers stole it the very next mornin’ after I had went down stairs; and when I sold ’em I hadn’t missed the money yit, so they got clean away with it. My servant here k’n tell you ’bout it, gentlemen.”
The doctor and several said “Shucks!” and I see nobody didn’t altogether believe him. One man asked me if I see the niggers steal it. I said no, but I see them sneaking out of the room and hustling away, and I never thought nothing, only I reckoned they was afraid they had waked up my master and was trying to get away before he made trouble with them. That was all they asked me.

The king hept up a solemn face and said he reckoned that was reasonable, but said the money wasn't where it was. The doctor and some others said that was a mighty thin story. When they asked me, I said I hadn't seen the niggers steal the money, but I had seen them slip out of the room and run off, and I had thought they was scared they had waked up the king.

events.title: Huck's Interrogation and Awkward Testimony
detailed_summary: Doctor Robinson abruptly turns his attention to Huck and questions if he is also English.
Huck affirms that he is, which elicits laughter and expressions of disbelief, such as 'Stuff!', from the doctor and others.
A lengthy and disorganized general investigation commences, continuing for hours without any mention of supper.
Both the king and the newly arrived old gentleman (the real Harvey Wilks) are compelled to share their respective narratives.
Huck privately observes that any unbiased person would easily discern that the old gentleman was telling the truth while the king was lying.
Eventually, Huck is called upon to provide his account of events.
The king gives Huck a subtle, sidelong glance, which Huck understands as a cue to support the king's version of the story.
Huck begins to invent details about their supposed life in Sheffield and information about the English Wilks family.
He does not get very far into his fabricated tale before Doctor Robinson starts to laugh.
Levi Bell, the lawyer, interjects, advising Huck to stop, remarking on his apparent lack of experience and skill in lying, and suggesting he needs more practice.
Although Huck doesn't appreciate the nature of the 'compliment,' he is relieved to be excused from further testimony.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Then the doctor whirls on me and says:
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: I didn’t care nothing for the compliment, but I was glad to be let off, anyway.

events.text_segment:
Then the doctor whirls on me and says:
“Are you English, too?”
I says yes; and him and some others laughed, and said, “Stuff!”
Well, then they sailed in on the general investigation, and there we had it, up and down, hour in, hour out, and nobody never said a word about supper, nor ever seemed to think about it—and so they kept it up, and kept it up; and it was the worst mixed-up thing you ever see. They made the king tell his yarn, and they made the old gentleman tell his’n; and anybody but a lot of prejudiced chuckleheads would a seen that the old gentleman was spinning truth and t’other one lies. And by-and-by they had me up to tell what I knowed. The king he give me a left-handed look out of the corner of his eye, and so I knowed enough to talk on the right side. I begun to tell about Sheffield, and how we lived there, and all about the English Wilkses, and so on; but I didn’t get pretty fur till the doctor begun to laugh; and Levi Bell, the lawyer, says:
“Set down, my boy; I wouldn’t strain myself if I was you. I reckon you ain’t used to lying, it don’t seem to come handy; what you want is practice. You do it pretty awkward.”
I didn’t care nothing for the compliment, but I was glad to be let off, anyway.

He lets out a kind of a snort and says, "Stuff!" and the rest of them all says "Stuff!" and laughed, and said it was the biggest lie they ever struck. Then they begun to investigate. They asked a million questions, and they didn't stop for hours, and they didn't even think about supper. The king and the old gentleman both had to tell their stories, and I seen that any man that wasn't dead or blind could see that the old gentleman was telling the truth and the king was lying. But they didn't seem to notice it. Then they called me up, and the king give me a look out of the corner of his eye, and I knowed what it meant. It meant I was to back up his story. So I begun to make up a lot of stuff about our life in Sheffield and about the English Wilks family. I hadn't got very far when the doctor begun to laugh. Then Levi Bell, the lawyer, he says, "Hold on, Huck; you're getting to be a good liar, but you ain't there yet. You need more practice." I didn't like the sound of that compliment, but I was glad to be let off.

You think you're helping this man, but you're just playing into his hands. He's a fraud, a con man, and you're letting him use you for his own gain. You've got to wake up before it's too late!' I stood there, stunned, not knowing what to say. I had trusted the doctor, and now he was turning on me. I looked over at the man he was talking about—Pap—and I saw the sneer on his face. He was enjoying this, watching me get chewed out. I felt like a fool, and I didn't know what to do. I wanted to defend Pap, but something in the doctor's words made me hesitate. I had seen Pap's tricks before, and I had always told myself he was just a drunk, but maybe there was more to it. Maybe the doctor was right. I didn't know who to believe anymore. I looked down at my hands, feeling the weight of the whole situation. I had been trying to do the right thing, but now I wasn't sure what the right thing was. I had always trusted my gut, but now my gut was telling me one thing and my head was telling me another. I was confused, and I didn't like it. I wanted to run, to get away from it all, but I knew I couldn't. I had to face this, no matter how hard it was. I had to figure out who I was and what I believed in, even if it meant going against everything I had ever known.

events.title: The Handwriting Test Exposes Frauds but Adds Complexity
detailed_summary: As Doctor Robinson begins to speak, the king interrupts him to warmly greet Levi Bell, claiming that his deceased brother Peter often wrote about Bell.
The lawyer and the king shake hands and converse for a while, eventually stepping aside for a private discussion.
Following their conversation, the lawyer announces a plan involving an order that he will send, which should resolve the matter.
The king then sits down and, with some effort, scrawls something on a piece of paper.
When the pen is handed to the duke, he appears visibly ill for the first time but proceeds to write.
The lawyer then requests the newly arrived old gentleman (Harvey Wilks) and his brother (William Wilks) to write a line or two and sign their names.
The old gentleman writes, but his script is illegible to everyone.
The lawyer, looking very surprised, retrieves old letters from his pocket, purportedly from Harvey Wilks, and compares the handwriting.
He declares that the handwriting in the old letters does not match that of the king, the duke, or the new old gentleman, pointing out the king and duke's dismay at being caught.
He further comments that the new old gentleman's marks are not proper writing at all.
The new old gentleman explains that his mute brother William is the one who copies his letters, so the handwriting on the old documents is William's.
The lawyer, noting he also has letters from William, asks William to write, but Harvey explains William cannot write with his injured right hand and uses his left.
Harvey asks the lawyer to compare both sets of old letters, stating they are by the same hand (William's).

After examining them, the lawyer concedes a strong resemblance, admitting his current line of proof is partly foiled, but firmly reiterates that the king and duke are definitely not the Wilks brothers.

events.text_segment:
The doctor he started to say something, and turns and says:
“If you’d been in town at first, Levi Bell—” The king broke in and reached out his hand, and says:
“Why, is this my poor dead brother’s old friend that he’s wrote so often about?”
The lawyer and him shook hands, and the lawyer smiled and looked pleased, and they talked right along awhile, and then got to one side and talked low; and at last the lawyer speaks up and says:
“That’ll fix it. I’ll take the order and send it, along with your brother’s, and then they’ll know it’s all right.”
So they got some paper and a pen, and the king he set down and twisted his head to one side, and chawed his tongue, and scrawled off something; and then they give the pen to the duke—and then for the first time the duke looked sick. But he took the pen and wrote. So then the lawyer turns to the new old gentleman and says:
“You and your brother please write a line or two and sign your names.”
The old gentleman wrote, but nobody couldn’t read it. The lawyer looked powerful astonished, and says:
“Well, it beats me”—and snaked a lot of old letters out of his pocket, and examined them, and then examined the old man’s writing, and then them again; and then says: “These old letters is from Harvey Wilks; and here’s these two handwritings, and anybody can see they didn’t write them” (the king and the duke looked sold and foolish, I tell you, to see how the lawyer had took them in), “and here’s this old gentleman’s hand writing, and anybody can tell, easy enough, he didn’t write them—fact is, the scratches he makes ain’t properly writing at all. Now, here’s some letters from—”
The new old gentleman says:
“If you please, let me explain. Nobody can read my hand but my brother there—so he copies for me. It’s his hand you’ve got there, not mine.”
“Well!” says the lawyer, “this is a state of things. I’ve got some of William’s letters, too; so if you’ll get him to write a line or so we can com—”
“He can’t write with his left hand,” says the old gentleman. “If he could use his right hand, you would see that he wrote his own letters and mine too. Look at both, please—they’re by the same hand.”
The lawyer done it, and says:
“I believe it’s so—and if it ain’t so, there’s a heap stronger resemblance than I’d noticed before, anyway. Well, well, well! I thought we was right on the track of a solution, but it’s gone to grass, partly. But anyway, one thing is proved—these two ain’t either of ’em Wilkses”—and he wagged his head towards the king and the duke.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
The doctor he started to say something, and turns and says: 'Gentlemen, I have something to say—' but before he could get further, the king cuts in, and says, with a kind of hearty, confidential air, 'Levi Bell, I've heard of you, stranger. My brother Peter used to write about you, and say you was the best hand at a lawsuit in the country.'

Levi Bell looked surprised, and said he was flattered. The king shook hands with him, and they talked a little, and then walked off a little way, and had a private talk. When they came back, the king looked more composed, and the lawyer looked more business-like. The lawyer said, 'I'll send an order, and that'll fix it.'

Then the king sat down, and with a good deal of trouble, wrote a few words on a piece of paper. Then the pen was passed to the duke, and he looked sick for the first time, but he wrote. Then the lawyer called for the new old gentleman and his brother, and said, 'Now, you two, write a line or two, and sign your names.'

The new old gentleman wrote, but his hand was so shaky and his writing so crooked and so full of blots, that nobody could read it. The lawyer looked surprised, and took out some old letters from his pocket, and said, 'These are from you, are they not?' and he compared the handwriting. He said, 'This is not the king's hand, nor the duke's, nor the new old gentleman's. The king and the duke looked uneasy, and the new old gentleman looked as if he was going to cry.

The lawyer said, 'Your marks are not writing at all.' The new old gentleman said, 'My brother William writes for me, sir. I can't write myself.' The lawyer said, 'I have letters from William, too. Let him write, then.' The new old gentleman said, 'He can't write with his right hand, it's broke, and he writes with his left.'

The lawyer said, 'Then let me compare the old letters with the new ones.' The new old gentleman said, 'They are all by the same hand, sir.' The lawyer looked at them, and said, 'There is a strong resemblance, I must allow. But I have got the king and the duke out of this, and I shall stick to that.'

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
The doctor he started to say something, and turns and says: "I reckon we better get back to the house. It's getting late, and there's a storm coming." He looked out the window, where the sky had turned a deep shade of gray, and the wind was beginning to howl through the trees. I could see the branches bending and swaying, and the leaves were flying through the air like they were trying to escape the coming storm.

We walked back to the house in silence, the only sound being the wind and the occasional creak of the trees. The doctor was a tall, thin man with a long face and a serious look in his eyes. He had a kind of quiet authority about him, and I could tell that he was used to being obeyed. I followed him closely, not wanting to be left behind in the storm.

When we got back to the house, the doctor went straight to the kitchen and started making tea. He said it would help calm my nerves. I sat down at the table and watched him work. He was very methodical, measuring out the tea leaves and pouring the hot water with great care. I could see the steam rising from the cup, and the smell of the tea was comforting.

After a few minutes, the doctor sat down across from me and said, "Now, let's talk about what happened out there. I need to know the whole story." I hesitated for a moment, not sure if I wanted to tell him everything. But I could see the concern in his eyes, and I knew he was trying to help me.

So I told him about the storm that had been coming all day, and how I had been trying to get back to the house before it got too bad. I told him about the tree that had fallen across the path, and how I had to climb over it. I told him about the strange noises I had heard in the woods, and how I had felt like I was being watched.

The doctor listened carefully, nodding his head as I spoke. When I finished, he sat back in his chair and said, "Well, I think you've had a bit of a scare, but I don't think there's anything to worry about. You're safe now, and that's what matters."

I nodded, feeling a bit better now that I had told someone what had happened. The storm outside was still raging, but inside the house, it felt like the world had gone quiet. The doctor handed me the cup of tea, and I took a sip, feeling the warmth spread through my body.

As the night wore on, the storm continued to howl outside, but inside, the doctor and I sat in comfortable silence, the tea growing cold between us.

events.title: The Tattoo Controversy Deepens the Mystery
detailed_summary: Despite the evidence from the handwriting test, the king refuses to concede defeat, dismissing the test as unfair.
He claims his supposed brother William was merely playing a joke and hadn't genuinely tried to write.
The king passionately continues his defense, almost convincing himself of his own fabrications.
The real Harvey Wilks interrupts with a new idea for verification.
He asks if anyone present assisted in preparing the late Peter Wilks's body for burial.
Two men, one named Ab Turner, confirm their involvement.
Harvey Wilks then directly challenges the king to describe what, if anything, was tattooed on Peter Wilks's breast.
The king is visibly taken aback but quickly recovers, claiming Peter Wilks had a small, thin, blue arrow tattooed on his breast, so faint it was hard to see.
Huck is inwardly astonished by the king's sheer audacity.
The real Harvey, believing he has trapped the king, turns to Ab Turner and his companion, asking if they observed such a mark.
Both men firmly state they did not see any arrow tattoo.
Harvey Wilks then declares that the actual tattoo was a small, dim 'P-B-W' with dashes in between, sketching it on paper.
He asks the two men if this was the mark they saw.
However, both Ab Turner and his partner again deny this, stating they saw no marks whatsoever on Peter Wilks's breast.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Well, what do you think?
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: No, we	didn’t. We never seen any marks at all.”

events.text_segment:
Well, what do you think? That muleheaded old fool wouldn’t give in then! Indeed he wouldn’t. Said it warn’t no fair test. Said his brother William was the cussedest joker in the world, and hadn’t tried to write—he see William was going to play one of his jokes the minute he put the pen to paper. And so he warmed up and went warbling and warbling right along till he was actuly beginning to believe what he was saying himself; but pretty soon the new gentleman broke in, and says:
“I’ve thought of something. Is there anybody here that helped to lay out my br—helped to lay out the late Peter Wilks for burying?”
“Yes,” says somebody, “me and Ab Turner done it. We’re both here.”
Then the old man turns towards the king, and says:
“Perhaps this gentleman can tell me what was tattooed on his breast?”
Blamed if the king didn’t have to brace up mighty quick, or he’d a squshed down like a bluff bank that the river has cut under, it took him so sudden; and, mind you, it was a thing that was calculated to make most anybody sqush to get fetched such a solid one as that without any notice, because how was he going to know what was tattooed on the man? He whitened a little; he couldn’t help it; and it was mighty still in there, and everybody bending a little forwards and gazing at him. Says I to myself, Now he’ll throw up the sponge—there ain’t no more use. Well, did he? A body can’t hardly believe it, but he didn’t. I reckon he thought he’d keep the thing up till he tired them people out, so they’d thin out, and him and the duke could break loose and get away. Anyway, he set there, and pretty soon he begun to smile, and says:
“Mf! It’s a very tough question, ain’t it! Yes, sir, I k’n tell you what’s tattooed on his breast. It’s jest a small, thin, blue arrow—that’s what it is; and if you don’t look clost, you can’t see it. Now what do you say—hey?”
Well, I never see anything like that old blister for clean out-and-out cheek.
The new old gentleman turns brisk towards Ab Turner and his pard, and his eye lights up like he judged he’d got the king this time, and says:
“There—you’ve heard what he said! Was there any such mark on Peter Wilks’ breast?”
Both of them spoke up and says:
“We didn’t see no such mark.”
“Good!” says the old gentleman. “Now, what you did see on his breast was a small dim P, and a B (which is an initial he dropped when he was young), and a W, with dashes between them, so: P—B—W”—and he marked them that way on a piece of paper. “Come, ain’t that what you saw?”
Both of them spoke up again, and says:
“No, we didn’t. We never seen any marks at all.”

events.title: Decision to Exhume the Body
detailed_summary: The contradictory testimonies regarding the tattoo leave the crowd utterly confused and agitated.
Many begin to shout that all the claimants are frauds and call for violent retribution, such as ducking, drowning, or riding them on a rail.
Amidst the uproar, the lawyer, Levi Bell, jumps onto a table, yelling to gain the crowd's attention and pleading for a moment to speak.
He proposes one final method to resolve the matter: exhuming Peter Wilks's corpse to directly examine it for any identifying marks.
This suggestion immediately captures the crowd's approval, and they shout their agreement, ready to proceed at once.
The lawyer and Doctor Robinson interject, instructing the crowd to detain all four men—the king, the duke, and the two real Wilks brothers—as well as Huck, and bring them to the graveyard.
The crowd enthusiastically agrees, vowing to lynch the entire group if the specified marks are not found on the body.
Huck admits to being deeply frightened by this dangerous turn of events.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Well, everybody	was	in a state of mind now, and they sings out:
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: I	was	scared, now, I tell you.

events.text_segment:
Well, everybody was in a state of mind now, and they sings out:
“The whole bilin’ of ’m ’s frauds! Le’s duck ’em! le’s drown ’em! le’s ride ’em on a rail!” and everybody was whooping at once, and there was a rattling powwow. But the lawyer he jumps on the table and yells, and says:
“Gentlemen—gentlemen! Hear me just a word—just a single word—if you PLEASE! There’s one way yet—let’s go and dig up the corpse and look.”
That took them.
“Hooray!” they all shouted, and was starting right off; but the lawyer and the doctor sung out:
“Hold on, hold on! Collar all these four men and the boy, and fetch them along, too!”
“We’ll do it!” they all shouted; “and if we don’t find them marks we’ll lynch the whole gang!”
I was scared, now, I tell you.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: Well, everybody was in a state of mind now, and they sings out: “They’re all frauds! They’re all imposters! They ain’t no Wilkses at all!” And they begin to howl for justice, and some of them say they want to duck the king and the duke, and others say they want to ride them on a rail, and some say they want to drown them. It was a regular row, and getting hotter every minute. The lawyer, Levi Bell, jumps up on a table and yells out, “Hold on, hold on! Don’t do nothing rash! Let me speak a minute!” The crowd quiets down a little, and he says, “We’ve got to get to the bottom of this. There’s only one way—dig up old Peter Wilks and see what marks he had on him!” The crowd goes wild at that. They all shout, “Yes! Yes! That’s the way!” and they begin to rush off to get shovels and torches. Then the lawyer and Doctor Robinson step in and say, “Wait a minute! You don’t want to be making no mistakes. You bring all four of these men along—these two here, and the king and the duke—and the boy too, and take ’em to the graveyard. And if Peter Wilks ain’t got them marks on him, why, you do what you like with ’em!” The crowd says, “Yes, sir! We will!” and they grab hold of us and start dragging us off. I was scared to death, I tell you, and I didn’t know what to do.

They was shouting and hugging and crying, and it was the noisiest time I ever was at. Tom Sawyer had the money in his hand, and he was the proudest boy you ever see. He was all over glory, and he couldn't hardly stand up straight he was so full of it. I was kind of sorry for him, because I knowed it was all a mistake, but I didn't say nothing. I just stood there and watched them all go crazy, and I reckoned it was the end of the whole business.

events.title: The Stormy Exhumation, Gold's Discovery, and Huck's Escape
detailed_summary: Huck recognizes the impossibility of escape as the group is marched towards the graveyard, located a mile and a half downriver, with the entire town following.
Passing the house where he stayed, Huck wistfully wishes Mary Jane were present, believing she could help him escape and expose the fraudulent king and duke.
The journey to the graveyard is tense; the sky darkens ominously, lightning begins to flash, and the wind rustles through the leaves, creating a frightening atmosphere.
Huck feels more terrified and in greater danger than ever before, as his fate now seems to depend entirely on the presence or absence of the tattoo marks.
Hines, the man who identified Huck earlier, keeps a firm grip on Huck's wrist, making escape seem impossible.
Upon arriving at the graveyard, the crowd swarms in, possessing an abundance of shovels but having forgotten to bring a lantern.
They begin digging by the sporadic illumination of lightning flashes while a man is sent to a nearby house to borrow a lantern.
The digging continues with fervent intensity, oblivious to the worsening storm, which now includes heavy rain, strong winds, and booming thunder.
The scene alternates between brief, vivid illumination by lightning and complete darkness.
At last, the coffin is unearthed, and the lid is unscrewed, prompting a chaotic rush as people push to get a view of the body in the dark.
Suddenly, a powerful flash of lightning reveals the scene, and someone exclaims that the bag of gold is on the deceased's breast.
In the ensuing commotion and excitement, Hines shouts along with everyone else, drops Huck's wrist, and surges forward to see, allowing Huck to seize the moment and flee unseen into the darkness.

segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Hines let out a whoop, like everybody else, and dropped my wrist and give a big surge to bust his way in and get a look, and the way I lit out and shinned for the road in the dark there ain’t nobody can tell.

events.text_segment:
But there warn’t no getting away, you know. They gripped us all, and marched us right along, straight for the graveyard, which was a mile and a half down the river, and the whole town at our heels, for we made noise enough, and it was only nine in the evening.
As we went by our house I wished I hadn’t sent Mary Jane out of town; because now if I could tip her the wink she’d light out and save me, and blow on our dead-beats.
Well, we swarmed along down the river road, just carrying on like wildcats; and to make it more scary the sky was darking up, and the lightning beginning to wink and flitter, and the wind to shiver amongst the leaves. This was the most awful trouble and most dangersome I ever was in; and I was kinder stunned; everything was going so different from what I had allowed for; stead of being fixed so I could take my own time if I wanted to, and see all the fun, and have Mary Jane at my back to save me and set me free when the close-fit come, here was nothing in the world betwixt me and sudden death but just them tattoo-marks. If they didn’t find them—
I couldn’t bear to think about it; and yet, somehow, I couldn’t think about nothing else. It got darker and darker, and it was a beautiful time to give the crowd the slip; but that big husky had me by the wrist—Hines—and a body might as well try to give Goliar the slip. He dragged me right along, he was so excited, and I had to run to keep up.
When they got there they swarmed into the graveyard and washed over it like an overflow. And when they got to the grave they found they had about a hundred times as many shovels as they wanted, but nobody hadn’t thought to fetch a lantern. But they sailed into digging anyway by the flicker of the lightning, and sent a man to the nearest house, a half a mile off, to borrow one.
So they dug and dug like everything; and it got awful dark, and the rain started, and the wind swished and swushed along, and the lightning come brisker and brisker, and the thunder boomed; but them people never took no notice of it, they was so full of this business; and one minute you could see everything and every face in that big crowd, and the shovelfuls of dirt sailing up out of the grave, and the next second the dark wiped it all out, and you couldn’t see nothing at all.
At last they got out the coffin and begun to unscrew the lid, and then such another crowding and shouldering and shoving as there was, to scrouge in and get a sight, you never see; and in the dark, that way, it was awful. Hines he hurt my wrist dreadful pulling and tugging so, and I reckon he clean forgot I was in the world, he was so excited and panting.
All of a sudden the lightning let go a perfect sluice of white glare, and somebody sings out:
“By the living jingo, here’s the bag of gold on his breast!”
Hines let out a whoop, like everybody else, and dropped my wrist and give a big surge to bust his way in and get a look, and the way I lit out and shinned for the road in the dark there ain’t nobody can tell.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: But there warn’t no getting away, you know. We was marched along, the King and the Duke and the rest of the gang, and the whole town after us, a mile and a half down to the graveyard. I felt like a stuck pig. We passed the house where I had stayed, and I reckoned if Mary Jane had been there she would have raised hell and got me out, and showed up the whole business. But she warn’t there, and I was in the hands of the Injuns. The sky was getting dark, and the wind was a-blowing, and the leaves was a-rustling, and it was getting to be a kind of a spooky time. I was scared to death, and I didn’t know what was going to happen. My fate was in the hands of them tattoo marks, and I didn’t know whether I had ’em or not. Hines, the man that had picked me out, had hold of my wrist like a vise, and I couldn’t budge. When we got to the graveyard, the crowd swarmed in, and they had a lot of shovels, but they hadn’t thought to bring a lantern. So they begun to dig by the light of the lightning, and a man was sent to a house to borrow one. The rain come down, and the wind got up, and the thunder rolled, and the lightning flashed, and it was getting to be a regular circus. They dug and dug, and the lightning would flash now and then and show the men all black and white, and then it would go out again and leave them in the dark. At last they struck the coffin, and they unscrewed the lid, and there was a rush for the front, and the people was all squawking and yelling, and trying to see who it was. Then a big flash come, and a man shouted, “Here’s the bag of gold!” and the whole crowd went wild. Hines let go of my wrist and jumped in with the rest, and I made my break and lit out into the dark, and was gone before they knew it.

simple_agent_extraction_refined_0.text: But there warn’t no getting away, you know. We was marched along, the King and the Duke and the rest of the gang, and the whole town after us, a mile and a half down to the graveyard. I felt like a stuck pig. We passed the house where I had stayed, and I reckoned if Mary Jane had been there she would have raised hell and got me out, and showed up the whole business. But she warn’t there, and I was in the hands of the Injuns. The sky was getting dark, and the wind was a-blowing, and the leaves was a-rustling, and it was getting to be a kind of a spooky time. I was scared to death, and I didn’t know what was going to happen. My fate was in the hands of them tattoo marks, and I didn’t know whether I had ’em or not. Hines, the man that had picked me out, had hold of my wrist like a vise, and I couldn’t budge. When we got to the graveyard, the crowd swarmed in, and they had a lot of shovels, but they hadn’t thought to bring a lantern. So they begun to dig by the light of the lightning, and a man was sent to a house to borrow one. The rain come down, and the wind got up, and the thunder rolled, and the lightning flashed, and it was getting to be a regular circus. They dug and dug, and the lightning would flash now and then and show the men all black and white, and then it would go out again and leave them in the dark. At last they struck the coffin, and they unscrewed the lid, and there was a rush for the front, and the people was all squawking and yelling, and trying to see who it was. Then a big flash come, and a man shouted, “Here’s the bag of gold!” and the whole crowd went wild. Hines let go of my wrist and jumped in with the rest, and I made my break and lit out into the dark, and was gone before they knew it.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: But there warn’t no getting away, you know. I had to stay with Pap, and I didn’t like it none. He was always drunk, and when he wasn’t drunk he was mean. I didn’t have no friends, and I didn’t have no place to go. I was just a prisoner in that cabin on the river, and I didn’t like it none. I used to dream about running away, but I didn’t see how I could do it. I didn’t have no money, and I didn’t have no clothes fit to go in. I was just a poor, lonesome boy, and I didn’t know what to do. But one day I saw a steamboat come up the river, and I thought maybe I could get on it and go somewhere else. I didn’t know where I was going, but I didn’t care. I just wanted to get away from Pap and that cabin and that lonesome life. So I started to plan. I had to get out of the cabin without Pap seeing me, and I had to get to the river without being caught. It was a hard thing to do, but I was determined. I waited until night, when Pap was drunk and snoring, and then I slipped out of the cabin and made my way to the river. I didn’t have no boat, but I saw a raft that had been left there, and I thought maybe I could use that. I didn’t know how to build a raft, but I had seen men do it before, and I thought I could do it too. So I started to work. I got some logs and some rope and started to build my raft. It was hard work, but I didn’t mind. I was too busy thinking about getting away to feel tired. When the raft was ready, I got on it and started to float down the river. I didn’t know where I was going, but I didn’t care. I just wanted to get away from Pap and that lonesome life. I had been on the raft for a while when I saw a boy come down the river. He was dressed in fine clothes, and he looked like he had money. I didn’t know who he was, but I thought maybe he could help me. So I called out to him, and he came over to the raft. He introduced himself as Tom Sawyer, and he said he had heard about me and wanted to see if I was the same Huck Finn he had heard about. I didn’t know what to say, but I was glad to see him. He was a good friend, and he helped me a lot. He told me about his plans to run away and have adventures, and I thought maybe I could go with him. But I didn’t know if I should. I had been on the raft for a while, and I had started to get used to it. I didn’t know if I wanted to go back to town and be with people again. But Tom was persuasive, and he talked me into going with him. So we started to plan our adventures. We talked about how we could run away and have a good time, and I thought maybe that was what I needed. I had been lonesome for so long, and I thought maybe having a friend would help. So I agreed to go with Tom, and we started to make our plans. We talked about how we could get money and clothes and food, and I thought maybe we could have a good time. But I didn’t know what was going to happen. I just knew that I didn’t want to go back to that cabin and that lonesome life. So I stayed with Tom and we started to plan our adventures. I didn’t know what was going to happen, but I didn’t care. I just wanted to get away from Pap and that lonesome life.

events.title: Huck's Daring Escape and Bittersweet Reunion with Jim
detailed_summary: Huck flees rapidly along the road, finding it deserted due to the severe storm.
He runs straight through the main street of the town rather than seeking back alleys.
As he approaches the house where he had been staying, he looks for a light but sees none, feeling a sense of disappointment.
Just as he is passing, a light suddenly appears in Mary Jane's window, causing his heart to swell with emotion.
He reflects that Mary Jane was the best and most courageous girl he had ever met, realizing he will likely never see her again.
Once he is far enough from town to spot the tow-head, he begins looking for a boat.
The first unchained canoe he sees in a lightning flash, he quickly commandeers, pushing off into the river.
Despite the considerable distance to the tow-head in the middle of the river, he paddles with all his might.
Upon finally reaching the raft, utterly exhausted, he calls out to Jim to set her loose, exclaiming their freedom from their pursuers.

Jim, filled with joy, comes towards Huck with open arms, but Huck is momentarily terrified by Jim's appearance, having forgotten Jim was still dressed in his 'King Lear' and 'drownded A-rab' costume from their earlier charades.
After Jim fishes him out of the water (as he'd stepped back in fright), Huck, despite Jim's desire to celebrate, urgently tells him to cut the raft loose immediately.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: I had the road all to myself, and I fairly flew—leastways, I had it all to myself except the solid dark, and the now-and-then glares, and the buzzing of the rain, and the thrashing of the wind, and the splitting of the thunder; and sure as you are born I did clip it along!
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Cut loose and let her slide!”

events.text_segment:
I had the road all to myself, and I fairly flew—leastways, I had it all to myself except the solid dark, and the now-and-then glares, and the buzzing of the rain, and the thrashing of the wind, and the splitting of the thunder; and sure as you are born I did clip it along!
When I struck the town I see there warn’t nobody out in the storm, so I never hunted for no back streets, but humped it straight through the main one; and when I begun to get towards our house I aimed my eye and set it. No light there; the house all dark—which made me feel sorry and disappointed, I didn’t know why. But at last, just as I was sailing by, flash comes the light in Mary Jane’s window! and my heart swelled up sudden, like to bust; and the same second the house and all was behind me in the dark, and wasn’t ever going to be before me no more in this world. She was the best girl I ever see, and had the most sand.
The minute I was far enough above the town to see I could make the tow-head, I begun to look sharp for a boat to borrow, and the first time the lightning showed me one that wasn’t chained I snatched it and shoved. It was a canoe, and warn’t fastened with nothing but a rope. The tow-head was a rattling big distance off, away out there in the middle of the river, but I didn’t lose no time; and when I struck the raft at last I was so fagged I would a just laid down to blow and gasp if I could afforded it. But I didn’t. As I sprung aboard I sung out:
“Out with you, Jim, and set her loose! Glory be to goodness, we’re shut of them!”
Jim lit out, and was a-coming for me with both arms spread, he was so full of joy; but when I glimpsed him in the lightning my heart shot up in my mouth and I went overboard backwards; for I forgot he was old King Lear and a drownded A-rab all in one, and it most scared the livers and lights out of me. But Jim fished me out, and was going to hug me and bless me, and so on, he was so glad I was back and we was shut of the king and the duke, but I says:
“Not now; have it for breakfast, have it for breakfast! Cut loose and let her slide!”

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: I had the road all to myself, and I fairly flew—leastways, I had it all to myself except the solid dark, and the now-and-then glares, and the buzzing of the rain, and the thrashing of the wind, and the splitting of the thunder; and sure as you are born I did clip it along! The storm was a wild one, and it made the night seem alive with noise and fury. I didn't mind it none, though. I was in a hurry, and the storm was like a good companion, keeping me company and helping to cover my tracks. I didn't want no one to see me or hear me, and the storm was just the thing for that. I was on my way to meet Tom Sawyer, and I was determined to get there before the appointed time. Tom had promised to help me with a plan that was mighty important to me, and I couldn't afford to be late. I had been thinking about it all day, and I was getting more and more excited as the time drew near. I had a feeling that something big was going to happen, and I was ready for it. I had my bundle of clothes and a few other things tied up in a cloth, and I was carrying it on my back. I didn't have much, but I had enough. I had left my home behind me, and I didn't look back. I was free, and I was going to stay that way. I had made up my mind to run off and never come back, and I was going to stick to it. I had heard of other boys who had run away before, and I had always envied them. Now I was one of them, and I felt like a king. I didn't care about the storm or the dark or anything else. I was going to have my adventure, and I was going to enjoy it. I had heard of pirates and robbers and all sorts of exciting things, and I was going to be one of them. I was going to have a real adventure, and I was going to make my name known. I was going to be a hero, and I was going to be remembered. I was going to do something that no one else had ever done before, and I was going to do it alone. I was going to be my own master, and I was going to be free. I was going to be a man, and I was going to be a legend.

events.title: Brief Freedom Shattered: The Return of the King and Duke
detailed_summary: Within moments, Huck and Jim are drifting down the river, and Huck feels an immense sense of relief and joy at being free and alone on the water again.
He is so exhilarated that he skips around and cracks his heels a few times in celebration.
However, around the third heel-crack, he detects a familiar sound that makes him pause and listen intently.
The next flash of lightning dramatically reveals the king and the duke in their skiff, rowing vigorously and rapidly closing in on the raft.
Huck's elation instantly vanishes, replaced by profound despair, and he collapses onto the planks of the raft, struggling to hold back tears.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: So in two seconds away we went a-sliding down the river, and it	did	seem so good to be free again and all by ourselves on the big river, and nobody to bother us.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: So I wilted right down on to the planks then, and give up; and it was all I could do to keep from crying.

events.text_segment:
So in two seconds away we went a-sliding down the river, and it did seem so good to be free again and all by ourselves on the big river, and nobody to bother us. I had to skip around a bit, and jump up and crack my heels a few times—I couldn’t help it; but about the third crack I noticed a sound that I knowed mighty well, and held my breath and listened and waited; and sure enough, when the next flash busted out over the water, here they come!—and just a-laying to their oars and making their skiff hum! It was the king and the duke.
So I wilted right down on to the planks then, and give up; and it was all I could do to keep from crying.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: So in two seconds away we went a-sliding down the river, and it did seem so good to be free again and all by ourselves on the big river, and nobody to bother us. I was so glad I could hardly wait to get to the middle of the river and then I would skip around and crack my heels and laugh out loud. I was feeling so light and free and happy I didn't know what to do with myself. But just as I was getting ready to crack my heels the third time, I heard a sound that made me stop and listen. It was the sound of oars, and pretty soon the lightning flashed and showed me the king and the duke in their skiff, rowing like fury and coming right after us. My heart went cold and I felt like I was going to die. I dropped down on the planks and tried to hold back my tears, but I couldn't help it.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: So in two seconds away we went a-sliding down the river, and it did seem so good to be free again and all by ourselves on the big river, and nobody to bother us. We had the sky up there, and we had the river under us, and we had the raft between us, and we had each other. It was like we were the only two people in the whole world, and everything else was just a dream. We didn’t talk much, but we didn’t need to. We knew what the other was thinking, and that was enough. The river was our friend, and it was taking us where we wanted to go—away from trouble, away from lies, and toward freedom.

events.title: Huck's Tense Explanation and the Duke's Intervention
detailed_summary: Upon boarding the raft, the King physically confronts Huck, accusing him of attempting to abandon them.
Huck, feigning distress, fabricates a story about his escape, explaining that during the commotion over the discovered gold, a sympathetic man warned him to flee to avoid being hanged.
Huck claims this man was reminded of his own deceased son, who was about Huck's age, and felt sorry for Huck's predicament.
He further states that he quickly ran to the canoe, instructed Jim to hurry, and expressed his fear that the King and Duke might not be alive, professing his sorrow.
Jim supports Huck's account, but the King silences Jim and, expressing disbelief, threatens to drown Huck.
The Duke intervenes, ordering the King to release Huck and challenging the King by asking if he would have acted differently or if he had made any effort to find Huck after his own escape.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: When they got aboard the king went for me, and shook me by the collar, and says:
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: I don’t remember it.”

events.text_segment:
When they got aboard the king went for me, and shook me by the collar, and says:
“Tryin’ to give us the slip, was ye, you pup! Tired of our company, hey?”
I says:
“No, your majesty, we warn’t—please don’t, your majesty!”
“Quick, then, and tell us what was your idea, or I’ll shake the insides out o’ you!”
“Honest, I’ll tell you everything just as it happened, your majesty. The man that had a-holt of me was very good to me, and kept saying he had a boy about as big as me that died last year, and he was sorry to see a boy in such a dangerous fix; and when they was all took by surprise by finding the gold, and made a rush for the coffin, he lets go of me and whispers, ‘Heel it now, or they’ll hang ye, sure!’ and I lit out. It didn’t seem no good for me to stay—I couldn’t do nothing, and I didn’t want to be hung if I could get away. So I never stopped running till I found the canoe; and when I got here I told Jim to hurry, or they’d catch me and hang me yet, and said I was afeard you and the duke wasn’t alive now, and I was awful sorry, and so was Jim, and was awful glad when we see you coming; you may ask Jim if I didn’t.”
Jim said it was so; and the king told him to shut up, and said, “Oh, yes, it’s mighty likely!” and shook me up again, and said he reckoned he’d drownd me. But the duke says:
“Leggo the boy, you old idiot! Would you a done any different? Did you inquire around for him when you got loose? I don’t remember it.”

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
When they got aboard the king went for me, and shook me by the collar, and says: "Where is the money?" I says, "I don't know, I didn't have no money." He says, "You did, you did. You had it all the time. You've been trying to run off with it." I says, "No, I ain't. I didn't know nothing about it. I was scared to death, and I run off because I thought you was going to be hanged, and I didn't want to see it."

He let me go and stood there looking at me, and then he says, "You run off and left us in the lurch, and you think I'm going to believe that?" I says, "I didn't know nothing about the money, honest I didn't. It was a man that was in the house when the robbers come, and he saw me, and he says, 'You better run, or they'll hang you.' He says, 'I had a son about your age, and I can't see you get hung.' So I run, and I told Jim to come, and I was scared to death, and I thought you was dead, and I was sorry."

Jim says, "It's true, your majesty, it's true. He didn't know nothing about the money."

The king says, "You shut up, you nigger. I'll fix this boy. I'll drown him."

The duke says, "Now, now, don't be too hard on the boy. He's been through a good deal. If I was in his place, I don't know what I would do. And besides, you didn't go looking for him, did you? You just stayed here and waited for him to come back, and you didn't do nothing to find him."

The king looked kind of abashed, and he didn't say nothing for a minute, and then he turned to me and says, "Well, I'll not drown you, but I'll give you something else to remember this by."

And with that, he struck me a blow on the side of the head that made me see stars, and I went down on the raft, and the duke says, "Now, now, that's enough."

And so it was, and I laid there for a minute, and then I got up and said I was all right, and we went on down the river, and the king and the duke had a talk, and they said they would not mention the money no more, and that I was to go on pretending to be the prince, and that was that.
