events.title: Aunt Sally's Outrage and Tom's Shocking News about Jim
detailed_summary: Aunt Sally, finally grasping the full extent of their escapade, expresses her utter astonishment and calls them "little rapscallions" for causing widespread panic and distress.
She vows to punish them severely once Tom has recovered his health.
Tom, however, is too proud and joyful to be subdued and continues to revel in their perceived success, even as Aunt Sally interjects with fiery exasperation.
Aunt Sally warns Tom that he should not meddle with "the runaway nigger" again.
Tom, looking surprised, asks whom she is referring to.
When Aunt Sally clarifies she means Jim, Tom turns to Huck with a grave expression, questioning why Huck hadn't told him Jim was alright and had gotten away.
Aunt Sally then informs Tom that Jim has indeed been recaptured, is currently confined to the cabin again, on a diet of bread and water, and heavily chained.

Upon hearing this, Tom sits bolt upright in bed, his eyes flashing and nostrils flaring, and passionately exclaims to Huck that they have no right to imprison Jim, because Jim is not a slave but as free as anyone.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “Well, I never heard the likes of it in all my born days! So it was you, you little rapscallions, that’s been making all this trouble, and turned everybody’s wits clean inside out and scared us all most to death.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Turn him loose! he ain’t no slave; he’s as free as any cretur that walks this earth!”

events.text_segment:
“Well, I never heard the likes of it in all my born days! So it was you, you little rapscallions, that’s been making all this trouble, and turned everybody’s wits clean inside out and scared us all most to death. I’ve as good a notion as ever I had in my life to take it out o’ you this very minute. To think, here I’ve been, night after night, a—you just get well once, you young scamp, and I lay I’ll tan the Old Harry out o’ both o’ ye!”
But Tom, he was so proud and joyful, he just couldn’t hold in, and his tongue just went it—she a-chipping in, and spitting fire all along, and both of them going it at once, like a cat convention; and she says:
“Well, you get all the enjoyment you can out of it now, for mind I tell you if I catch you meddling with him again—”
“Meddling with who?” Tom says, dropping his smile and looking surprised.
“With who? Why, the runaway nigger, of course. Who’d you reckon?”
Tom looks at me very grave, and says:
“Tom, didn’t you just tell me he was all right? Hasn’t he got away?”
“Him?” says Aunt Sally; “the runaway nigger? ’Deed he hasn’t. They’ve got him back, safe and sound, and he’s in that cabin again, on bread and water, and loaded down with chains, till he’s claimed or sold!”
Tom rose square up in bed, with his eye hot, and his nostrils opening and shutting like gills, and sings out to me:
“They hain’t no right to shut him up! Shove!—and don’t you lose a minute. Turn him loose! he ain’t no slave; he’s as free as any cretur that walks this earth!”

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: Well, I never heard the likes of it in all my born days! So it was you, you little rapscallions, that’s been making all this trouble, and turned everybody’s wits clean inside out and scared us all most to death. I’ve been afeared ever since the first of it happened that it was one of you, but I couldn’t be sure. But now I am, and I’ll fix you for it, Tom Sawyer, when you get well. You’ll never get out of my sight again, and you’ll never have another holiday as long as you live. And as for you, Huck Finn, I don’t know what to do with you. You’re a bad boy, and I always said so. But I never thought you’d be the kind to go and make such a row and get folks all in a sweat like this. And I hope you’re satisfied, too, Tom Sawyer, with the way you’ve gone and made a fool of yourself and scared the life out of your poor old aunt. And I hope you never meddle with that runaway nigger again, Tom Sawyer, if you love me. You just let him alone, and don’t you go and get into no more trouble with him, or I’ll—I’ll—I’ll do something to you that you won’t forget in a hurry. Tom looked surprised at this, and said, “Runaway nigger? What runaway nigger?” “Why, Jim,” said Aunt Sally. “Didn’t you know he was caught?” Tom sat up in bed, all the color gone out of his face, and said, “Caught? Jim caught?” “Yes,” said Aunt Sally, “and he’s in the cabin now, and they’re feeding him on bread and water, and he’s got chains on him, and they say he’s to be sold down the river.” Tom sat there a minute, and then he said, “Huck, I didn’t know Jim was caught. Why didn’t you tell me?” “I didn’t know,” said Huck. “I thought he was safe.” Tom looked at Huck a minute, and then he said, “Well, I don’t care if he is or not. He’s not a slave, and he’s as free as any man in the country.”

events.title: Jim's Legal Freedom Revealed and Aunt Polly's Surprise Arrival
detailed_summary: Aunt Sally, bewildered, asks what Tom means by his declaration of Jim's freedom.
Tom emphatically states that he means every word: Miss Watson passed away two months ago, and feeling remorseful for ever planning to sell Jim down the river, she had set him free in her will.

When Aunt Sally, still trying to process this, asks why on earth Tom would then go to all the trouble of orchestrating an escape for a man who was already free, Tom begins to explain that he wanted the adventure of it.
Before he can continue, Tom suddenly exclaims, "goodness alive, AUNT POLLY!"
Huck confirms that Aunt Polly is indeed standing right inside the doorway, looking unexpectedly pleasant and satisfied.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “What does the child mean?”
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: If she warn’t standing right there, just inside the door, looking as sweet and contented as an angel half full of pie, I wish I may never!

events.text_segment:
“What does the child mean?”
“I mean every word I say, Aunt Sally, and if somebody don’t go, I’ll go. I’ve knowed him all his life, and so has Tom, there. Old Miss Watson died two months ago, and she was ashamed she ever was going to sell him down the river, and said so; and she set him free in her will.”
“Then what on earth did you want to set him free for, seeing he was already free?”
“Well, that is a question, I must say; and just like women! Why, I wanted the adventure of it; and I’d a waded neck-deep in blood to—goodness alive, AUNT POLLY!”
If she warn’t standing right there, just inside the door, looking as sweet and contented as an angel half full of pie, I wish I may never!

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: What does the child mean?" said Aunt Sally, bewildered, and looking from Tom to me, and then back again. "You mean to say that Jim is free?" "I do," said Tom, "and I mean every word of it. Miss Watson died two months ago, and she was mighty sorry for ever thinking of selling Jim down the river, and so she set him free in her will." Aunt Sally just stood there, her hands to her temples, and her face all worked up. She said: "Well, I'm astonished! I'm confounded! I'm—" But Tom cut in. "It was the adventure, Aunt Sally," he said, "that I was after. It was the fun of it. It was the glory of it." Just then he gave a sudden jump, and cried out: "Goodness alive, Aunt Polly!" And sure enough, there was Aunt Polly in the doorway, looking uncommonly pleased and satisfied, and with a smile on her face that was like a secret.

“What does the child mean?”

The man looked puzzled, squinting at the little boy who had just spoken. The child, with a mix of innocence and mischief in his eyes, simply shrugged and said, “I don’t know. I just heard it on the street, and it sounded funny.” The man chuckled, shaking his head. “Well, you got a sharp ear for words, that’s for sure. But you best be careful what you say around here. Some folks take things the wrong way.” The child grinned, clearly enjoying the attention. “I just like to say things and see what happens.” The man sighed, “You got spirit, I’ll give you that. But spirit without sense can get you into trouble.” The child nodded, not quite understanding the warning, but happy to be part of the conversation.

events.title: Identities Unraveled and Complex Motivations Clarified
detailed_summary: Aunt Sally reacts with overwhelming joy, rushing to embrace Aunt Polly and crying.
Huck, sensing the escalating tension and potential for awkward revelations, decides to hide under the bed.
After a moment, Aunt Polly disengages from the hug and looks sternly across at Tom.
When Aunt Sally refers to the boy in bed as "Sid," Aunt Polly immediately corrects her, stating that it is Tom, and then asks for Huck Finn.
Huck reluctantly emerges from his hiding place.

Aunt Sally is depicted as utterly baffled, a state shared by Uncle Silas when he is later informed of all the events, leaving him so disoriented that he preaches an unintelligible sermon that evening.
Tom's Aunt Polly proceeds to explain Huck's true identity and his circumstances.
Huck then explains that when Aunt Sally mistook him for Tom Sawyer, he felt compelled to maintain the charade, knowing Tom would relish the mystery and adventure of the situation.
He adds that Tom subsequently pretended to be Sid to make things easier for Huck.
Aunt Polly confirms Tom's earlier statement that old Miss Watson had indeed freed Jim in her will.

This revelation brings a moment of clarity for Huck, who finally understands how Tom, given his upbringing, could have participated in freeing a slave: Tom knew Jim was already legally free, thus turning the entire elaborate escape into a risk-free adventure for himself.

segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: And his Aunt Polly she said Tom was right about old Miss Watson setting Jim free in her will; and so, sure enough, Tom Sawyer had gone and took all that trouble and bother to set a free nigger free! and I couldn’t ever understand before, until that minute and that talk, how he could help a body set a nigger free with his bringing-up.

events.text_segment:
Aunt Sally jumped for her, and most hugged the head off of her, and cried over her, and I found a good enough place for me under the bed, for it was getting pretty sultry for us, seemed to me. And I peeped out, and in a little while Tom’s Aunt Polly shook herself loose and stood there looking across at Tom over her spectacles—kind of grinding him into the earth, you know. And then she says:
“Yes, you better turn y’r head away—I would if I was you, Tom.”
“Oh, deary me!” says Aunt Sally; “is he changed so? Why, that ain’t Tom, it’s Sid; Tom’s—Tom’s—why, where is Tom? He was here a minute ago.”
“You mean where’s Huck Finn—that’s what you mean! I reckon I hain’t raised such a scamp as my Tom all these years not to know him when I see him. That would be a pretty howdy-do. Come out from under that bed, Huck Finn.”
So I done it. But not feeling brash.
Aunt Sally she was one of the mixed-upest-looking persons I ever see—except one, and that was Uncle Silas, when he come in and they told it all to him. It kind of made him drunk, as you may say, and he didn’t know nothing at all the rest of the day, and preached a prayer-meeting sermon that night that gave him a rattling ruputation, because the oldest man in the world couldn’t a understood it. So Tom’s Aunt Polly, she told all about who I was, and what; and I had to up and tell how I was in such a tight place that when Mrs. Phelps took me for Tom Sawyer—she chipped in and says, “Oh, go on and call me Aunt Sally, I’m used to it now, and ’tain’t no need to change”—that when Aunt Sally took me for Tom Sawyer I had to stand it—there warn’t no other way, and I knowed he wouldn’t mind, because it would be nuts for him, being a mystery, and he’d make an adventure out of it, and be perfectly satisfied. And so it turned out, and he let on to be Sid, and made things as soft as he could for me.
And his Aunt Polly she said Tom was right about old Miss Watson setting Jim free in her will; and so, sure enough, Tom Sawyer had gone and took all that trouble and bother to set a free nigger free! and I couldn’t ever understand before, until that minute and that talk, how he could help a body set a nigger free with his bringing-up.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: Aunt Sally jumped for her, and most hugged the head off of her, and cried over her, and I found a good enough place for me under the bed, for it was getting pretty sultry for us, seemed to me. After a little while Aunt Sally let go, and looked around, and then she see Tom, and she went for him too, and hugged him, and cried over him, and said she didn't know what to do with them both. Then she went for me, but I was under the bed, and she didn't see me. Aunt Polly looked kind of uneasy, and said, “That ain’t Sid, Sally; that’s Tom.” Then she called for Huck Finn. I didn’t want to come out, but I had to, so I did. Aunt Sally looked at me, and then at Aunt Polly, and then at Tom, and then at me again, and then she said, “Well, I’m afeared I’m getting to be a crazy old woman.” Then she went and told Uncle Silas all about it, and he said he didn’t know what to make of it, and he went and preached a kind of a crazy sermon that night, and the people didn’t know what he was talking about, and they said he had lost his mind. Aunt Polly told us all about it, and how Tom had been pretending to be Sid, and how I had been pretending to be Tom, and how we had both been pretending to be something we wasn’t, and how we had both been trying to get out of something we didn’t want to get into. And then she said Tom had told her that old Miss Watson had set Jim free in her will, and that was why Tom had gone along with the whole thing, because he knew Jim was free, and so it didn’t make no difference to him, and he could have the fun of it without any trouble.

events.title: The Mystery of the Intercepted Letters
detailed_summary: Aunt Polly explains her unexpected arrival, stating that when she received Aunt Sally's letter announcing that "Tom and Sid" had arrived safely, she became suspicious, especially since she couldn't get clear answers from "Sid" (Huck, who was intercepting her mail to him) about the situation.
Aunt Sally interjects that she never received any such earlier letters from Aunt Polly.
Aunt Polly clarifies that she wrote twice to Aunt Sally to inquire what she meant by "Sid" being there.
Aunt Sally reiterates that she never received those letters.
Aunt Polly then turns slowly and severely towards Tom, demanding he hand over the letters.
Tom, with some irritation, admits that the letters are in his trunk, unopened, explaining he had kept them because he anticipated they would cause trouble and thought there was no hurry.
Aunt Polly remarks that Tom certainly deserves a punishment for his actions.
She also mentions sending another letter to inform them of her impending arrival.
Aunt Sally confirms she received that particular letter the previous day but admits she has not yet read it.
Huck considers offering a wager that Aunt Sally hasn't truly got the letter but decides it's safer to remain silent.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Well, Aunt Polly she said that when Aunt Sally wrote to her that Tom and Sid had come all right and safe, she says to herself:
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: So I never said nothing.

events.text_segment:
Well, Aunt Polly she said that when Aunt Sally wrote to her that Tom and Sid had come all right and safe, she says to herself:
“Look at that, now! I might have expected it, letting him go off that way without anybody to watch him. So now I got to go and trapse all the way down the river, eleven hundred mile, and find out what that creetur’s up to this time; as long as I couldn’t seem to get any answer out of you about it.”
“Why, I never heard nothing from you,” says Aunt Sally.
“Well, I wonder! Why, I wrote you twice to ask you what you could mean by Sid being here.”
“Well, I never got ’em, Sis.”
Aunt Polly she turns around slow and severe, and says:
“You, Tom!”
“Well—what?” he says, kind of pettish.
“Don’t you what me, you impudent thing—hand out them letters.”
“What letters?”
“Them letters. I be bound, if I have to take aholt of you I’ll—”
“They’re in the trunk. There, now. And they’re just the same as they was when I got them out of the office. I hain’t looked into them, I hain’t touched them. But I knowed they’d make trouble, and I thought if you warn’t in no hurry, I’d—”
“Well, you do need skinning, there ain’t no mistake about it. And I wrote another one to tell you I was coming; and I s’pose he—”
“No, it come yesterday; I hain’t read it yet, but it’s all right, I’ve got that one.”
I wanted to offer to bet two dollars she hadn’t, but I reckoned maybe it was just as safe to not to. So I never said nothing.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
Well, Aunt Polly she said that when Aunt Sally wrote to her that Tom and Sid had come all right and safe, she says to herself: “That’s strange, for I wrote to Aunt Sally myself, and she never said a word about Tom and Sid being there. I must have made a mistake.” But the more she thought about it, the more it seemed queer. So she wrote again, and again, and again, and every time she got the same answer—that Tom and Sid had arrived safe and well. But she couldn’t get any clear account of what had become of Sid, for whenever she asked about him, the answer was always something like this: “Oh, he’s all right; he’s with Tom, and they’re having a fine time.”

At last Aunt Polly got so uneasy that she resolved to come herself and see what was going on. So she came, and when she got there, she said to Aunt Sally: “Now, Aunt Sally, I want to know the truth. I wrote to you three times, and you never answered me. I wrote to Sid, and he never answered me. I wrote to Tom, and he never answered me. I wrote to both of you, and you never answered me. I wrote to Tom and Sid, and they never answered me. I wrote to Tom, and he never answered me. I wrote to Sid, and he never answered me. I wrote to both of you, and you never answered me. I wrote to Tom and Sid, and they never answered me. I wrote to Tom, and he never answered me. I wrote to Sid, and he never answered me. I wrote to both of you, and you never answered me. I wrote to Tom and Sid, and they never answered me. I wrote to Tom, and he never answered me. I wrote to Sid, and he never answered me. I wrote to both of you, and you never answered me. I wrote to Tom and Sid, and they never answered me.”

Aunt Sally said: “Why, Aunt Polly, I never got any of those letters.”

Aunt Polly said: “Well, I did write them, and I know it, for I kept the copies.”

Then she turned slowly and severely toward Tom, and said: “Now, Tom Sawyer, where are those letters?”

Tom looked a little uneasy, and said: “Well, I—I don’t know as I’ve got ’em.”

Aunt Polly said: “You have got ’em, Tom Sawyer. I know you have. I know you’ve been keeping them from me, and I know you’ve been keeping them from Aunt Sally. Now, Tom Sawyer, where are they?”

Tom said: “Well, I—I don’t know as I’ve been keeping ’em from you, but I’ve been keeping ’em from myself, and I’ve been keeping ’em from Aunt Sally, and I’ve been keeping ’em from the whole world. I’ve been keeping ’em in my trunk, and I’ve been keeping ’em unopened.”

Aunt Polly said: “Well, Tom Sawyer, you certainly deserve a whipping for that.”

She said she had written another letter to Aunt Sally, telling her that she was coming, and Aunt Sally said she had got that letter the day before, but hadn’t read it yet.

Huck looked at her, and thought to himself that if he had a hundred dollars he’d bet she hadn’t got it at all, but he didn’t say so, because it was safer not to.

events.title: Tom's Grandiose Post-Evasion Plan Revealed
detailed_summary: Huck inquires about Tom's original intentions for Jim's escape, considering Jim was already a free man.
Tom reveals an elaborate scheme he had conceived from the beginning.
The plan involved them accompanying Jim on the raft down to the river's mouth, enjoying adventures along the way.
Only at the end of this journey would they inform Jim of his freedom.
Following this revelation, they were to bring Jim back home in luxury on a steamboat.
Tom also intended to compensate Jim for his time spent as a captive.
The climax of Tom's plan was to be a grand, orchestrated welcome for Jim, featuring a torchlight procession and a brass band, which would establish Tom, Huck, and Jim as heroes.
Huck reflects that the way events actually transpired was probably just as satisfactory.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The first time I catched Tom private I asked him what was his idea, time of the evasion?—what it was he’d planned to do if the evasion worked all right and he managed to set a nigger free that was already free before?
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: But I reckoned it was about as well the way it was.

events.text_segment: The first time I catched Tom private I asked him what was his idea, time of the evasion?—what it was he’d planned to do if the evasion worked all right and he managed to set a nigger free that was already free before? And he said, what he had planned in his head from the start, if we got Jim out all safe, was for us to run him down the river on the raft, and have adventures plumb to the mouth of the river, and then tell him about his being free, and take him back up home on a steamboat, in style, and pay him for his lost time, and write word ahead and get out all the niggers around, and have them waltz him into town with a torchlight procession and a brass-band, and then he would be a hero, and so would we. But I reckoned it was about as well the way it was.

events.title: Jim's Liberation, Recognition, and Fortuitous Reward
detailed_summary: Jim was quickly released from his chains.
Aunt Polly, Uncle Silas, and Aunt Sally showed great appreciation for Jim after learning how diligently he assisted the doctor in caring for Tom during his injury.
They treated Jim exceptionally well, providing him with ample food, leisure, and relieving him of any chores.
Jim was brought to Tom's sick-room where they engaged in a significant and uplifting conversation.
Tom presented Jim with forty dollars as compensation for his patient and commendable role as a prisoner during the elaborate, and ultimately unnecessary, escape plot.

Jim was immensely pleased by this monetary reward, exclaiming that his earlier premonition on Jackson's Island—about regaining wealth, which he believed was signified by his hairy chest—had now demonstrably come true.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: We had Jim out of the chains in no time, and when Aunt Polly and Uncle Silas and Aunt Sally found out how good he helped the doctor nurse Tom, they made a heap of fuss over him, and fixed him up prime, and give him all he wanted to eat, and a good time, and nothing to do.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Dah, now! doan’ talk to me—signs is signs, mine I tell you; en I knowed jis’ ’s well ’at I ’uz gwineter be rich agin as I’s a-stannin’ heah dis minute!”

events.text_segment:
We had Jim out of the chains in no time, and when Aunt Polly and Uncle Silas and Aunt Sally found out how good he helped the doctor nurse Tom, they made a heap of fuss over him, and fixed him up prime, and give him all he wanted to eat, and a good time, and nothing to do. And we had him up to the sick-room, and had a high talk; and Tom give Jim forty dollars for being prisoner for us so patient, and doing it up so good, and Jim was pleased most to death, and busted out, and says:
“Dah, now, Huck, what I tell you?—what I tell you up dah on Jackson islan’? I tole you I got a hairy breas’, en what’s de sign un it; en I tole you I ben rich wunst, en gwineter to be rich agin; en it’s come true; en heah she is! Dah, now! doan’ talk to me—signs is signs, mine I tell you; en I knowed jis’ ’s well ’at I ’uz gwineter be rich agin as I’s a-stannin’ heah dis minute!”

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: We had Jim out of the chains in no time, and when Aunt Polly and Uncle Silas and Aunt Sally found out how good he helped the doctor nurse Tom, they made a heap of fuss over him, and fixed him up prime, and give him all he wanted to eat, and a good time, and nothing to do. They brought him to Tom's room, and he had a long talk with him, and Tom told him he was the best friend he had in the world, and that he was sorry for the way he had treated him, and that he would make it up to him if he ever could. Then Tom give him forty dollars, and said it was for being a prisoner and all, and for going through with the whole business, and for being so patient and good about it. Jim was might glad, and said he reckoned he was rich now, and that he had always had a kind of feeling he was going to be, ever since he had that hair come on his chest when he was down on Jackson's Island, and he had always thought that was a sign.

events.title: Plans for New Adventures and Pap's Fate Revealed
detailed_summary: Tom, still in recovery, enthusiastically proposed that he, Huck, and Jim embark on a new series of adventures.

His plan was for the three of them to secretly depart one night, acquire the necessary gear, and spend a couple of weeks experiencing thrilling escapades among the Native American communities in the Territory.
Huck expressed his immediate agreement and enthusiasm for this new plan.

However, Huck then voiced a practical concern: he believed he lacked any money for the required outfit, assuming his absent father had returned, claimed his six thousand dollars from Judge Thatcher, and squandered it all on alcohol.
Tom corrected Huck, reassuring him that his substantial sum of money was still untouched and safe, and that Pap had not made an appearance since Huck's departure.
At this point, Jim interjected with a solemn and serious tone, informing Huck that his father would not be returning, ever.

When Huck pressed for an explanation for this definitive statement, Jim reminded him of the floating house they had encountered earlier on their river journey, which contained a deceased man covered by a blanket.

Jim then revealed the critical information he had withheld at the time: he had entered the house, uncovered the man, and deliberately prevented Huck from seeing the body, confirming now that the deceased individual was indeed Huck's father. This revelation meant Huck could finally access his inheritance.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: And then Tom he talked along and talked along, and says, le’s all three slide out of here one of these nights and get an outfit, and go for howling adventures amongst the Injuns, over in the Territory, for a couple of weeks or two; and I says, all right, that suits me, but I ain’t got no money for to buy the outfit, and I reckon I couldn’t get none from home, because it’s likely pap’s been back before now, and got it all away from Judge Thatcher and drunk it up.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Well, den, you kin git yo’ money when you wants it, kase dat wuz him.”

events.text_segment:
And then Tom he talked along and talked along, and says, le’s all three slide out of here one of these nights and get an outfit, and go for howling adventures amongst the Injuns, over in the Territory, for a couple of weeks or two; and I says, all right, that suits me, but I ain’t got no money for to buy the outfit, and I reckon I couldn’t get none from home, because it’s likely pap’s been back before now, and got it all away from Judge Thatcher and drunk it up.
“No, he hain’t,” Tom says; “it’s all there yet—six thousand dollars and more; and your pap hain’t ever been back since. Hadn’t when I come away, anyhow.”
Jim says, kind of solemn:
“He ain’t a-comin’ back no mo’, Huck.”
I says:
“Why, Jim?”
“Nemmine why, Huck—but he ain’t comin’ back no mo.”
But I kept at him; so at last he says:
“Doan’ you ’member de house dat was float’n down de river, en dey wuz a man in dah, kivered up, en I went in en unkivered him and didn’ let you come in? Well, den, you kin git yo’ money when you wants it, kase dat wuz him.”

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: And then Tom he talked along and talked along, and says, le’s all three slide out of here one of these nights and get an outfit, and go for howling adventures amongst the Injuns, over in the Territory, for a couple of weeks or two; and I says, all right, that suits me, but I ain’t got no money for to buy the outfit, and I reckon I couldn’t get none from home, because it’s likely pap’s been back before now, and got it all away from Judge Thatcher and drunk it up. Tom says, no, he ain’t been back, and he ain’t got it, and he never will, and I says, why, how do you know? He says, because I seen him, and he’s dead, and I says, who? He says, your pap. I says, how do you know? He says, because I went aboard that floating house and I looked at him, and he was dead, and I knowed him by his clothes, and I knowed it was your pap, and I didn’t tell you because I didn’t want to make you feel bad, and I says, why, Jim, how come you didn’t tell me that before? He says, because I didn’t want to make you feel bad, and I says, well, I don’t feel bad, I feel good, because now I can get my money, and I ain’t got to worry about pap no more.

events.title: Huck's Farewell to Writing and Rejection of Civilization
detailed_summary: Tom is described as being almost fully recovered from his gunshot wound.
He now conspicuously wears the bullet that was extracted from his leg on a watch-guard around his neck, treating it as a memento and frequently consulting it as if it were a timepiece.
Huck declares that with these recent events resolved, there is nothing further of significance to narrate in his book.

He expresses immense relief at concluding his writing endeavor, admitting candidly that had he known beforehand the considerable trouble and effort involved in creating a book, he would never have embarked on the project and has no intention of ever undertaking such a task again.
Huck concludes his account by stating his firm intention to depart for the Territory ahead of the others.

His primary motivation for this preemptive departure is that Aunt Sally has plans to formally adopt him and attempt to "sivilize" him, an experience he finds unbearable and is determined to avoid, having endured it previously.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Tom’s most well now, and got his bullet around his neck on a watch-guard for a watch, and is always seeing what time it is, and so there ain’t nothing more to write about, and I am rotten glad of it, because if I’d a knowed what a trouble it was to make a book I wouldn’t a tackled it, and ain’t a-going to no more.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: I been there before.

events.text_segment: Tom’s most well now, and got his bullet around his neck on a watch-guard for a watch, and is always seeing what time it is, and so there ain’t nothing more to write about, and I am rotten glad of it, because if I’d a knowed what a trouble it was to make a book I wouldn’t a tackled it, and ain’t a-going to no more. But I reckon I got to light out for the Territory ahead of the rest, because Aunt Sally she’s going to adopt me and sivilize me, and I can’t stand it. I been there before.
